The soba was decent, but the mochi had a deep and distinct flavor of fish - as if they not only cook it all in the same oil, but they don't change the oil often enough. It was a cold day, and at the end I asked for sobayu (the hot soba cooking water you're supposed to mix with the dipping sauce and drink at the end) and the waiter said "no, we don't have that," which is super weird because they cook soba there. So, also not very authentic.
author: Michelle V.

description:
My review back in 2015 was 5 stars and my review now is still 5 stars! 

Seriously the best ramen I've ever had. I've ate at plenty of other ramen places but I still reminisce about this place. I actually had to take my mom here, 1 1/2 hr drive but totally worth it! (she agrees) 

We came in at 11am (before lunch time) and it wasn't packed at all! Loved it. We ordered an order of the calimari appetizer and OMG! It was a big hit! The fried calimari isn't like any other calimari. It was actual squid legs. They were huge and had a nice crunch to it! Love love love! My new favorite from this place. You MUST try it!

For ramen, I almost always order the spicy beef (because every other ramen has pork and I'm not a big fan of pork). It's not at all spicy and the beef is just...amazing! They're cut into perfect little cubes and the texture is super soft. You bite into it and it'll just break apart. The broth is suuuuper delish and not at all too creamy. 

Overall, I brag about this place to everyone saying it's the best ramen place ever because to my tastebuds, they think it is. I think of this place whenever I go to another ramen place because I feel like I'm cheating on it hehe.
author: Donna H.

description: Suprised to see this ramen place at a mall, and truly loved the experience! Will definitely go back!
author: Sarah O.

description:
I have had ramen at restaurants maybe twice in my entire life, so I am no ramen expert by any means. 

I really liked their fried chicken pieces. They were really crispy and delicious. I ordered their ABC Ramen and the entree was a bit disappointing. There were very little noodles and the meat didn't taste too fresh. There were also not a lot of meats included with my order. The broth was also very oily and unsatisfying. 

I honestly think you are better off ordering Panda Express or that Japanese Grill place next door because those places don't cost a leg and a foot for a mediocre meal.
author: Philip M.

description:
I had the Chicken Ramen with the pork broth and it was amazing. I couldn't believe that my bowl was over so soon. Delicious. Spice level = perfect. Happy this place is near my house. Will start visiting this often. 

Great food Ajisen Ramen !!
author: Anurag K.

description:
Food: 5/5
Nothing to complain about I thought the food was really good and flavorful.

Service: 4.8/5
I honestly like it when waiters just leave us to eat and not keep coming back so I don't have any complaints about their service. They sat us down, took our order, brought us water, and gave us the bill when we asked. Simply and quick.

The only thing I didn't really like was how it's always so busy. I sat facing the mall so everyone who's waiting to be seated stares you down while eating so it feels kinda uncomfortable but that's understandable since they just want us to hurry up and leave. It also gets really nosy but again it's in the mall so it can't be controlled.
author: May G.

description: Our server was very shy but nice and informative. My boyfriend and little brother got the spicy beef soup. If you love Bun Bo Hue and are craving for some spicy soup, I think you'll love the spicy beef soup. I got the Summer (spicy miso broth). We all asked for it to be made extra spicy. The broth is very flavorful and they give you a pretty good amount of food in their entree.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Not bad given the location! Obviously, there are a variety of Ramen locations in San Francisco -- this is a nice choice if you don't feel like venturing out to Chinatown or further west in the city.
author: Zachary T.

description: I came here twice in one week since it's near my work and I caught a cold (summer colds - boooo!) so I figured hot, spicy soup would help. Ajisen Ramen is a gem for food court food. Convenient location in Westfield Mall, so easy to get to on foot or by BART/MUNI. Every time I've come here, there was a line to dine in. It went by fast-ish after putting my name down (less than 20 min wait), but if you want faster service then perhaps consider getting take-out and sitting somewhere else, or come during off hours. Since it's located to a bunch of offices, weekday lunches gets really busy, expectedly. It's a little strange sitting at one of the tables near the entrance since a bunch of people are hanging around nearby watching (lol), but fine otherwise. Staff is friendly and service is pretty quick once you've put your order in.
author: Bianca C.

description:
The food : I came here a few times but finally found time to write reviews. It's a chain, so to be fair it's not one of the best ramen places but it's consistent. Great place to grab a quick bowl of ramen. we only waited around 5 minutes on Friday for lunch. We ordered spicy pork ramen and spicy seafood ramen, and some deep fried octopus and a mango boba drink . We slurped down everything- The soup was pretty tasty . 
Service : Very quick and attentive service. They came out to take the order as soon as we sat down. Asked for some water and they came right away. 
I would come here next time I'm in SF if I want to quick ramen fix.
author: Lucy L.

description:
Ramen chain with branch  in Westfield food court. 

Gyoza - 2/5
Tantan ramen - 3/5 - Decent but not enough sesame flavor.
Mochi tempura - 2/5

Overall, Ajisen is a reliable chain with good prices and lots of options.  "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
This place is located inside of a mall, normally mall food isn't very good but this Ramen is pretty good. If you are in the mall area and looking for some Ramen you should stop in here and check it out.

I was very surprised how good it was I was skeptical at first but the pork Ramen is very good and has a lot of delicious flavor to it.
author: Netin V.

description:
This is my 4th time here in one year.

We went to Westfield on Saturday and had lunch at Ajisen. I ordered Combo Ramen($11.50) and Thai Iced Tea($3.75). My husband ordered Chicken Ramen($9.75). 

We came before noon so we got seated sooner than the past that we had a quite long wait. The server, Kimmy, was nice and fast. The food was hot when served and looked delicious, especially when you are hungry. I'm not sure what's wrong, if they had a new chef or different ingredients, but they don't taste as flavorful like they used to.

My husband and I both agreed that the element of surprise was gone.
author: Marilyn B.

description: Okay food but really bad service. They didn't hear my order clear and blamed on me. And not just one server had a bad mood. Disappointed.
author: Ruonan H.

description: Expensive compared to other Ajisen. Service is horrible and they short change on the food. There's another food court on the Westfield side that has better food for the same price, or you can go next door to the Japanese grill place or Chipotle. Will never visit this Ajisen again.
author: Ken Y.

description:
I usually end up eating here because Ajisen is one of the better places to eat in the food court and prices are reasonable!

My go-to order is the corn and bbq pork ramen. It's not authentic ramen but you can't expect authenticity with franchise restaurants - still pretty tasty!!  
However, my only complaint it the temperature of the soup. The soup comes warm and never hot =/ so it's a little disappointing if you're a slow eater.
author: Leilani Y.

description: I usually get the Ajisen Best Combo Ramen as it has the Tender pork Ribs, Premium Pork, and BBQ Pork. It's $11.50 and taste really great on a rainy day. Sometimes the wait is long for a table so as soon as you walk up you need to write your name on the clipboard!
author: James H.

description:
Short for time and starving. I don't know what I was expecting from Ramen in a mall. 
Pro: This place will feed you if you're hungry.......
Tip: eat before you shop.
author: Mary C.

description:
Generally not a fan of mall food courts, I was taken by surprise by Ajisen Ramen. It wasn't the best ramen I've ever had, but it certainly wasn't the worst.

The menu has pictures of the food next to the name, which calls for some bias, as I tend to eat with my eyes while hungry. Not surprisingly, I settled for the Ajisen Best Combo (ABC) ramen, which is the first item in the menu. With the variety of protein -- thin premium pork, chasu, and pork rib meat -- the ABC ramen is a good option if you want different cuts and flavor. To me, the premium pork was good, but the chasu and rib meat were just okay. The tonkotsu broth was creamy, but not rich enough. And although there were kikurage mushrooms, green onions, and green cabbage in that ramen, I still felt like some key ingredients were lacking, such as dried seaweed, bamboo shoots, and a soft-boiled egg.

Overall, Ajisen Ramen would satisfy my ramen cravings if I'm at Union Square and not wanting to endure the wait at Katana-Ya. Though, I wouldn't make the effort to come here just for ramen.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
The roommate's family friends from Korea were visiting last year and his mother wanted to take them to the mall for Panda Express. (Don't ask. I didn't.) Instead of American Chinese food, I thought I'd take the opportunity to try Ajisen! They ate outside in the food court tables, so I got my order to go and sat with them.

March 2013
Ajisen best combo ramen ($10.75) Spicy (+$1)
*Noodles & toppings http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ajisen-ramen-san-francisco#RaulDnHRGpX2SKjAMymdHQ
*Soup http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ajisen-ramen-san-francisco#BHHAlXQ0FMIVESL-6FsSCg
*Boba milk tea ($3.75) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ajisen-ramen-san-francisco#30dvJvXUXq3Wn8szxRWOow

I thought the ramen was okay. The soup could have used more body and spice. And there could have been more veggies, but the meat was tender. And the bowl did satisfy my soup craving. The boba was okay as well. The balls were chewy and the milk tea wasn't too sweet.

If you need a quick ramen fix and don't want to wait for a seat at some of the other ramen shops, Ajisen is an alternative. I'd say this is like eating the fast food of ramen!
author: Elena N.

description:
It's not bad for a chain Ramen shop, especially being in a mall. I came in with very low expectations so it definitely met my expectations if not more.

Decently sized and conveniently located in the food court of Westfield Mall in San Francisco. They have quite a few options and add ons. I usually go with the Shoyu or spicy pork ramen. Generally comes out to about $13-15 with tip depending on the add ons you get.

Like I said before, its not to die for, but when you're craving ramen and don't feel like venturing too far out of the Union Square area, this would be the go-to spot as beggars can't be choosers. Plus I've had way worse ramen for a longer wait and higher cost.
author: Milton F.

description:
The selection of ramens was pretty overwhelming. I just ended up getting the ajisen best combo ramen to get a variety of pork meats and get something more traditional. 

The noodles were pretty meh. They were pretty firm for ramen noodles and the texture was a bit off. The premium pork was okay, but slightly dry. The bbq pork didn't taste much different than the premium pork and the short ribs was mediocre. Normally, ramen broths don't make me thirsty, but this made me crazy thirsty. I tried to drink some water, but I was too full.
author: Marco C.

description: Been here on multiple occasions but today was the day I would ask for extra pork for my ramen for the first time. Instead of getting pork, I received less pork than the regular serving AND was charged for "extra spicy pork". WTF. Their definition of that was for the soup to be more spicy, when I had specifically asked for extra pork. REALLY..
author: Johnson Q.

description:
A pretty popular ramen place inside the SF Westfield mall, which has many dining options.  We tried it for lunch after some window shopping.  They had a sign-in sheet so it's obviously very popular (it seats 50).

We shared some apps - the gyoza (small, but well flavored) and the fried calamari (seasoned but a bit hard to eat due to large portions).  The menu showed the calamari as grilled, but it's actually like tempura style.

For ramen, we both got their special combo ramen.  The broth was light and creamy.  Very good and drinkable.  Noodles were small-diameter but very chewy.  The meats are what really shined - I believe they add pork rib meat, BBQ pork, and their premium pork.   Very tender and good balance of meat and fat.

A minor gripe here is that they don't offer hot tea.  Service otherwise fast and friendly.
author: Daniel C.

description: Early morning eat here for my breakfast. Like their Ramen a lot. Since I'm the Ramen fun. Price is ok, if you want hang out with friend or shopping in the mall, it's a good place for you to eat your lunch. Will come back. I like their spicy ramen however I forgot the exactly name about that.
author: Yueming G.

description:
Not bad for a mall restaurant! The wait was fairly quick-- I suppose Ajisen has been here long enough where they have an efficient system. This place tends to be packed, definitely more people than Chipotle and Sarku. I typically change my order around, but in general we get ramen and an appetizer. 

We ordered corn w bbq ramen, pork ramen and karage. The karage is meh, but it went well with the ramen. Their noodles are not thick, or chewy, but the broth was tasty. The corn really adds flavor AND color to the ramen. I think that's my go-to ramen now (instead of regular ajisen). Like other yelp-ers have commented, it is not authentic ramen, but it does the job! I'm always full when I finish. The warm soup feels great on a cold SF night. They unfortunately don't have a wide selection of appetizers, so I typically stick with the karage or edamame. I have tried their spicy squid, but it tastes very one-dimensional and was TOO spicy.
author: Connie L.

description:
Ordered Ajisen Special Pork Combo, Ajisen ramen, shoyu ramen after happy hour in the city with friends. 

Was very disappointed with the egg which came with the Ajisen ramen. hardboiled & not softboiled like how it should be served in a bowl of ramen. Nowhere in Tokyo will you find hardboiled egg in ramen. I always look forward of perfectly cooked softboiled egg in my ramen. The place was suggested by a friend & I didn't check the various pics on Yelp. Luckily, it was my friend's order & I didn't have to eat that

Mine was the Special Pork Combo. It was just A-OK. broth was flavourful but the pork wasn't melt in the mouth kind. The shredded cabbage was thicker than I would like it.

Would I go again? yes, only for a quick bite. There are other better ramen places
author: Sonia F.

description: I love this restaurant when I visited Hong Kong. I was definitely in awe when they open this one in San Francisco. This place has decent ramen. The location is small and sometimes feels crammed when it's lunch rush. The workers there are quick to follow through on your orders. The food doesn't take forever to come out of the kitchen. Good quality ramen. I really enjoy their promotion on checking into either yelp or facebook, and you can buy one and get one free drink. It definitely made the environment more lively and affordable. I ended up leaving with a satisfied stomach. I would recommend this place as a good affordable ramen joint in the city.
author: Ruby C.

description: Was in the mall early and found ourselves cold for the SF weather.  Was glad that this place opened at 10:30am. It is not in the food court area but to the right in its own nook. Gets pretty packed even at opening. Ramen was good and had good portion.  We got the BOGO drink offer with Yelp check in.
author: Emma G.

description: Ramen was delicious and very fast service. The servers were friendly, and i would come again whenever i am here
author: Lourence D.

description:
I was unsure about trying a food court ramen joint, but this place is nearly as good as it gets. Is it as good at Katana-ya? No, it is not. It is better than any other fast service ramen place in town? Probably.

The menu is robust and they offer something for everyone. I got the spicy pork combo ramen, and wow, that was delicious. The fried chicken is also very good and comes with a decadent sauce on the side.

Don't let the location fool you. This is A+ ramen!
author: Luis P.

description: Rich in flavor. Wish they has a veggie option for all my vegetarian friends.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This ramen place is pretty decent, but delicious.

I only go there on the weekdays with no waiting lines and no signing the clipboard. 

My favorite ramen is The Miso Ramen with BBQ pork. I love the way the miso broth tasted and cooked to perfection. 

Service is pretty good and accommodating as well.

If your in the mall area on the weekdays, go there. Weekends aren't good due to high traffic inside the mall.
author: Cindy G.

description: Came here to eat Ramen today. The Ramen was good. I ordered the Beef Ramen, and it was good! I will definitely be back to try other Ramen in the future.
author: Patrick T.

description:
I've been wanting to try Ajisen ramen for the loooongest time, as I am a huge ramen fan. 

Long story short, it is very mediocre ramen that I would not come back to again. It is something to try once to satisfy your curiosity but that's it.

I ordered the best combo ramen, and paid an additional dollar to have the spicy broth. It wasn't spicy at all and the broth was a bit bland, so I had to add a tonnnn of chili powder. The noodles were thin, unlike most ramen places whose noodles are a bit chewy and thicker. The meat was pretty bland as well besides their charsiu, and although it was salty, it probably the best part of the dish. Overall, not really worth it but a one time try. It was a bit disappointing :(
author: Cassie T.

description:
Came here  to get some quick dinner with my hunny. He always comes here for lunch and my first time here. I wasn't in the mood in getting ramen but the hunny did so I ordered chicken karaage. It was good and good portion for an appetizer. I also got a seaweed salad which was good. The ramen broth and pork was good. I would have given this place 4 stars but the server FORGOT the ramen which we ordered and mentioned to her first before anything else. Basically the server FORGOT to place our order. Poor hunny, he was waiting for 15 -20 minutes already and my food was almost gone and I was full. Finally it came, but hunny said it didn't taste as good because they rushed the order since they FORGOT it.
Oh well, atleast I discovered that this place is not bad and another option to eat besides the foodcourt below bloomies.
TIP: WAIT to get seated and don't walk up to the counter. There is Big sign in the front saying wait to be seated and there could be a long list too, so wait your turn.
author: Claudine V.

description:
Ramen is marginally better than Shin Black Label (Korean instant noodles)

Eating here is like getting ramen at one of those Richmond dessert houses... food is comparable and it's also made by Chinese people

One star for the location and one star for the awesome prices considering location + table service
author: Roger L.

description: Theres usually a line but i've never waited more than 10mins for a table. Theres usually only 2-3 servers working so they don't really check on the tables,but overall the service is great and the ramen soups are delicious . I usually get the spicy pork, if you're into spicy food thats a must !
author: Claudia B.

description:
It's good after a long day of work. Is it superb? Not really. I like that the aji ramen combo is not salty. The broth is slight creamy and refreshing. The pork with tendon is great. 3.75

The hard boiled egg costs $1. I was hoping for creamy yolk. Nope.
author: Ann K.

description:
My sister and I were greeted by super friendly staff. After considering all the Westfield food court options, this seemed like the best bet for my noodle craving.

While the broth was meh, the noodles meh, the pork meh, it was enough to satisfy my ramen craving. Good enough for $10ish dollars at the mall.

The special sushi roll we ordered here was excellent though--filled to the brim with crab, topped with delicious uni, and topped with bonito fish flakes for that extra unami!

I'll come back!
author: Michelle N.

description:
I've had a lot of ramen in my life and this place is seriously my ultimate all time favorite ramen joint! 

You just can't go wrong with their Premium Pork Ramen!! The pork is cooked to perfection and their tonkatsu broth is exactly how I like it! Creamy, rich and full of flavor!

I also like their fried tofu appetizer. You get two pieces of tofu. 

This spot is my go to mall food. I always got to get my Premium Pork Ramen fix before leaving this mall.
author: Alice X.

description: Too long of a line at most of the other places in the city.  My friend and I decided to come here. I was really surprised at how good it was since it's in the mall. Got the pork broth, super super tasty. It got really busy with people and the waitresses seemed overload. Food took some time to come out but they were apologetic and graceful about it all. I'll come back.
author: Natasha S.

description: The ramen is decent and decently priced. Our waiter messed up our order but apologized by offering us free drinks. Mess ups are bond to happen so the fact she tried to make up is a sign of good service effort. Although the drinks weren't great so I wouldn't order them at this place, just FYI. But the ramen was on point and hey, that's what we come here for right?
author: Sue L.

description: We weren't planning on eating here but we just couldn't resist having ramen one last time before leaving SF. I'm glad we did because the broth here was amazing. It was so creamy and I just wanted to drink the whole bowl. I ordered my ramen with bbq pork and corn. The ramen was a bit different than the typical ramen. It was like the Chinese pulled noodles but still had some chewy texture to it. I would highly recommend this place if you are ever in the Westfield mall.
author: Karen K.

description:
RAAAAAAAAAAMMMEENNNNNN.

Some simple notes:
1. Conveniently in the Westfield center in downtown SF.
2. Resonance prices for ramen ($7.50-$9.00 at the most)
3. Generous portions

This place makes me sleepy as hell after I eat here. Food knows it has done a good job if it can make the consumers sleepy afterwards.

I've tried the following:

- Spicy Pork Miso: not that spicy but it has a creamy broth and generous amounts of pork, noodles, and veggies. Corn is my addiction in ramen and they give a nice amount to me loves it long time.

- Shoyu ramen: a more simpler ramen with a less creamy soup. Not my most favorite however because it was a bit too bland for me, and the noodles were kinda tough.

- Ajisen ramen: one of the cheaper ramen noodles here (like $7.50) and probably one of my favorites. The creamy buttery soup really goes well with the pork slices. And corn corn corn corn. I laaaahve corn. And buttery soup. And soft noodles. Urgh.

-Assorted veggies: this one is like the Shoyu ramen. Non creamy base, but a nice helping of veggies and noodles.

- Agedashi tofu: super hot when it comes out, but pretty chewy and fresh. Crispy exterior with that soy sauce works well.

- Dragon roll: typical dragon roll with loads of benito flakes on top. It was okay. Nothing too special. 

- Cranberry yogurt juice: holy hell I lahve this. Cranberry and yakkult mixed together. Ugh sweet, tart, refreshing.

What I don't like is how cramped it is in here. And it gets busy eeeef. But otherwise, it's alright in my book.
author: Jerianne G.

description:
Top Ramen this is not! And thank goodness 'cause I've eaten enough of those when I was in college. Love that all of these ramen places are popping up in the Bay Area!  The rich savory broth, tasty pork slices and ramen noodles make it such a delicious all in one meal.  I usually get the Ajisen Best Combo which is not particularly spicy, but you can add some hot sauce or shichimi.  I've also ordered the Spicy Ramen in the past, and that was quite spicy. A bowl of their ramen is big enough to satisfy a hearty appetite. I don't even have room for water after eating!  It's so filling! 

Sometimes, if we're really famished, we'll order an appetizer before our ramen. We've had their Karaage and Gyoza.  Both come out piping hot. The Karaage is not too heavily breaded and it comes with aioli. The Gyoza is tasty. 

Service is attentive. They're always ready to refill your water. If there is a wait, it's usually not bad. A table will soon be available, so don't go too far once you've put your name on the list. The price is good too. Where in SF can you eat under $12 a person in a full service sit down restaurant? This place may be in a mall, and may not be as good as Orenchi, but I am so happy to be able to eat ramen when I'm craving it and do some shopping as well.
author: Hazel C.

description: Hungry for ramen or pork cutlet and curry? Give Ajisen a try. Then ramen is very good and tasty. Prices are fair and ambiance is good for a fast food place in the mall.
author: Michael M.

description:
Eating in a mall
That should have been my first clue
Peanut butter soup

Yup. In a city like San Francisco, I did the unthinkable. I ate a meal in a mall food court. Why? Well, location, hunger, time constraints and Yelp reviews. That's why. And surprisingly, my mall ramen experience here was not nearly as bad as most mall dining experiences. In fact, it was actually A-OK. For what it was, at least. 

Many ramen joints in The City don't open until dinner time. Why? I don't know. I like ramen for lunch sometimes. Because soup for breakfast, soup for lunch, soup for dinner. Soup all the time. That's why. Anyway, Ajisen is open for lunch, and it's convenient. And the soup? Really not all that bad. Definitely not vying for a top ramen spot, but operating at a much higher level than the vast majority of mall food. 

I tried the tantanmen, a current obsession of mine. The broth here is very heavy-handed - mostly just peanut with a bit of other depth to it. Nothing like the tantanmen I've had anywhere else. But the noodles here were decent, and the size for the price is generous. A sampling of my dining companion's pork ramen confirmed a similar heavy hand with the broth there too. 

Our gyoza and fried mochi appetizers were passable. The thai tea is overly sweet - but will appeal to a mall audience. 

With all the amazing food offerings in this city, I can't see myself returning. But if I worked nearby, this could be a stop every couple of months, for convenience sake. Yes, it's in a mall, but it's way better than most mall food.
author: Don B.

description:
Spicy pork ramen, fried calamari and honey aloe drink are my favorites at Ajisen. 

I didn't order the spicy pork ramen. I tried a few spoonfuls of my friend's spicy pork ramen. It was flavorful & yummy and I wanted more. But I ordered the Ajisen ramen and I wasn't too satisfied with it.

Surprisingly, when I ordered the fried calamari it was good & crispy! Maybe it's my preferred taste. Anyway, usually I do not order fried calamari at Asian restaurants because its totally different from the "original" calamari. But I was craving for fried calamari that day and said why not! And I'm glad I did! 

The honey aloe drink is delicious & refreshing. The aloe is the real kind of aloe. I enjoyed the drink very much. 

The service was slow. Maybe it was during lunch hours. There was only about 2 servers on the floor waiting the tables. There should be more than 2.
author: Kathleen U.

description: My friend and I came here for lunch yesterday. We waited 30 mins, but it was worth it! I order the spicy pork ramen and my friend ordered the seafood ramen. The broth in both were very tasty!!! I just wish they had add-ons. The tea was very good a well. It's definitely in my go-to list, especially if I don't feel like driving to Raman dojo or Ramen Parlor.
author: Rochelle S.

description: The service is good. Friendly and attentive staff and quick service. Taste is okay. Had ramen and eel with rice.
author: B C.

description: This place is average. I'm sick so I had the volcano ramen and it wasn't spicy enough. I choked on a cabbage piece and had coughing fit... they probably thought I was choking from how spicy it was LMAO.
author: Anny H.

description:
For the last week and a half I've been coughing quite heavily. After work today I came here for a quick dinner after I was done shopping at Champs Sports. I thought chicken ramen soup would help, but I was distracted by the fried chicken ramen soup. Common sense would suggest that fried chicken wouldn't help my cough. I forego common sense - I decided to order the fried chicken ramen soup. I also ordered another dish the baked eel. 

Several minutes my ramen arrived but not my fried chicken. The waitress said the fried chicken will come later. When I go out to eat I don't care about service too much as long as the food is good. However since the name of the dish is fried chicken ramen soup I expected the fried chicken to arrive at the same time. Imagine if you ordered a bbq pork fried rice the fried rice came but not the bbq pork. Or if you ordered broccoli beef the broccoli came but not the beef. That's how I felt with the fried chicken ramen soup. I didn't want to eat the ramen until the fried chicken was served. About five minutes later the fried chicken arrived. Luckily the broth of the ramen remained hot.

The fried chicken is chicken karaage, which is a Japanese version of fried chicken. The chicken karaage was moist in the inside, but not crispy enough on the outside. The broth was tasty and the noodles were tender. The dish overall was ok. The baked eel however was much better than the fried chicken ramen soup. The eels I've had in the past were either too many boney or too oily. The baked eel was neither the case. The meat was tender yet not too oily. The skin had a slight crispiness. 

This is a decent place to have a quick dinner. Overall did the fried chicken ramen soup help get rid of my cough? No. What can you say I'm a sucker for anything that is fried chicken.
author: Gerald R.

description: Fast and delicious. Awesome lunch option. The portion is perfect and well balanced between pork and noodle and other ingredients. I got spicy pork noodle. Soup is yummy and did not leave me parched afterwards. Will definitely return. There is a bit of wait for dining in, but the to-go option is great. You don't need to pay tips and can get your food within 10 minutes. No need to stay in line.
author: Dancing S.

description:
Quick, cheap and decent ramen! :) 

SERVICE: 
There is never a wait when I come here and service is always quick.  

FOOD: 
There is a large variety of ramen in addition to katsu, curry and varies seafood salads. The ramen is very flavorful without having the amount of MSG that makes your mouth dry and isn't soaked in too much oil. The only complaints I have is that they use egg noodles instead of ramen noodles annd they don't have eggs like typical ramen does or as shown on the menu - which is misleading. 

Overall, decent Ramen place with the flavor, but without the actual ramen - haha.
author: Samantha F.

description:
All I remember is we got gyoza, boba tea and ramen! Maybe it was Ajisen ramen? Whatever it was it was all amazingggggg! New favorite ramen spot for sure.

I would seriously go here everyday if it wasn't an hour away.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Leaves you thirsty at the end of your meal, but I guess that's everywhere that serves soup? 

Half of the customers come here to eat alone. It's a convenient place for a quick meal if you're working nearby. 

I usually get Ajisen or corn ramen. If you have a large appetite, then one bowl will not be enough for you. I notice that ladies are typically full after one bowl and a drink. But the men tend to have a side dish.
author: Danae L.

description: The best ramen I've ever had. The spicy beef ramen! Full of flavor and the beef was tender.
author: Venetzy M.

description: Every time I come to the mall, Ramen is definitely a must especially this place. Strange that such a small place in the mall is not only so busy but actually has nice ramen too. I came here with my sisters and there was a bit of a wait, luckily I have some patience and waited the time I had to rather than just leaving especially since people thought it was okay to cut me and put their name on the list when clearly I was there before them. Quite annoying. But after maybe almost an hour later, we get sat, we look over the menu, make our selections quick and we chose our ramen selection. One shoyu ramen, spicy pork ramen and a premium pork ramen plus the gyoza as an appetizer. Food came out pretty quick, overall enjoyable. This place is definitely recommendable especially if you're a tourist look for something warm and "foreign" or even if you're just stopping by the mall for a quick bite.
author: Chantille T.

description:
When I lived in Hong Kong 7 years ago, I enjoyed eating at the Ajisen Ramen a lot.  My favorite was always its pork rib ramen.  I loved its tender meat, the crunchy cartilage, and most the robust and flavorful seasoning.  The rich and complex seasoning made the pork ribs really, really enjoyable.  I loved it in any Ajisen Ramen outlet in Hong Kong as they all shared the same wonderful flavor.  I would rate it 5* if there were Yelp in Hong Kong.

When I found Ajisen Ramen in San Francisco six years ago, I was delighted and readily patronized it.  Even though the meat and cartilage were familiar, I was disappointed that I did not find the same rich flavor.  I would eat it with some misgiving, trying to replenish the missing flavor with my fond memories from Hong Kong.  I rated it 3*, fair and edible.

Today, I ate pork rib ramen again.  I was really disappointed with the bland flavor and lackluster seasoning.  There were three pieces of big meat, and I ate them as they were tender and crunchy as they should be.  But I did not enjoy the flavorless meal.  Reluctantly, I have to rate it 2* as a poor meal.

I heard the owners of this San Francisco Ajisen Ramen is the same owner of the Hong Kong Ajisen.  If so, I wonder how can they allow the same food in SF to be 2* while their restaurants in Hong Kong can cook it into 5* fare.  Something terrible happened in their QA.  The owners should come to SF and eat their pork rib ramen and see for themselves.  Then maybe they would dispatch their HK chef to SF to teach the proper way to cook pork rib ramen.
author: Robert W.

description:
Not a bad ramen place at all. Especially for being inside the mall. At first, I thought it was towards the fancy food court, but I was wrong. It's downstairs near the Chipotle.

I got the Spicy Pork Ramen and it was indeed, spicy. I loved the heat but what I didn't care for were the chili flakes inside the broth. Everyone who eats ramen knows that you're slurpin down that broth along with all the noodles.

So I was slurpin away...*COUGH COUGH COUGH* a damn chili flake flies to the back of my throat causing me to cough uncontrollably. Not cool!

I would have liked a little bit more color in my ramen. Some fresh cabbage maybe? Check out my picture and see what looks like a lackluster bowl of noodles.

The pork was a tad dry and the noodles were all clumped together. 

This place gets packed and the ever growing line makes you feel like you're being rush.

Overall, for the price, this place really isn't all that bad. It wasn't the worst ramen that I've had, but it definitely wasn't the best. I didn't think that the broth was salty at all, but the heat level, to me, was pretty high. Gave me a good sweat!
author: Tiffany N.

description:
It's been 5 months, time for an update. Too bad, still not a fan of this place yet...

Actually came here twice to eat in and both times, service was quick and polite. Food came quickly after order. Piping hot as well (burned my tongue twice TT-TT). Ordered a Miso Ramen. The broth tasted the same as the broth used in Ajisen Ramen and Premium Pork but with a HINT of miso. Also, the noodles were tough to chew. As a small eater, this place was just right. I was able to finish my meal. Not sure if that's a good thing... 

If I had to choose between the 3 I've had, I think the Premium Pork is the way to go. Lots of pork with plenty of flavor! Spicy pork is also great as well (So I've heard).
author: Benita M.

description:
Been coming here for over 5 years. I moved to Sac and come up just to have the spicy beef ramen. So here's the verdict:

Spiciness...(I can eat a habenero raw and am on the journey to tasting all the different ghost peppers I can land. Just to give you an idea)
author: Desirea O.

description: I just can't resist ordering the fried chicken ramen because it tastes so amazing! I haven't even found another ramen place this good so I am very very happy with the food there. I think that all of the food is good but people don't order some of the things because the ramen fills you right up!
author: Claire T.

description: Not the best ramen I've ever had, but for what it's worth, it's pretty decent ramen! The noodles aren't as flavorful though and doesn't absorb any of the broth but the pork was really good and the broth alone is good!!
author: Emilio C.

description: Best Ramen i have ever had. Spicy beef ramen broth is amazing. The brown sugar milk tea is also good, but a little too sweet.
author: Nicole S.

description: The Ajisen Ramen was absolutely delicious! Rich broth and nice portion. The toppings were tasty too. I arrived at 11:30, so I beat the lunch rush. I have heard that going here for lunch is not an amazing experience because it's hard to get a seat, but I did not have an issue with this because I got there early. Service was fine, nothing spectacular though. I'd say it's a great place to grab a quick and yummy bite.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
It's a pretty sad day for SF when the best ramen place is in the mall.. This place is pretty good, not the best..doesn't give me the cravings and the shakes but it'll do. Prices are reasonable..around $10ish. Food is decent.. Service is nice.

The pork bone broth is not that flavorful but still good. The fried chicken that comes with the fried chicken ramen is great! Ask for srirarcha!!!

My last trip here I got the veggie ramen with pork bone broth cuz the veggies looked so bright and colorful! The shiitake mushrooms that came with it were really bland and didn't taste like shiitake mushrooms at all... The enoki mushrooms were good.. Corn was good.. Noodles were good.

Yea, everything here is decent but doesn't get me excited .. That's how I would summarize it..
author: Stephanie W.

description: Had the ajisen ramen and it was very bland for my taste, kind of like when you make ramen noodles at home and put way too much water in it. However, if that's what people like they should get this or if not maybe try the spicier ones? Definitely not my cup of tea slash bowl of ramen though.
author: Erika C.

description: Been here a year and a half ago once and loved it. Came back today since it was one of those extra cold San Francisco days but when is it not cold? Anyways coming here during dinner time around 7PM, you have to wait for a seat but it's not long before people slurp all their ramen. Last year I tried their corn and pork ramen so today id thought I get something different. I got something not too different just super super spicy. I got the Volcano Curry while my friend got the corn and pork ramen. I was hungry so I was ready for my food to come. Right when my food came, it was picture time then time to eat. The soup base looked extremely spicy, I mean on the menu it showed three chili peppers so that was expected. It also came with the usual tender pork meat(3 pcs), half a boiled egg, and some fungus I think. The ramen was perfect, not too soft and not hard at all. The soup base, oh man, I choked on my first bite because it was so spicy. Overall if you want something to warm your body up and enjoy spicyness, order the Volcano Ramen because it will warm your body in one minute.
author: Lisa W.

description:
The food is OK but the service is awful. It's not really busy at today's lunch time, the server didn't show like a server should do. We ordered Ramen and she even didn't give us chopsticks! But she asked the other lady in next of our table whether she'd like fork or chopsticks. 
At first we thought maybe because we are Chinese, she treat us like normal visitor, but later I heard she can speak and understand Chinese. That's really funny. She didn't show any good attitude and tried to make herself busy, but the thing is, really not busy at that time.

So no more next time.
author: Ounan R.

description:
The broth is really flavorful--they most likely put a lot of butter into it, because afterwards I felt sleepy all day!

The atmosphere is not bad, but hard to describe. It's located within the food court of a shopping mall, next to a Panda Express, but it's not really a fast food store, since it has it's own closed-off seating area and a hostess at the front to bring you to your seats. But in a way, it *is* set up like a fast food store, with a row of cash registers in the back and giant back-lit menus hanging from the ceiling behind the cash registers.

Most confusing setup ever.

Ramen is pretty nice though.
author: Henry L.

description:
Was this ramen or chewy spaghetti noodles in pork broth?

Cabbage? in my ramen? really? At least the broth was decent.

Fried chicken (karaage) was overfried -- think painful crunchy -- and kind of bland.

There was a line, but the wait was short.  With so many tables, the turnaround time is pretty quick.
author: Jennifer M.

description: if you're looking for ramen, you will instead find spaghetti.  the broth and meat were flavorful and the spaghetti was fine, but if you're craving actual ramen noodles, you won't find it here.  the pork rib was 99% fat.
author: Nedra D.

description:
I don't need to say much here: This international chain's soup base is made from a powder.  this is the mcdonald's of ramen.  

Truthbomb: SF needs to get over itself and learn what real ramen is like.
author: Daniel P.

description: Volcano ramen was deliciously spicy and crave-worthy! Not quite as unctuous as our favorite Bay Area ramen at Ramen Parlor on the peninsula (lobster pork broth-- yum!) but very satisfying and much better than you'd expect at a food court!
author: Emily E.

description:
I went to there once when I visited SF downtown during Spring Break.
Have been to this restaurant when I was in China, and the taste is nearly the same!
The price is acceptable and the service is good, it more likes a ramen fast good chain since the food comes fast and people eat fast here.
author: Betsy L.

description: Spicy beef . Try some. I added a picture for it. You should check out and see. If you have better beef , then it is discrimination.
author: Vegg C.

description:
STAY AWAY!
Well, I was about to write an excellent review for this place based on my experiences. It's my favorite place for ramen, which, considering it's in a mall is as shocking to me to be writing as it must be for you to be reading. However, now I'm being told that they've failed multiple health/safety inspections recently? Have I been deceived this whole time? Is an as-yet-unidentified disease contracted from food prepared under unhygienic conditions in my future? These and so many other questions are sure to keep me up at night over the coming weeks....

Update: I stopped by earlier this week, and found out that they are failing to display their health inspection report, as required by LAW. Avoid this place at all costs.
author: Mike S.

description:
Can't quite remember what the ramen tasted like, had it years ago but it was nothing to complain about, definitely pretty good for the price and such.  But what I was craving during my recent visit was the Pork Cutlet Curry, I was not disappointed here (yes I understand it's not necessarily their specialty).  I had been extremely hesitant to order this as it was nowhere to be found in pictures on Yelp.  But whatever I was craving it, how bad could it be?  Well Ajisen did one even better by making a better pork cutlet than most Japanese sit-down restaurants.  It came out golden brown, good crisp outside, yet not too dry on the inside as well.  This place has earned my respect for keeping a well-rounded menu, and not just specializing in one item.  It'll definitely be a go to when I drop by Westfield.  

On a side note, why is this place like a sit down restaurant?  It seems easier to just have counter service, the restaurant looks like it should be too anyways.
author: Bryson L.

description:
For a ramen restaurant that is franchised and in a mall, it is pretty good!

I got their Volcano Pork Ramen and it was endearingly spicy - in a delicious way!

They offer Chicken and Beef Ramem as well, but that Spicy Pork Ramen caught my eye and spiced up my palate!

They have appetizers and boba drinks too, but they are known for their ramen!  Hence, the restaurant's name!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Pretty to cool to see a Ramen chain in a mall. This place seems pretty packed during dinner time, which is a good sign on itself. The staff are nice and friendly, there's nothing to nitpick on that at all.

Now as to why I end up giving this a 3/5.

I ordered gyoza and the ABC Ramen, while my friend got the spicy ramen. The gyoza is just mediocre, nothing special at all and I would say not a good order. Now for the ramen order as that's what this place is about right? The ramen noodles itself are nicely done, not overdone and mushy but also not underdone and tough, just right. The broth is not bad, but exactly rich in flavor. Toppings, the ABC comes with chashu, braised pork and premium pork slices. Chashu itself is okay compared to other ramen places, same goes for the braised pork. The premium pork slices however would be my choice of meat from the ones in the ABC and would say is the "best" among them. My friend's ramen came with a boiled egg, but it was a hard boiled compared to a soft boiled egg, not sure if it's meant to be hard boiled egg, but a soft boiled I would think is more fitting for ramen.

Overall for the price it isn't bad at all, decent toppings and a good amount of food. However for a serious ramen craving I wouldn't say this place would be among my primary choices.
author: Joel L.

description:
Amazing ramen
Friend chicken ramen replaced pork broth with veggie option
Simply amazing
author: Chennamaneni V.

description: Surprisingly decent ramen for a mall spot. Tried a little something different with the Beef Curry bowl at $10.75. Noodles were a bit undercooked, and the portion size could be better, lacking on the beef and the condiments. Broth was tasty, flavorful and not greasy. Owner/manager in the dress shirt was nice and attentive. Not amazing as there are great ramen places around the city, but not a bad choice if you have to eat in the mall.
author: Ho-Shing C.

description:
Let me first start off my saying that the young gentleman was nice enough to seat us and serve us a little bit before they fully opened! He was super nice and helped us decide what to get.
we ordered the spicy pork ramen . IT WAS DELICIOUS!!!
My husband and I frequently eat ramen in DT LA at Shin Shen Gumi, which is Hakata style ramen, which we love, but this place was amazing as well!
The broth has fabulous flavor and the ramen came with fermented egg, pork cutlet and ground pork and dried chilis as well. OMG I couldn't get enough of the broth, and I wish I would've taken one to go to eat at the hotel!!! 
I know the location isn't as trendy as other ramen spots but the flavors were great and as a true food lover, that's all that matters!!!!
we will be back in San Francisco next weekend and I will be back to eat more delicious ramen!
author: Naidine V.

description:
Their place is usually packed during the weekend and evenings. The only food place in the mall that has a wait list to be seated.
The staff is always friendly and attentive.

The ramen is flavorful and plenty. I usually get the fried chicken ramen or the pork ramen. You can add shrimp to any ramen for $1 each. I've also tried several of the iced teas and they are way too sweet for y taste. I usually add water but they are flavorful
author: Ayana K.

description:
I really like the flavor and milkiness of the broth and the pork texture of all the ones I have tried so far. The ramen noodles are nothing spectacular and the quantity is okay, but it is enough that I crave this from time to time after a long day at work.  Mmmmmm ramen. Just the right temperature too. 

I come here to eat by myself with no shame. It's that good. It looks like a hybrid between a food court and a sit down restaurant.

Oh yeah random but they always give you the pen with the check up front before they give you a receipt you can actually sign..... which really confused me the first time! ... Anyyyyyyway.
author: Esther S.

description: Not bad for a food court. Love the ramen. I've tried the premium pork, spicy pork, tender pork and the Ajisen best combo. Love it all. So good especially on a cold day. The prices are not bad either. The only downfall is that they're super busy. The wait times could be long. Sometimes the wait isn't too bad. We ordered the ramen to go a couple times and eat at the tables out in the center of the mall. The only difference is that I feel like they give more portion if you eat inside. I noticed they give less for to-go orders. Oh, and the ahi poke is a must get!
author: Amy H.

description:
Pretty good for a ramen chain that's located inside a mall.

I ordered the corn and BBQ pork ramen. The noodles were the best part of the meal. Not your typical ramen noodles, but these were firm yet chewy. The broth was really bland in my opinion. I love their garnishes especially the wood ear fungus; however, I thought it was a bit strange that they put cabbage in the ramen. I recommend getting the cabbage on the side so you can choose how much you want to add into the noodles.

Overall, the prices are very reasonable here. I was pretty surprised that they had such an extensive drink menu with boba! This is a place that I'm glad I tried, but will never come back again.
author: Joy L.

description: I hesitate to eat in a mall, much more at a food court, but this modest and quaint place isn't to be glossed over. If anything, it's a reason to brave the mall crowds. For a mere $9.25, you get a giant bowl of ramen with pork dashi, veggies, and a huge tonkatsu (pork cutlet breaded in panko and fried). You can hear them pounding/tenderizing it in the back so you know it's fresh. If you must get the vegetarian broth, it's mediocre, so if you are open to opting for the pork-based broth, go for this. Just know it's a bit on a spicy side, but the best broth I've had so far in the Bay. Also, don't make a trip there without getting the tempura mochi with ginger dipping sauce. Staff are super friendly, and they try their very hardest to seat you quickly in the small and compact space. So worth the wait, so just suck it up and do it. To sum it up, super cheap yet high quality food with amazing and quick service.
author: Alison A.

description:
98. I had just finished running a half marathon and hadn't eaten anything all day.  So I was more than happy to eat at a food court inside Westfield.  Enter Ajisen.

Make sure you wait before you're seated.  My friends and I didn't know about this until after the fact.  They didn't make a big deal out of it, so it wasn't a problem.  I got the Ajisen best combo (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=lWY2VcLq9QU_zeeBSVJ4XQ&userid=qEdxnnadZ2tcU9JOXjnGdw) which is actually a good deal because it includes three different kinds of pork (if I'm not mistaken).  However, mine was really salty, so I'm not sure if there was MSG in it or just too much flavoring.  When you've ran 13.1 miles though, you really don't care for the world and the idea of eating cardboard sounds totally acceptable.  No joke, the feeling of starvation drives you crazy.

Service was a bit lacking, and it was hard to flag down the waiter for our check.  But if you're at the food court, this is one of the better places to eat at.  And I am not a mall foodie at all.
author: Katherine C.

description:
If you had to eat at the mall.. this one has a decent tonkatsu broth.. and some good appetizers too. 
Or you could go to panda express next door to complete the mall experience..
author: K K.

description: Probably the most inefficient restaurant in history. 30 minutes for ramen. These people seat customers and let food sit. Do not come here unless you like to starve.
author: Jason G.

description: Service is good, employees are nice.. I love the pork cutlet ramen and the beverage is so good... Its my fave place for ramen
author: Maymay I.

description: For the ramen they use spaghetti noodles. Buffalo said. The broth is good though. And if you want a smoothie or Karage this place is good but miss the ramen.
author: Ashton Z.

description: I serve as a chaperone for my school's monthly Glide dinner service field trips. We conclude our trip with a stop at the SF Centre food court. The students love Chipotle(I don't) so that limits the options the rest of us can get to Panda Express and a few other Asian-inspired fast food places.  My colleague thankfully recommended we try Ajisen. I'm grateful we did. Though we ordered to-go so we could sit out in the food court with our students, we were treated to rich broth to go over our noodles and protein(I went with chicken).  Exactly what I wanted on a rainy night.  Will definitely stop by again!
author: Julie C.

description: The terrible service except the men waiter, they even forgot to give us water, after we almost finished we ask for water the waitress has bad service. And food is much worse than other Ajisen Ramen.
author: Liu Z.

description:
1. Service subpar. Actually, there's no service. 

2. Broth subpar, one of the ramen has a shrimp based broth which I feel is made with bouillon or powder. Didn't taste like real shrimp based broth. The pork ramen's broth was also poor... It's a mess.

3. Noodles pale in comparison to some individually operated shops in SF. 

4. The wait totally not worth it.

I really don't recommend spending money or time here.
author: Danny L.

description:
Not too bad for a mall ramen noodle joint. I would definitely eat here again, this place is incredibly busy, the staff works as quick as they possibly can.

I ended up getting the Beef Ramen, which completely hit the spot!  I suggest adding chili paste and Sriracha.
author: Michelle H.

description: Ramen was pretty good, the broth had nice flavors and the appropriate fat content, but the fried chicken and fried calamari was chewy I felt it was fried for too long in the fryer!
author: Sahil S.

description:
Great place for ramen! My go to used to be the spicy pork ramen, which included pork belly and ground pork, but it started to taste pretty fatty. You can see the grease floating at the top. So, I switched it up and started getting the spicy beef ramen. It was a great change! I was worried that the beef would be too chewy, but it ended up being very tender. I finished the whole bowl! 

Service here kinda sucks. You just have to try to catch a waiter's eye or call them over.
author: Gina P.

description:
It's been about 2 years since I had ramen here and boy had it gone downhill. The host was very rude. He couldn't wait 2 secs for our other 2 members to seat us. Most of the people ordered to go anyway! Then when they arrived another patron offered to let our 5th person sit at his table next us but the host didn't allow it. The patron was still eating his food and told the host our friend could sit there. The service is really slow. They are not efficient in turning tables around. There was a good 10 min of empty tables. We opted to order to go instead. No tip for the Asian guy hosting. 

-minus one star for crappy salty ramen 
-minus one star for super sugary milk tea
-minus one star for extra long wait
-minus two stars for poor service all around. 

Unfortunately I couldn't rate this place a zero star.
author: Nina E.

description:
This place has amazing ramen.  Our family went there last night.  We had the pork rib, beef curry, shoyu, and fried chicken ramen.  We all very much enjoyed our meals.  The noodles were especially delicious.  Favorite ramens were the beef curry and pork rib.   A word on the pork rib--it's Asian style, more fat than meat, but the meat is very flavorful and tender.  

We were served quickly. The staff was efficient, and at 6, on a Wednesday night, we just beat having to wait in line.
author: Lois V.

description:
ajisen is located at the lowest level of the westfield shopping center, between chipotle and panda express. it's not the best bowl of ramen in the world, but it will successfully satisfy the lunch soup/noodle/ramen craving (until you have the time or the weekend to head to your favorite noodle spot!). you can also grab a quick chicken teriyaki sample from the Japanese place two doors down to satiate your stomach and prep it for the ramen!

each bowl ranges from ~$9  to $13, and there are at least 10 different types of ramen to choose from! i usually order the premium pork ramen, and to sum it up - solid sized portion, meat (pork!) is always on point, good veggies, noodle texture (thinner, harder noodles) isn't my favorite but it's not bad, soup broth is delicious but puts me to sleep once I get back to the office. i also must note that ajisen provides those awesome ladle soup spoons with your bowl of soup - gotta give it a shoutout, because it's a little accent that just makes the experience more enjoyable!

i would recommend adding a side of spicy pork to your bowl of ramen, but instead of paying a whopping $1.75 for an itty bitty bowl of spicy pork, i would just recommend ordering the spicy pork ramen $9.75 and getting the pork on the side. it's spicy but definitely adds a kick!

tried the boba here once and it was alright - i prefer to walk over to sharetea at the metreon instead.

last note - for the ramen lunch cravers out there, you NEED to get there by 11:45, because by 12:15 there's a long wait list and a crowd of people milling around outside. luckily, the turnover at the restaurant is quick so the wait isn't too painful.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
As far as mall food goes,
Ajisen isn't half bad.

And
as far as where it ranks in my
wonderful world of ramen,
I'd have to consider it what a
base ramen should be.

The broth they serve isn't completely bland.
The ramen is actually pretty decent.
And the chashu is usually edible although the tenderness varies from day to day.

I'm not a fan of their spicy pork ramen.
There's just something about the way they spice it up that just doesn't do it for me.
But then again
it is ramen from a food court
and I should maybe lower my expectations.

Whatever.

Ajisen provides yours truly
with the needed fix when I
get that hankering for ramen.
author: Dan B.

description: Not much to love not much to hate. Came here for lunch on a weekday and there was a decent line of people waiting to get tables. after about a 15 minute wait, we were seated. My friend ordered a seafood ramen, and I got their regular signature ramen. The seafood ramen was rather bland and the soup was very watery with a spicy aftertaste. Their signature ramen soup was flavorful though and decent. Not bad for $10 and a mall food court!
author: Grace P.

description:
Not real Japanese.  But good. 

Very busy place.  The milk bubble tea is good. It is Chinese style Japanese food.  But it's good. I like it.  

The corn salad is good too. 
 
The volcano ramen is really good.  The chasu is good too.  The soup is not greasy.  And very spicy. 

And the service is quick!
author: Emma C.

description: The ramen here is alright. I tried the vegetarian vegetable ramen with shoyu broth + half an egg, fried tofu appetizer and the gyoza appetizer. The fried tofu was great! Nice and crispy and the sauce gave the soft (and pretty bland) tofu and nice flavor. The gyoza was good, though nothing extraordinary. And the ramen was okay. The real disappointment was that the extra egg I asked for was HARD BOILED! Man! Nothing is much worse than meeting your bowl of ramen for the first time and seeing a hard. boiled. egg.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I don't understand why people only give it 3 stars!
Indeed, there's always a long line out there.
I recommend any ramen with pork. If you want taste ramen, pork ramen is a must-have! Beef is so so. Chicken and vegetables is kidding in ramen world. Unless you really want it. I will go spicy pork ramen or volcano pork ramen. The broth is so tasty. Compared to any other ramen house, this one is affordable and delicious.
author: Wakani H.

description:
We had the sole requirement of having to eat at the mall and I wanted more of a sitdown - this was a good option for that in the mall that's not a food court.

We got there just early enough on a weeknight b/c after we sat down a ton of people started to come and there was a little bit of a wait.

I tried the premium pork ramen and hubby had the miso.  The noodles are thinner which to be honest I don't like as much.  The soup was alright, not incredibly flavorful as I'd hoped.  The portion was decent sized.

The miso didn't taste much like miso though so I'd recommend against that.

Overall for the price and the convenience factor it was alright but nothing to write home about.
author: Kay C.

description:
Ajisen is great for a quick bite after work if you work in the city. The broth is packed with flavor, the noodles have the perfect texture, and the fried calamari is delicious! 

I really enjoyed the quick service, perfect portion size, and convenience of the location.
author: Judy L.

description: I ordered a boba drink with my ramen but it didn't arrive until AFTER I asked for my check (which also arrived insanely late). I asked the waitresses 10 times for my drink but they just kept saying it would come. The group of people next to me ordered the same drink as me and they received their drinks before me even though they came after me. The waitress had the audacity to tell me that my drink was sold out and instead asked me if I wanted a substitute. I was beyond frustrated at that point but decided to give them another chance so I said fine. That substitute didn't come until my check came. When I order a boba drink I want it with my ramen, not 40 minutes later. Horrible experience.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
3.5 stars 

Looks like I beat the lunch rush since I only waited 5 mins for a table. I looked at the picture menu, with prices from $7.50 - $9 (around 10.50 for seafood) and didn't take long to decide on the Ajisen ramen with hard boiled egg, bamboo shoots, pork and seaweed.

My ramen came out steaming hot, but the noodles were obviously not REAL ramen noodles (more like Chinese version of egg noodle)  but I love the overly fatty, rich broth! I don't eat ramen often but when I do, I want it to be THIS flavorful. 

The milk tea with boba are lightly sweetened and the pearls are soft and chewy, just the way I like my boba! The extra half star goes to my server who was quick and efficient. Not a bad choice at the food court!
author: Janice C.

description: I wasn't a huge fan of this place, but I don't have much experience with ramen, so I'm not sure if what I got was normal (hence three stars). I ordered the BBQ pork ramen and it certainly was a lot of food, but I only got three small pieces of pork and they didn't seem barbecued at all. My boyfriend ordered their ABC special and he said it was very good, so maybe I just ordered the wrong thing. Also the staff wasn't very attentive. It took a while for them to realize we needed our check and didn't really notice when we tried to flag them down.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Not bad for mall food.

Tastes are the same in comparison to the Irvine, California location.

Noodles are good. They never give enough broth.

The mixtures of flavors make it really good.

Will come back.
author: Jeff H.

description: Even though they were crazy busy the service was still on point and the staff very friendly.  The waitress even got me a refill of my soda for the road. Food was awesome!
author: G W.

description:
I've been coming here for years. Probably the best eatery in Westfield mall, especially in the basement.  Evaluating it against other ramen shops, it's still above average, on par with Katana-Ya but probably not as good as a more legit one out in the Richmond.

Ajisen Ramen: 3.5 stars
Their most basic ramen for $7.95, this was a thoroughly satisfying meal. Noodles are mediocre, too al dente. Broth is wonderful, even though this is the most barebones pork broth it still has a milky, smooth texture. Chashu is deliciously tender and melts into your mouth. Also comes with fungus, cabbage and half a hard-boiled egg, which were nothing to write home about.

Their miso, shoyu, corn ramen, fried chicken entrees etc are also great.

Tender Pork Ribs: 2 stars
The ribs were so dry and awful. Don't get this.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Had the Miso & Teri pork ramen. It was made with white miso on the mild side with slices of cabbage, half a boiled egg. If you're a big eater, not for you. 
Rather have the ramen in Hawaii, comes with fried rice, gyoza and a small dish of tsukemono for the same price.
author: Elsa N.

description: I took a tan tan ramen and it was alright, like a typical mall restaurant based ramen. It is decently spicy and satisfies a hungry person but nothing great.
author: Piyush K.

description: I got the fried chicken ramen and it was pretty good.  I ordered the volcano sauce for an extra $1.50 and made my broth very spicy just the way I like it.  The chicken was a nice texture but the noodles themselves reminded me of spaghetti. Although it is a bit pricy, overall my meal was tasty.
author: Kimberly A.

description:
**This is for their take-out services only**
There aren't too many Ramen spots that I visit in SF, I feel they're better (and more convenient, parking wise) down the peninsula. Aijsen Ramen is one of the few spots that I'll go to in SF. 

I enjoy their Miso Ramen with BBQ Pork. The broth is nice and creamy, the actual noodles are cooked well, and the pork is very very tasty - soft and tender. A bowl of ramen ranges, depending on the type, is between $9-$13. 

For a mall joint, they definitely get a lot of foot traffic and on weekends and nights have a line to be seated. This is the reason why I always get take-out. You walk right in, order at the register and are given a vibrating light-type contraption to let you know when your order is ready. On good days, your order will be ready between 7-10 minutes.

I also enjoy their iced milk tea boba - just the original milk tea. It has a good taste to it, it's not jasmine tea, so it's not flowery tasting, but it does remind me of Honeyberry's boba which I love so much.

If you are a mall employee, let them know at check out, I used to order from them all the time when I was working at Westfield, and they'd give me an employee discount!
author: Kathleene E.

description:
I should have known better than to eat at a ramen place in a food court.

I have an extremely high sodium tolerance - meaning that I like my food heavy in flavor and "too salty" rarely ever comes out of my mouth. I don't know what it is about Ajisen but they were DEFINITELY TOO SALTY. I have never had broth more MSG-laced than this. I was so thirsty afterward that it gave me a headache. The noodles were also more spaghetti-like than ramen noodles. Not a fan.

NEVER AGAIN. And for over $10 per bowl, I'd rather eat instant ramen.
author: Maggi K.

description:
I first went to Ajisen a while back when it first opened in Westfield a couple years back, but didn't get around to writing a review. I've been avoiding it ever since, until recently craving ramen with no other immediate options.  Now I remember why.

From what I remembered, seating was really confusing before...Do I seat myself, or wait to be seated? They have since put up a "Please wait to be seated" sign to eliminate any doubts. 

I had the Ajisen Ramen, add spiciness for $1.  Seriously though, $1 to make my ramen spicy? For real now? I was also given a bottle of sriracha on the side. What. 
The amount of meats was pretty adequate and the noodle to meat ratio was not bad.  Broth was only ok, nothing spectacular. What was most off-putting was the cabbage. Would it kill to put some bean sprouts in there?

Why am I given a ladle to eat my ramen with?! The spoon, which is supposed to be used as a serving utensil, is too large and cumbersome for simply transporting my ramen from bowl to mouth. I'm not trying to shove food down my throat.

Overall, an unremarkable experience.
author: Monica V.

description: Very good restaurant! The karage curry rice was my favorite. We also had the pork rib ramen (I think that's what it's called) was great as well! The pork was so tender! Overall, awesome experience!
author: Tee M.

description:
I always enjoy eating at Ajisen Ramen whenever I'm in the area. I still remember eating here for the first time and thinking "this is the best ramen I've ever had"... and I still honestly feel this way.

Their ramen is great portion size (I feel full but I don't feel as if I ate wayyy too much if I finish the whole thing). The noodles are always cooked perfectly for me. And the broth... is amazing!

I've tried the Ajisen Best Combo ramen, spicy pork ramen, and the spicy beef ramen. So far, my favorite is the spicy beef ramen. The beef is always tender and very tasty.

Customer service, however, is not always great. I usually get the feeling that I'm being rushed, which I guess is understandable because they're normally packed and the place is not that big.
author: Elen Joie B.

description: I thought the ramen was so so. Got dragged here to grab lunch on Black Friday since my younger sister loves the ramen here! The line was long but went by fast. We shared a tiny table for the 3 of us which was meant for 2. They did ask if that was okay and we agreed because I didn't want to wait longer for a bigger table. It had plenty of room for the 3 of us though. Sister ordered the ajisen ramen and I got same thing but with added corn +$1. Boyfriend had the beef Katsu curry which was very tasty! I don't like thin noodles in my ramen and I believe they only serve the thin noodles here. The broth could use some more flavor. It was very light and lacking in flavor IMO. The service was very nice but I don't see myself coming here to fulfill my ramen craving. I need a mean bowl full of flavors with thick noodles! Try it and see if this is your type of ramen! :)
author: Lily M.

description: I would leave a zero star if I could. This place sucks! The customer service was so crappy; I didn't see my waitress the entire time I ate.  The prices are ridiculously expensive, even for San Francisco standards. I got the eel which was on a 4 x 3" plate  for over $10. Definitely appetizer portion. Try to get the beef Ramen, but of course they were out. There's a big sign for buy one get one free drink, be careful because it doesn't  include a slush or smoothie.  Of course you only see that part when you're right in front of the sign because it's in such small lettering.  What an absolute disappointment for my last night in SF!
author: Thuy N.

description:
I've been here plenty of times, always getting their standard Ajisen Ramen bowl for 7.95. I would probably get that if it is your first time here since they include the basic egg, chashu pork, noodles and broth. For around 8.95-10.95, they offer a wide variety of ramen bowls that are spicy, include bbq pork instead of the chashu, one with miso soup, a bowl with three types of meat in it, or a vegetarian ramen. I personally like sticking with the basic ramen bowl because it has everything you need in it for a decent price. Random fact: It seems like they use thin spaghetti noodles. hmm. Overall, their ramen here isn't something I would go out of my way for, but only if I'm shopping downtown and have that Asian food craving. I have to admit though, their broth is yummy.

They also have other dishes like salad, sushi rolls, curry rice dishes, and boba drinks. Never tried any of those because, hence the name, I figured their specialty sticks with the ramen. 

It gets really crowded here on the weekends, because this is probably the closest you can get in a food court that still has a restaurant kinda feel. On some occasions, you may have to snuggle up next to another party if you want to get seated as soon as possible. You can't go wrong with the service here either; waiters and waitresses are super friendly and always on the lookout for refilling your water.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Based on previous mediocre Ajisen experiences, this Westfield Mall location is remarkably good by comparison. Serving up consistent bowls of flavorful, albeit food court chain worthy ramen, it serves the greater noodle soup craving community and is a vastly superior option than its food court neighbors. Granted it is high on the Ajisen scale, it is still behind the best ramen available in the Bay. And as a result, it's deemed 3 star worthy at best.

Like most Asian businesses in San Francisco, it appears to be Chino-run. Subtle attempts at Japanese may get puzzled looks from the staff, but Cantonese seems to be A-OK. They get slammed during lunch time and as a result, a nice line will often build up and the wait for tables is even more gruesome. That said, the place is clean and can surprisingly fit a decent amount of people.

Ramen lovers may find solace in the premium pork ramen, a nearly $10 bowl served with nice cuts of pork and a milky but flavorful broth. Topped with chives and a nice abundance of noodles, it might just be their best ramen dish. I've found the shoyu ramen ($9) to be a tad too salty at times, but still surprisingly decent enough to be a slurp worthy time. And of course, the classic Ajisen ramen ($9) is presented quite well here, best enjoyed with an extra side of corn ($1), a hard boiled egg, and perhaps some extra cuts of charsiu pork ($3).

Not feeling noodles in broth? Shoot for some appetizers and their small but tasty selections of rice dishes. They seem faster out of the kitchen anyway and the perfect solution for folks in a hurry. Agadeshi tofu ($1.50)? Solid. Chicken karagae aka Japanese fried chicken ($6)? A-OK. Premium pork rice platter? A bit pricey at $9 for a clump of rice and a few cuts of pork. Potato croquettes ($4) aren't exactly filling, they're just perfect as an appetizer.

Beware of the gyoza ($6), teriyaki enoki beef rolls ($5) and any of their sushi rolls ($7-14). They're all small and sadly overpriced. Anyone willing to pay these prices might as well go to an actual Japanese establishment and shoot for a tad higher quality. Shoot for Ajisen when feening for some ramen and a quick lunch spot.
author: Jando S.

description:
I've have eaten here a handful of times.  The broth is really good...sometimes hella good.  My only problem is the ramen is inconsistent, there are days when it's al dente, which makes it hella good but when it's over cooked and mushy...then YUCK.  Even the broth cant make up for mushy noodles.  For the most part, it's a slurping good time when I come here.

I always order the same dish, the Ajisen Ramen.  It comes with the delicious pork broth, tender bbq roast pork, soy sauce cooked egg and some veggies.  I try not to add the additional corn but when I do, it's $1.75 more on top of the $8.95 price.  You come out paying approximately $10 for a bowl of ramen.  This place is more yum then not.

TIP:  This place is usually packed during lunch hour, so, I'd recommend coming at 1135AM.
author: Jenny T.

description: Well not as good as hoped but still ok. Standard thin pork slices a bit dry and dont seem as fresh as other places. Noodles and tonkotsu broth fine.
author: Philip L.

description:
Ramen just wasn't that great.
Noodles: okay
Broth: Great
Meats: horrible 
Eggs: inedible overcooked green yolk
Potstickers: pretty good
Hot tea: $3.50 per person
Water: most excellent

Overall not pleased. This was a pretty decent broth but that's about all. Service was good tho. Not worth a second chance.
author: Gio D.

description:
Awesome food.
But unfortunately there is some kind of racism/Preference over here. They help asian customers first, even if you got there first.
author: Alex E.

description:
We were pleased with our meal at Ajisen ramen - it certainly was a nice mall food court find!

I enjoyed the Ajisen ramen (chasu pork, boiled egg, and veggies) - the noodles were good and the broth was delicious.  My fiancé enjoyed his premium pork ramen.

The service was friendly and fast, and it was nice to have a quick, sit down meal.
author: Barnali D.

description:
I'm giving them 4 stars based on service & my salad. I was with a group of 6. According to them the 2 ramen bowls they ordered plus 1 sushi roll were very good.

All their ramen bowls come in one size. To me they look like pretty average size portions. Definitely not the big huge bowls you would probably expect at a Pho restaurant.

To start, you have to write your name down on the clipboard hanging on their sign out front. We were here on a Friday around 1:30. They were pretty busy, but this place is inside the Westfield Shopping Center and it's just busy here all the time! So our wait time was about 10-15 min. 3 tables were pushed together to accommodate the 6 of us. The server immediately brought us waters & gave us a chance to look at the menus.

I didn't have any ramen, but I did try their Tofu Salad. According to the picture there was corn in their salad, so I requested my salad without corn. The portion size was very generous. Probably enough for two. They use silk tofu on the salad and give you 2 portions cut from the tofu block. I think this is about 6-8oz. of tofu. A really good serving. The salad was good! The dressing was light, flavorful & the salad wasn't drenched in it so the greens were nice & crunchy! At the end $7.50 was very reasonable for this salad & the amount you get, plus the nice flavor of their dressing.

Tofu Salad: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ajisen-ramen-san-francisco#RjwBk4TkfNZMiZbp0GvkUg
author: Joel R.

description:
3.5 stars. 

I came here with super low expectations. 1) It's located at a food court, 2) the noodles don't look authentic 3) the volcano was described as not spicy. I came anyway because I was on my way to another ramen spot but the rain made me change directions. 

I came here around 11:45 for lunch, there were some empty tables. Right after I was seated though, there was a crowded on the waitlist to be seated.
