I ordered the volcano despite the reviews. It's the only thing on the menu with 3 red peppers next to it... it SHOULD be spicy right? 

Took awhile to get my food. I ordered the volcano and "fried chicken". "Fried chicken" made me laugh, what ramen place calls their chicken "fried chicken"? Thinking about it, I guess it makes sense, it's in a food court and not every who rolls through knows what chicken karaage is.

My ramen came with a ladle, which made me giggle. I don't think I've ever seen a place serving ramen with ladles. It's peculiar... no? You know what, the volcano was spicy. I was surprised. For someone who eats pretty spicy foods, this tasted spicy. It's not a crazy spice but it's not bland. The pork slices were pretty good, not too fatty either. The egg... sigh. It's a seasoned hard boiled egg, but it looked like a miniature egg size, either someone chomped on my egg or it just was mildly deformed. I do love soft boiled eggs in my ramen... 

Oh, and the noodles. Like all the other descriptions of spaghetti noodles. Totally on point. It was a little weird, but I've gone to other ramen places that use that kind of noodle too. Odd but not a deal breaker. It's a food court! What do you really expect? 

The "fried chicken" was pretty good. For the $5, it was a good portion for the price. 

Overall, I'd come back if I'm in a pinch and want some ramen (while at work). There are a ton of better places for ramen if you're not confined to the downtown/fidi district for lunch.
author: Jeannie L.

description: Loved the spicy pork ramen! There wasn't a long wait for lunch and the prices aren't bad. The service was pretty good. It definitely satisfied my craving for ramen
author: Adelisa L.

description:
Tried it for the first time tonight and was pleasantly surprised! Of course it's not incredible ramen (it is in a mall after all), but it's good and will satisfy any craving you may have.

Ajisen Ramen: Chasu Pork, Boiled Egg, and Veggies. The broth was flavorful and the noodles were tasty.

Milk Green Tea with Boba: Sweet and delicious!

Service: The waitress was patient in explaining the different types of ramen and helped recommend one. She also recommended the boba over the slushies and juices, which ended up being a great choice. 

Ajisen Ramen isn't gourmet by any means, but is delicious and convenient!
author: Yanni L.

description:
I came here in a rush before a meeting. I ordered a fried chicken ramen, which was plain ramen with shredded cabbage and a side of chicken karaage... About $9.95. The broth was a bit watery, not thick like usual ramen places. Noodles were also a bit weird, it was not the curly kind of ramen noodles... It was more straight. Think of soba noodles that aren't buckwheat. 

However, service was good. Left me alone, yet was readily available when I needed anything, plus checked on me once while I was eating. Because of that I would come back if I ever wanted mall noodles.
author: Elaine S.

description: Not bad, but true it's not the best in class. The ABC is solid. Broth very good.
author: Bib G.

description:
We hadn't eaten here in a while since we haven't gone to the mall or caught a movie fr quite some time.

I got he Cold ramen which was basically regular ramen in a bowl of cold, dilute, garlicky soy broth. The concept is interesting but I won't be getting this gain. Oh yeah, there was a hair in my bowl too! The Boyfriend got the ABC ramen which has 3 different types of pork all together. It's a great value & our waitress told us it's the most popular item on the menu.

The menu has expanded quite a bit since we were here last. The service was efficient & quick - maybe a little too quick - but slightly less friendly than usual.

I can't say with 100% certainty it was because of this meal but the 2 of us both got sick later that evening...and this was the only meal that we had together and the only time we ate the same (or similar) foods.
author: Karen S.

description: The ramen itself isn't ramen noodles - they're just plain long thin noodles, but the flavors are decent. I got the spicy pork ramen and my friend got spicy beef ramen. The meat is surprisingly yummy, but I do believe that the serving sizes are small for the price you have to pay.
author: Ally M.

description:
Stumbled upon this place unexpectedly, not knowing there was a ramen place that existed in the food court at the SF Westfield. I was def craving ramen so I had to try this place. It was pretty busy when I got there. Got seated promptly. If you want to order to-go, simply go up to the front cash register and they have a huge menu on the wall that you can order from. If you're dining in, you wait to be seated. 

I was debating between the tan tan and the spicy beef ramen. Ended up going with the spicy beef ramen because the waitress said the tan tan was a bit on the heavy peanuty side. Ramen bowls were about $8.  The ramen came out fairly quickly! However our drinks took forever... We see it ready on the counter and it took forever for a waitress to bring it over to our table. Finally it came, after my ramen came out. 

The broth was def very flavorful, a bit on the salty end though. I was so hungry that I didn't care and devoured everything. The beef was tender and they gave you plenty at least 7-8 pieces. The noodles though I noticed were different from regular ramen noodles I tried elsewhere. They almost reminded me of thin spaghetti. I didn't really like that texture of the noodles. 

Try the honey aloe green tea! It had chunks of aloe Vera in there. Extremely refreshing!!! Conveniently comes in the to-go cup as well. 

Will I be back? Probably... If I'm ever craving ramen again while shopping in the city! :) next time Id like to try the volcano ramen.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Pricey, subpar ramen. 

I got the VOLCANO RAMEN because I love spicy food, but it wasn't very spicy despite the 3 chilis next to it on the menu. My favorite part of any bowl of ramen is the meat. All the ramen places I've been to have had really tender pork in their ramen, so I was pretty disappointed with the pork here. Not tender at all. The noodles also didn't look like normal ramen noodles. They were thinner and chewier, like spaghetti. Their veggies consisted of some cabbage and there was half of an old-looking egg. There also must be a ridiculous amount of salt/MSG in the ramen because I woke up the next day parched and dehydrated for most of the day.

The only good thing was that it was a pretty generous portion size, especially with 3 slices of pork whereas I usually get 2 slices at other places. But for $10, you can easily get a bowl of much better ramen elsewhere.
author: Jessie L.

description: I came to this place on Wednesday and had the craving for ramen and warm soup. That day was the day because the weather was cold and so I had a tan tan men. It was delicious and had hint of peanut butter. Will come again.
author: Larry F.

description:
came for lunch with a friend. usually not a fan for franchises but, is this really a franchise? and besides, i'm here to see a friend first so, i think anytime or, anywhere eating with her already boosts the ambience. there was no line so i sat right in. i had to shoo away the waitress a couple of times but, after awhile i just started ordering water as i wait. 

order
---
premium pork ramen with extra corn
-it was good. the broth wasn't too salty and, really tasty. a fan of their type of broth. 
chicken karaage
-your average run-of-the-mill chicken to go along with your meal. wasn't bad but, it wasn't memorable.

kinda just wished i ordered the boba to take care of my other cravings as well. definitely a good spot to cover those ramen cravings ..
author: Phillip R.

description:
They have quite an extensive menu with sushi rolls, ramen, soba, boba drinks and more. Food is standard and consistent.

I normally get the tan tan mien or spicy pork ramen. I've never been disappointed. I will say there seems to be a difference in portions when you dine in vs taking out (less food). I don't mind this as I normally can't finish my food anyhow.

It normally is busy. Be prepared to wait even at odd hours. The wait isn't usually longer than 15 minutes.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
The restaurant was packed with all these holiday shoppers but the servers were fast and efficient to handle the large crowds. Tables are packed in tight.  

Had their signature handmade pork ramen for lunch. Kinda bad, but not a late night skidmarks kinda bad. 

It came with these dry shreds of overcooked pork that were similar to dried out Greek gyro meat. Add the noodles, green onion, and watered down pork broth and it was a basic bare minimum bowl. Kinda pricey for $10 but exactly what you'd expect out of a fast food chain. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=ZjMjS2y2VWhsP6HfFOJdsw)

It just made me want a legit bowl of ramen somewhere else. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=2jq0PkEANi3ElCBLt92mHw)
author: Earl G.

description: I had the Tan Tan Ramen, it was pretty spicy even though it's one pepper(or maybe I just cannot eat spicy in general). I think the Ajisen here is very organized. I have been to the one in San Diego, and this one in San Francisco seems a lot better. There were only two people working and it was super packed and pretty small but everything seems to be under control. Teamwork is great here! Thank you!
author: Keung P.

description: I got the curry ramen. I asked for chicken instead of beef. The broth wasn't bad. I think if you're hungry, this isn't a bad place to eat, but I've had much better ramen elsewhere. It didn't taste all that authentic. It tasted kinda greasy. It wasn't as smooth-tasting as other ramen I've had where all of the different flavors (chicken, broth, noodles, vegetables, egg, etc.) blended nicely together. But again, this isn't a bad place to eat if you're in the area, hungry, and craving ramen.
author: Dee F.

description: Oh ajisen, first time I came here upon a Taiwanese coworkers recommendation and now it's become my favorite ramen shop in the city. A no-frills place in the food court, tasty broth at the appropriate rich level, the basic ajisen ramen comes with veggies, pork, and half a braised egg. I often get a side dish as well, like the potato croquette or grilled scallops. Inexpensive being in a nice mall. Haven't tried their boba, but my friend loved it. Might be quite some wait for a big party, but shouldn't be too long for a group under 4.
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
I had never seen this Ramen place at the food court before, and the smell from all the food tempted me in. Although the place doesn't look super nice, given it's in a shopping mall food court, the food was amazing! I got the Spicy pork ramen and the service was super fast which is always good. The pork itself was okay, but the spiciness was on point, the noodles were terrific, and the broth nice and rich.

Definitely left super satisfied with my meal, especially on a rainy day. And given the price, even better!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
So, this was actually better than I thought it would be, being a chain restaurant!

Get the PREMIUM PORK! Man, this was pretty delicious! [http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/bH7-1wxhGZUT7ddt3_GjvA/l.jpg] 

Bf was also surprised to see that I really liked it since it was just average to him. He said Ajisen is like the "McDonalds of Asia" but I don't know, I'm a ramen lover (Look at my other 15 ramen joints just in Nor Cal alone) and this was 4 stars in my book. Pork was delicious, soup was tasty, noodles were not too hard or too soft. Only thing is that it's a bit overpriced, around $12 for a bowl of ramen when most bowls should be around $9-10. But it's in a mall in Downtown SF so it's not surprising it's overpriced. At least it's good.

We also got the fried octopus which was not bad either, but again, overpriced. $6 for a few small pieces. 

- Location is convenient, next to BART off Powell and in the heart of Downtown SF at the Westfield Mall. 

- Service was fast.

- Ambiance was food court style haha

Overall - Yummy for a quick bite to eat to satisfy your ramen cravings in Downtown SF :)
author: Raquel Y.

description:
I'm terrible spoiled. Ajisen is totally fine, but just doesn't go beyond very good fast food ramen, because that is what it is. 

I will go there again, and again, and again. Never dissapointed, never particularly impressed. 

Service is very good, the wait can be annoying depending on the time of day, but then it is in the middle of the mall.
author: Greg F.

description: This is my go to for quick all in one Ramen.  It's not super great but it's good enough for me to return.  Meaning, you get more bang for your buck here.  It's an all around all inclusive kind of a place where you don't have to order all the individual items separate and have to pay separately.  You can order a combo for over 14 bucks which is really good for Ramen.
author: Kathy C.

description: This is my favorite place to eat, and I am there two to three times a week. On the weekends, my husband is there with me. They have a large selection of ramen and drinks. I've tried all of the ramen and they are all so good that I couldn't say which is my favorite. They have several broths and each one is flavorful and rich. The beef, pork or fried chicken curry rice is also excellent. Of course, you must have a boba milk tea to go along with the ramen. The staff is amazingly efficient and friendly--always! Even when there is a long line, the wait is not very long and the servers are constantly rearranging the tables to accommodate anywhere from one person to a crowd.
author: Terry N.

description:
Booty call ramen!!  It's not bad but it's not spectacular!  It's where you go to when you just want some ramen & you're around but don't want to wait at Suzu or Katana-Ya (thus booty call status)!  It is however, a good alternative to your food court food, fair priced & quick.  We wanted something quick & narrowed it down between the Italian place & Ajisen, & decided that Ajisen may be a better bet, plus I knew what to expect as I've been to the one in Fremont. 

 I got the Ajisen Ramen which was a Tonkatsu broth & my bf got the Shoyu Ramen.  Both gave big portions & came with super tender pork.  My broth however was a lot more flavorful, thus making him a little jealous; usually it's the other way around!  =)  

Sadly they do not offer their chicken karaage at this location.  Not that it matter for us, but the waiter told us they were only serving ramen that day as well.  Three stars for helping with ramen cravings!
author: Cat C.

description:
First time going here:

Around dinner time - There was a long line and a sign-up sheet. Wait time was 10-15min.

Food - My friend and I ordered the croquettes, ajisen ramen, and shoyu ramen.

Croquettes (fried mashed potato with veggie pieces inside): 
not greasy. Crispy. Would order again.

Ajisen Ramen:
My friend prefers the "hokkaido-".."special-"..ramen...... the most expensive ramen bowl. However, she would order the Ajisen ramen again.

Shoyu Ramen:
I wish there were more toppings, meat, naruto (fish meat with pink swirl, NOT the annoying spiky anime kid.. Believe it!). The pork was very tender and fatty (because it was PREMIUM PORK, not regular pork. Premium pork is very marbled/fatty/yummy.) I was left wanting more, but I think it was a yummy, cohesive dish. I would order it if I was craving something more than a snack but not when I'm starving.
author: Judge F.

description:
We ordered cold noodle and tofu salad, after 30 mins wait the waiter told us they can't make them because their equipment is broken... 
This is not acceptable.
author: Godziller W.

description:
More like a 3.5 stars but I'm giving it three. On a cold Sunday afternoon, I was craving ramen. It's my boyfriend's favorite ramen place in the city so he convinced me to try Ajisen instead of going to Ramen Yamadaya. We ordered the ABC Ramen. The broth is probably my favorite broth I've tried so far, it's garlicky and thick. The noodles, ehh they're okay. My favorite meats were the premium pork and the tender pork ribs. 

I added corn and volcano sauce. $1.75 extra for corn. I mean forreal, it's canned corn that should really cost 50 cents. Just my two cents. But I get it. Rent in SF is expensive so charging ridiculous price for corn is acceptable. Also, the ramen doesn't come with egg. But what is ramen without soft boiled egg? Also, no extra garlic available to add to your ramen.
author: Kayla O.

description: had their volcano ramen with added corn, cabbage and seaweed over the weekend and it was aiittteeeee. corn was $1.75 extra (more expensive than most places) but the other veggies were free so i didnt mind as much.  ramen was pretty chewy, but the broth, although spicy, lacked depth of flavor. i also ordered the fried chicken and that was super disappointing - it was just nothing like the karaage you would expect from other japanese places - overfried and not seasoned well. i probably wouldnt come back given bangkok thai is yummier and cheaper and only a block away.
author: Christina L.

description: Surprisingly good for a mall restaurant! I liked the Mille-feuille katsu and the salad that comes with it. Ramen is average.
author: Ryan L.

description: Got the 3 meat ramen. They do thin straight noodles here. Broth while oily and cloudy white was not as porky as I would like. This place is a'iight, but there are certainly better options around town.
author: Linus W.

description: Food is good. Price is ok but the noodles have way too much MSG. It is way to salty but the food is still good, Portions are huge and the selections are fantastic.
author: Clayton L.

description:
I went into the foodcourt hoping to find noodle soup. I wasn't impressed with the offerings so I headed towards the BART entrance part of the mall to head home and was pleasantly surprised to see this place (in the Nordstrom part of the mall). I'm a fan of ramen but not an aficionado so my standards aren't super high but I still know good ramen when I taste it.
I was promptly seated, the place was full (good sign) and presented with a menu. I really liked the menu; lots of ramen options and clearly this is a place of Japanese descent as most of the menu is written in Japanese. I've since read from other reviews it's a chain in Japan. Good to know. 
I ordered the spicy pork ramen. At only one chili rating on the menu I am really glad I didn't order the volcano broth that had 3 chilies because there is no way I would have been able to handle that heat. The regular spicy was quite spicy but not overly so. 
I thought the broth was very good. Slightly creamy, it had a good texture and flavor profile. The noodles were a little boring but it seems that's what ramen noodles usually are, no? 
Non regular noodle slurpers, beware; slurping noodles from a large spoon can be tricky. To say nothing of getting soup on your shirt, you can swallow incorrectly and nearly choke. Since the broth and the noodles can be a little hard for the back of your mouth to negotiate as you are shoveling a large spoonful in your mouth, a little broth and in my case small bit of meat can go straight down the wrong pipe. The result for me with the spicy pork going down the wrong way was a very unpleasant coughing fit that lasted a good 10 minutes, had fellow slurpers give me some WTF looks (although amusingly the 2 young Asian girls next to me chatting endlessly about things teen girls do couldn't seem to care less that I was nearly choking to death) and had me streaming in tears. No bueno. 
I'll be more careful next time but would definitely return to try some other bowls.
author: Matt H.

description:
Shopping right before Christmas, we ended up eating dinner at Ajisen Ramen inside San Francisco Centre. Its not the best ramen in SF, but not bad if you want a quick dinner.

Grilled Hokkaido Scallop Ramen - broth was a little bland to me, noodle was more like straight spehetti noodle. I wish it was a little more curlier like other ramen noodles. The grilled scallop had a great smokey flavor, wish there is more than 2 pieces :P

ABC Ajisen Best Combo Ramen - combination meat ramen. Broth was more flavorful than the Scallop ramen, not a fan of their ramen noodle. The pork was tender and flavorful.

For a quick ramen fix, Ajisen will do its job. But for a truly savor ramen, you will need to explore beyond.
author: Sandi C.

description:
Dining area was packed on a Tuesday evening. Got the Ajisen Ramen to go, which comes with 3 slices of pork, half a hard boiled egg, scallions, and seaweed. Pork was deliciously fatty, but the broth was much too oily for my taste. Didn't see a soft boiled egg option, but that would've been nice. 

Nice that the total came in under $10, but the portion was on the smaller side. Overall, average ramen in a convenient location - really good for a mall!  The search for the best ramen in SF continues.
author: Cheryl L.

description:
Came here last week cause my friends and I were craving some ramen. Ramen Underground was our first choice, but we didn't want to wait for an hour plus for seats there so we just came to Ajisen. As expected, we were seated right away.

I ordered the Ajisen ramen and it's pretty good for a $8 bowl of ramen. The broth was not sodium hell, which is characteristic of most ramen and the slices of pork belly were very tasty. One criticism I have is that my noodles were a little tough, but not to the point that they were unpleasant to eat. I'd come back again to satisfy my ramen craving.
author: Austin W.

description: Omg. Probably one of the best ramen placed I've been to. It's worth it. Price isn't bad. Quite affordable actually. Service is great and same with the quality of the food. The broth i got was miso. I like how it wasn't so overpowering. Overall good place to go to
author: Marie V.

description: Surprisingly pretty good ramen for a mall ramen! I had the volcano ramen. It's supposed to be their spiciest ramen and it's just right for me...but then I have high tolerance. It was too spicy for my friend although she eats pretty spicy food as well. Broth was just salty and creamy enough. Fortunately the noodles are not spaghetti noodle like some reviews said. But it's on the skinnier side and doesn't look to be fresh noodle.  Egg is hard boiled so I could do without it. Veggies were mostly cabbage. Spinach or something greener would be more pleasing to the eyes and tastebuds.
author: Jessica N.

description:
HOKAY so I ate here twice. I am not a ramen expert and I used to think that ramen should taste like instant noodles and like, what's the difference between the two anyways??? OH godddd... there is definitely a difference!

I came here the first time after being really tired and hungry after shopping. I ordered the premium pork ramen because it was the highest priced item on the menu and I felt like treating maself....AND good thing I did because that bowl of ramen was so amazing!!! The broth was flavorful but not too salty (like the feeling you get after eating pho, ya know what I mean). There was obvi pork and the noods were extra bouncy in my mouth. 

Order the premium pork bowl because you most likely won't go to a mall to get ramen again and there are other places to get ramen in SF ( according to Yelp LOL) so don't limit yourself to this. They also got small dishes like fried chicken and spicy tuna. But in general, this place ain't so bad.
author: Eileen W.

description:
We all agree that a bowl of Ramen Noodle tastes best during the Winter-holidays. Strangely, I just suddenly have the craving in the month of May. Thus most of my craving of the soup is eaten in the spring and summer time. 

But this busy ramen place inside the hectic Westfield Shopping Center makes me feel like I'm in a serene atmosphere. 

I do like the cute logo of the restaurant. There are also a ton of cute girls eating one of restaurant's many popular ramen noodles. So Joe Cool (me) went along and ordered the Curry Beef Stew Noodle soup. For $9.50, I get few pieces of the tender beef stew, shredded green cabbage, thick noodles in a thick and creamy curry soup. 

Many of my followers know that I'm a rookie in Ramen noodles. And it definitely shows when I slurped the bowl of ramen in my face like the real Joe Cool (Snoopy). Cute girls looked at me like I was born in a farm or something. But then I find this ramen soup very comforting and satisfying. 

Again I may not be an expert in Ramen Noodles, but this place has been good to me so far. The price is decent (used my Visa for my meal). The hustling Cantonese workers are friendly. Thus I might come here again
author: Matt G.

description:
With food court standard, this is a GREAT PLACE! A lot better than Panda Express, but in real food standard, this is ok. 
Do yourself a favor and get out of the mall for some real food!
author: Jenny C.

description:
You have to be seated; kind of weird because it's in the middle of a food court, where people sit wherever.  But that's okay.  You sign up at a board for a "waiting list" even though there are tables everywhere.  

The food is really good!  Not any options for children, which was bad for my baby niece, but we got her some chicken strips and a bowl of rice.  The boba drinks are pretty good too.

I think they reuse their chopsticks.  They're plastic and black, and one was a little wet, even though it was in the packaging.  But that's okay.  As long as they're clean, right?

A little stiff on giving water refills, and checking up on us.  But the food topped it off.
author: Ivy N.

description:
Dear Food God,

Why have I not found this place before?  (*mind explodes*)   Convenient location, strong execution, and about a billion different options.  Touchdown.  I look forward to exploration.

Best,
-Darin

(3.5 stars)
author: Darin E.

description: This place only competes with the chipotle right next door. The volcano ramen is spicy but definitely worth the pain.
author: Jeff F.

description:
No vegetarian ramen here. No substitutions allowed. Their vegetable ramen has fish and chicken powder in it. Even their miso has a meat base to it. 
You can't eat here. 
The ramen looks good and presents well.  
They're always busy. 
You would recommend it for meat eating friends.
author: Victoria D.

description:
Did a takeout order here for the first time today, and I'm now considering whether or not doing that is perhaps a better way to go over being served in the restaurant...

Walked right in and up to the counter, made my order (my go-to, the spicy beef ramen and a can of chilled green tea), and in no more than five minutes my ramen was ready for me to take. It also felt like it was even hotter (temperature, not spiciness) than when I order in the restaurant but, oddly, they serve your noodles and beef in a separate bowl than your broth and you have to combine the two. 

The downside is that the serving is smaller (or at least seems that way) than an in-house order, even with having ordered extra noodles. If it's really swamped in there and you want your ramen quickly, ordering takeout seems to be the thing to do; if you want your money's worth (because the amount I got didn't seem worthy of the $15 price tag), just be patient and wait for a table.
author: Angela M.

description: This place is convenient because it is located on the first floor of the mall. I ordered a volcano ramen and it was spicy! Just like I liked it! The service was really quick. I gave this place a 4 star instead of 5 is because it's not the best ramen I've ever had but it certainly is a great place to eat after hours of shopping!
author: Helen H.

description:
I actually enjoyed this ramen more than some of the ramen spots I've had in the Silicon Valley area. I first tried this place when I was studying abroad in Shanghai a few years back, so it took me forever to finally try Ajisen back here in the states. Although I remember it tasting better in Shanghai, this place does an above decent job for a restaurant chain in the mall. 

Located at the basement of the SF Westfield Mall in downtown SF, it's in a good location for all the Bay Area tourists that Barts into Powell. It's in a clean, rich mall, right off the Powell Bart station. 

I ordered the spicy pork ramen which turned out pretty darn tasty. It hit the spot the morning after NYE in the city. The noodles weren't that spicy, it had that spicy flavor and the meat portions were generous, which is something that I don't normally get from the overrated ramen spots in the Silicon Valley. The noodles itself were good, not too soft nor hard. The soup base tasted pretty generic, tasty and flavorful, but it wasn't outstandingly great.  

My friend had the volcano spicy ramen (the spiciest one) and he is the type that can tolerate ghost peppers. He said it was good spicy, so I'm assuming that it would actually burn for the medium spice eaters. 

One downside are the drinks. I ordered the strawberry iced tea which tasted more like water and flavored strawberry syrup. Too sweet and had no tea flavor at all. 

About $9 or so for a bowl of ramen, not bad for the over priced food court located at the Westfield Mall. Our noodles came out in less than 5 minutes!
author: Rita K.

description: Dirty.  I was sitting in front of the kitchen.. and i saw the last guy that prepared the food.. he was the salad/lettuce guy.  He dropped the lettuce on the counter and he picked it up and put it back into the bowl.  Eww...
author: jenny t.

description:
Typical fast food mall type food.  The Ramen was good and extremely tasty.  I ordered the combo and the picture showed loads of meat.  Well lets just say I got fooled by the picture.  Very little meat if any at all!

I liked how we did not have to order at the counter, but instead we were seated and they took my order.  I am sure there are a gazillion places in SF with better Ramen, but I can guarantee there are not any better in the Mall!
author: David G.

description: The service was really fast and everyone was really polite but the ramen itself was a let down. I ordered the shoyu ramen and the broth tasted watery and noodles were still hard. Overall the dish was just bland. The only reason I gave it two stars was because the fried chicken and the Thai iced tea were actually pretty decent.
author: Alex C.

description:
When you call yourself a ramen place, generally you want to make sure your general layout isn't visually misleading. When you see this place for the first time, it looks generic by name and Chinese run by the layout of food and drinks here....

The whole drinks menu o swear makes you wonder if you didn't take the 38L to Clement instead of Powell by mistake. If anyone has a friend that can take a picture of the drinks and desserts side, unless you already been here, you have a fair chance of guessing that you're eating at Creations or 100% than anything ramen...

Because of my skeptical impression of this place, the name itself also carries no weight for me no more in a food way. I plucked the Miso Ramen from the bunch and the standards I held it to were not exactly high...

How should I put this....I'm comparing you to Momiji in Daly City...doesn't get any easier  than that....

The Miso Ramen came out with more of a milky miso than anything I've seen in sometime of being in San Francisco..milky would ultimately be an understatement..

It tasted very watery.. as if they plucked out of one of those bags from 99 Ranch and boiled it so far THEN put it into miso...the flavor is very blandishly lacking life to it.and it costs close to 10 bucks for it....not including tax and tip from add ons 


NO Spicy Miso here.
NO Kotteri...
NO Shio..

Ramen mixtures of pork and beef..like Chinese instant noodle style...

Only Ajjisen....or in American terms..Ahh-Sh*t....

I think Miso soup alone from Fuji in west portal has all more value than the miso broth here....

Instead of here...Go to---
Yamadaya in J-Town
Tanpopo in J-Town
Santa Ramen- Somewhere near San Mateo.


If it weren't for the nice waitress, the star on this review would otherwise not be here...

..Emergency bathroom run now..abort! abort! abort!...
author: Eric C.

description:
I finally got to try Ajisen Ramen and I have to say it was pretty good for mall restaurant.  I've been wanting to try Ajisen ever since I saw a pic of their Premium Pork Ramen ($9.75).  Who wouldn't want a bowl of Ramen topped with layers and layers Grilled Pork?

When they bought it to my table it was awesome!  Just look at all that Pork (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw&select=QRiwEcGAe0cxRWT0QaSYYg).  Now I don't really have a discriminating taste for Ramen so I actually liked everything from the Noodles and Broth to the huge amount of Pork.  

And if you've read my past reviews from other Ramen houses, I always get a side of Chicken Karaage with my Ramen.  The Chicken Karaage (Fried Chicken on the menu) at Ajisen was really good too.  If you've had the Nanban Chicken at Kitchen Kura, it's almost similar to that (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw&select=5bGrnXQtH07xYInX7S0NQA).  I prefer my Karaage with fried batter, so theirs was a very nice addition to go with my Ramen.

One thing that did bug me was that they didn't have any hot brewed green tea to serve.  I had to get one of their Sweet Hot Drinks.  Oh well, I guess I can't have everything.  I give this place 4 Stars and I shall return again to try their Tender Pork Rib Ramen.
author: Rodney H.

description: We were hungry and wanted something warm. Place itself is not very clean. Food is average and typical food court mall.
author: Alain T.

description:
The dearth of good ramen houses in the FiDi is a sad situation. Not Afghanistan-level sad, but probably Jersey Shore-level sad. My dreams of a fantastic noodle shop stateside were actually fulfilled...but in New York with the Pork Belly Ramen at David Chang's Momofuku. But San Francisco?...where are you? You can imagine how my hopes were instantaneously dashed when Jamie W. made me aware of a new operation in the ghetto side of the Westfield Shopping Centre.

It's a chain. Oh yes, there was the unmistakable air of assembly line production about the place the moment you see it. And of course, it was abuzz with customers downing ramen and other predictable dishes, mostly clutches of young, squawky Asians looking for something quick and an excuse to sit down and text. Nothing looked terribly exciting to me, so I went with the $7.50 bowl of Chicken Ramen (see photo). The noodles were decently al dente, but the uniformly separated chicken pieces tasted packaged in the worst way.

Jamie had marginally better luck with the same-priced Beef Miso Ramen probably because the meat at least tasted like it was marinated in soy to give it flavor (see photo). I probably should have gone with the pork but the photos make it look like they process the pork into a roll and slice it like Pillsbury cookie dough. I may end up going there again for the convenience, but it would be nice to see a little more effort in the execution. Focus of this operation appears to be on turning over the tables with speed and efficiency. That they do very well.

FOOD - 2.5 stars...generic ramen, could be worse
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...definitely not the orchestra section of the Westfield
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...service was speedy and efficient
TOTAL - 3 stars...squeezing it over to three because there is a lot on the menu to try if you want to
author: Ed U.

description: I was glad we were able to drop in and didn't have to wait more time in weekend. Also this place is on the list of the best ramen places in Bay Area. No complains about service either :))
author: Amelia D.

description: Noodles are like the packaged instant kind. Broth is okay but I sense a lot of MSG. Service was nice for fast food style  If you're at the mall it will do in a pinch.
author: Nancy T.

description:
Above average ramen to me. My favorite is the Spicy Pork Ramen. It has a nice balance of saltiness and spiciness. The three slices of pork and half an egg may be skimpy if you have a healthy appetite. At the extremes are the Premium Pork Ramen or the Volcano Ramen (spicy).

The Ajisen Ramen was okay, somewhat bland but I think it's supposed to be that way (no msg?). The pieces of pork and egg were not bad, but adding chili flakes did not improve the soup flavor. They also have sriracha if you prefer.

Like the other eateries in the Westfield-Nordstrom side food court, they start turning people away at 8:30pm and was a bit pushy to get customers out. Didn't happen to me but did to a few groups. You also have to sign-in a waitlist to be seated.
author: Peter L.

description:
I came here for their boba slush and was extremely disappointed! I couldn't think of any other place that had boba in the area - so, to the mall I went -_-

They had a line for ramen lol OKAY, I see them. Mall ramen tho? Get cho life. 

My Peggy and I ordered a mango slush and a green apple slush....been day dreaming about that fluffy artificially flavored ice and tapioca balls ALL DAY! 

Picked up our drinks and I'm -_____________- 
....soooo what brainless person put HOT tapioca balls in my SLUSH? Fuck. Ruining my dreams, ya bish!!!! 
The bottom half of my drink was watery and the top half was ice..
Tapioca was kinda mushy....

FML moment. Thanks for breaking my heart, assholes.
author: Lydia L.

description:
Luckily we got there before a line started to form on a Saturday during lunch were sat right away.  The service was quick and friendly.

My husband had the chicken ramen, which he though was just OK.  I thought it was a little bland.  My daughter had the pot stickers and some lychee slush drink.  I wasn't really impressed with the drink.  She and I shared the Pork Short Rib ramen.  The broth was tasty and the pork short rib is not something I'm used to seeing on ramen menus.  The noodles, although they were thinner than I usually like, was cooked well.  I had to add 1/2 and egg for $0.50 but I kind of liked that the ramen was pretty simple (just cabbage, seaweed, and green onions).

I've had better ramen but I wouldn't mind coming back here if I were in the area...
author: Rose A.

description:
Pros: very good ramen, friendly staff and fast service

Cons: long wait, ineffective seating

Came here yesterday, Friday 5/29/15 for lunch around 12:30 pm. It was very busy. There was a sign in list. We waited at least 30 minutes. It's awkward because the menu is displayed as if you could walk right up and place an order but there was a crowd waiting in the front. They should re-configure the seating -- maybe add one long table on one side, facing the wall so that people who come here solo can all sit next to each other, like at a bar. There were solo diners being seated at tables that usually seat two - four people. It made me sad. Other than the people standing in the front watching you eat, with faces like "hurry the hell up" the dining experience was pretty nice. Casual. The ramen was SO good. I had the Volcano Ramen. It had three chili signs next to it which was kind of intimidating. But it wasn't even that spicy - if you're into spicy food. Don't come here if you're starving.
author: Charmaine P.

description:
For some reason, my parents LOVEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE this place. This is like their GO TO list whenever they are in downtown. 
Although this is really the ramen place, I think their ramen sucks honeslty. 
I know 90% of these ramen places in SF use pre-made miso pack anyways (instead of making their own broth from the scratch), but this place even seems like they pre-made their noodle, and just pour the soup over after. 

Then people may wonder, why the hell did you leave 4 stars?LOL
Well... their katsu is amazingly good. And to be honest, this place is pretty good for mall cuisine. 
Oh and they have bubble teas :) 
Those are pretty good too ! hahah Try Honey lemon one :) !!
author: Yumi K.

description: In all honesty, this was the best ramen I have had so far in my two short months in San Francisco.  I have gone to Japantown and Fi Di for ramen but Ajisen Ramen had the best overall ramen quality especially for the price.  I ordrered the Ajisen Ramen and the best part was the soup because unlike the other shops I've been to, the broth was actually not overly salty and actually drinkable.  The noodles were the chewy type which is my preference and decently cooked, not the best but not the worst.  The meat wasn't the best part of the meal because it wasn't soft and tender but more tough. Nonetheless, it still had flavor.  Service was decently fast and the food came out quick.  The only qualms I had was that the amount of ingredients was little but for the price, I wouldn't expect a whole lot.
author: Jasmine C.

description:
Came here since I was craving pho soup, or any kind of noodle soup!!!!!!! lol.
and this hit the spot :) loved the noodles.. 
they give you the big spoon, and the chop sticks, [duh].

they didn't ask if I wanted to take the rest to go,
I had asked them if I can get a to go container since I didn't finish..
(I did forget how to use chop sticks in the beginning, but got the hang of it though(: )..
weird they don't really ask.. the men seemed a little more helpful. hmm...
they sit you as soon as there's a seat available, but it's in a small space,
so they sit you very close to other people O_o 

 I will be coming back here for soup:)
very good!

it's easy to get to since it's in downtown :)

Yummyyy!!!
author: Mariana O.

description:
It's the best you can expect from a chain restaurant in a mall food court.  There is usually a crowd here, and sometimes you have to wait a few minutes for a table.  However, the service is fast and they go through customers fairly quickly.  

Excellent selection of fruity fizzy drinks and iced teas.  There is a wide variety of ramen to chose from, though for the most part they use only three different broths, with variations in added meats.  Volcano ramen might kill white people, so watch out!  Fried chicken ramen is good, any curry ramen is excellent, and the spicy pork or premium pork is my go-to.  There is shredded cabbage in nearly every ramen dish, which some might find odd.  Personally I'm okay with it.  

Servers are prompt and efficient.  Never had a problem with anyone there, and at this point I've been at least six times.  They move very quick and have never made a mistake with my order.

Honestly this is the only place I'll eat in the mall.  It's clearly the best option.
author: Lars T.

description: Not bad for mall served ramen. Quite decent, actually... But then again it IS in the San Francisco Centre and though I am biased, the standards for mall food in this shopping mall is higher than most. My friends & I spotted Ajisen on a cold, rainy Friday and were happy to see they had ramen inside this mall but the line to get seated was halfway down the page of the sign-in list... So being we couldnt wait that long as we were starving and tired, we ordered at the take-out counter, they gave us a pager and about 10 mins later.... buzzzzzz... our order was ready. Boom! I ordered the premium pork ramen (tonkotsu). It surprised me how tasty it was. The ramen noodles were a good consistency. The broth was rich & a little salty. Just the way I like and expect it. The tonkotsu was tender and was cut easily with the plastic spoon & fork it came with.... Being that it was a to-go order. They packaged the ramen separately from the broth/pork/vegetables. The plastic containers they came in were sturdy and every utensil (chopsticks/spoon/fork) I could possibly need was neatly packed for us. I commend them. Everything was organized well. Down to how they stacked all the containers in the 2 heavy duty plastic bags they came in. Props!
author: Chuck D.

description:
Noodle was hot and good. Just the place was too hot due to the lights and crowd.
I will return but hope the seating can be improved so the experience.
author: Andrew F.

description: We used to run into Ajisen Ramen when we lived in Shanghai.  The menu in Asia has more variety but this is a good place to stop in when you need a bowl of ramen.  I usually get the ABC and it's good. Love the broth, the chewiness of the noodles and I always leave satisfied.
author: Susan C.

description:
This is technically a 3.5 star review. 

Located on the base floor in the Westfield mall, this is a solid, convenient sit down option. 

The service is satisfactory and the ramen is definitely good. For how quickly it's brought to you and for the price, you can't expect anything too fancy. 

My personal favorite is the spicy pork ramen. I've had the tonkatsu and it's not the milky broth you'd expect. The volcano ramen is great for those who like spicy food. 

Haven't ordered it here, but boba is also available.
author: Alice H.

description: Ive eaten here about 4 times. When my bf and I first started dating we ate here after walking around the mall. Its pretty restaurant-like. We tried the baby octopus and at first I was very afraid at first but when I tried it, it didn't taste fishy like I thought. I believe they boil it. It was refreshing. The servers are very attentive and nice. THey don't forget you. I don't think I've had to wait long for a table or to receive my food. There are a lot of people that come in there. Obviously everyone loves this place! The soup here is excellent and so is the pork katsu!!! Definitely come here if you got a craving for it.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Double dinner! Double dinner! After a crappy meal at Ryoko's, Tranny and I walked to Ajisen Ramen for dinner #2. Why oh why do I bother going to overpriced Japanese restaurants when Ajisen has perfected ramen and at dirt-cheap prices.  We got the special pork, fried chicken, and agedashi tofu (so we can compare it with Ryoko's at double the price).  The ramen and fried chicken was perfection but I will say their tofu needs a little work.

This ramen shop is conveniently located in Westfield mall- and I highly recommend this place if you are visiting SF and want a guaranteed yummy meal for under $20.
author: Betty L.

description: Ramen broth was super tasty for the Ajisen Ramen combo. Came with lots of meat but I really only like one of them, the other two were eother hard or not flavored enough. The noodles were cooked at a good tenderness and it tasted great with the broth. I wish there was other ingredients as well though.
author: Cindy T.

description: I got the ABC since 3 kinds of pork sounded really good, but it didn't meet my expectations.  The pork was pretty good, but it did not cover up the lack of flavor in the broth or noodles.  The noodles were cooked fine, just nothing to it.  We also had the potstickers which were the size of an unshelled walnut.  With only 4 to an order, it was more like the size of 2 normal sized ones.  I think I get better value at other places in this large food court.
author: Scott F.

description:
Much better than expected considering the 3 star rating. Best ramen place yet since moving back to the Bay Area. I was expecting something not quite as authentic, but this is the only place other than Santouka where I have found that amazing creamy pork broth (Ajisen Ramen). With the way it looks, it can't be healthy. But oh so delicious!  Noodles were really good too. Cooked al dente. I won't swear that they are fresh, but they are definitely not your average dried Ramen noodle. 

I highly recommend the Ajisen Ramen. Quite an experience. My son's chicken ramen was also quite good. They had sauteed and caramelized the onions in that dish, giving the broth a very nice flavor. My husband ordered a cold, soba noodle salad, which was very healthy and flavorful. Prices were maybe a bit high, but not unexpected considering the location and the portions are quite large.
author: Nora S.

description: I really like this place for quick, yummy, filling, reasonably-priced ramen (lots of choices!) with friendly, quick service.  This location is perfect in the west side of the mall food court as you can run in for a quick meal while you are downtown and be on your merry way full and happy!
author: Maile N.

description:
C'mon guys, how can you seriously compare this place to the Ramen KINGS in San Mateo?! You're in a mall... DOWNTOWN for god sake. This is a touristy spot.. so you're not gonna get food where the locals eat, obviously.

The ramen is actually really good, considering the location. I ordered the Spicy pork ramen and bf ordered the one with all 3 meats (Special something). It was actually very tasty! Broth was salty, but not too salty. Pork was tender and noodles weren't special, but they were delicious nonetheless. We also ordered fried chicken (kinda like fried calamari, but with chicken) and it came with a mayo dipping sauce. Pretty tasty!

There was also a lot of people waiting for a seat, but the servers were quick, efficient and polite! I don't know how they keep their cool. They deserve that extra star.

I'm a Ramen Dojo fan.. and obviously this place isn't it, but I'd eat here in a heartbeat for a quick fix when I doni't want to wait 2 hours for my bowl of noodles that I would inhale in 2 minutes.

Just do it.
author: Lynda P.

description:
This is better than your average mall food.   anyway....

my friend orderd pork ramen and pork cutlet w/curry sauce & rice.  He orders the ramen for the broth and eats it with rice...

I ordered the tofu soba salad.   way too much dressing.   

not bad nor good.  bill came to $35 for 2 ppl.  take it he did most of the ordering.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Today was the grand opening day of this Japanese fast food chain. The menu variety is awesome, more than a dozen types of ramen and a ton of snacks (appetizers) plus a few rice plates. I'd definitely come back to try more items.

As expected, the place was filled with customers and servers were having difficulty adjusting to the fast pace. The system is not well organized yet, so once seated u could easily be forgotten about. Apparently different staff are assigned separate tasks and since they don't seem to talk to each other... u get the picture. Just be proactive and flag someone when u need something. On the other hand the kitchen was doing a superb job and all orders (after they've received them) I saw were completed in under 10-12 minutes. Takeout orders get a green device that buzzes when the order is ready for pickup.

The picture menu is a very nice feature, although it only has a general description of the dish and doesn't tell u every ingredient in the bowl. Only a few ramen versions include an egg (hard boiled, I prefer soft boiled eggs). Ajisen specializes in Kumamoto Ramen, similar to Hakata Ramen (same region, Kyushu island), which uses straight noodles.

I'm familiar with Ajisen, so for my first order I knew I wanted to try the premium pork ramen ($8.75) http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/70kpSXbqNSrxe0zVFF2kBA/l and I was not disappointed. If u like Santouka u will like this tonkotsu broth very much. It's topped with thinly sliced pork. All the meats I saw were sliced thin, so if left unattended the meat could dry quickly. In short, the soup was delicious!

So far the appetizers ("snacks") are just okay. The gyoza are tiny. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/j6npB1pcSHCPVZAf5-P22w/l
For anyone with sesame seed allergies, know that the rice in the California roll is premixed with it.

UPDATE: service has improved a lot after the first week. And found another winner in the tender pork ribs ramen. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/0UyA-_QlcdJ6zCI9rL3E0w/l
Solid 4 stars!

Unlike most other ramen shops they accept take out orders. Yay!
Hours: Mon-Sat 10am-8:30pm, Sun 10am-7pm
author: Luis C.

description:
The following are known facts:

1) This place is NOT authentic ramen. If you're looking for delicious and complex Japanese ramen, I wouldn't look at chains, which segues into the next fact...

2) Yes, this place IS a chain. Meaning the focus is more on an easy to follow simple recipe.

3) This place is not Japanese run, obviously.

However, this doesn't detract from the fact that Ajisen Ramen produces decent and delicious ramen. The first time I tried this chain was believe it or not, actually in Melbourne. One things that you need to know first is that Melbourne is a LOT more expensive than San Francisco - you'd be hard pressed to find any meal for less than 10 dollars in a restaurant is what I mean. What's considered cheap in Melbourne is considered overpriced in the bay area.

Now... after that's settled, onto the review.

Atmosphere:
Considering how it has its own little section in Westfield, it is pretty cramped. I don't particularly mind, but it is something to consider if you're coming with a large group or just don't like sitting super close near others.

Customer Service:
I see some reviews complaining about the fact that the service is not Japanese, but I don't think this really matters. The customer service is really friendly, welcoming, and attentive - THAT'S what matters.

Food:
I ordered the tender pork spare ribs ramen, also known as paiku ramen. I was a bit disappointed to see that the prices were.... exactly the same prices as Melbourne. And remember what I said? That means that it's pretty overpriced. However, the pork was still very tasty, tender, and the soup yummy. I added a bit of red pepper for an extra kick and loved it. The downside is that the additions to the ramen were a bit disappointing - basic cabbage, not even an egg! Ajisen Ramen in Melbourne was more complex than this - I expect more out of a branch in San Francisco (the food capital itself!)

---

Overall, I can't fault Ajisen Ramen. Don't come here expecting much, but they do deliver consistently delicious ramen. If you're willing to spend 10 dollars for excellent service and 3-stars ramen, have a visit. If you're looking for something more authentic, skip the trip.
author: Clarissa Y.

description:
For a franchised chain of ramen restaurants, I have been surprised by the lack of uniformity in Ajisen restaurants. From Hong Kong to Singapore to Bangkok to NYC and now SF, each has had varying standards and slightly differing menu items but sadly none have offered the cold beef brisket with mustard dipping sauce from the Hong Kong stores. 

That dish would have been a wonderful treat because I was unfortunately really underwhelmed by my ramen here. Despite ordering the premium pork ramen (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=5Krro9IQUfl1HLjTnTMvag), I found the broth to be lacking in rich fatty pork flavor. The ramen noodles were flat and didn't have a good consistency or spring in your mouth. We also had the seaweed salad (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=scqMp02rI56nFZzR1nsASA) but it was pretty pedestrian too. Not bad, but it's probably what you can buy from the supermarket too.

A special shout-out here to the manager though who took his time to explain the difference between the premium pork and pork rib ramen. I was torn between the two but went with his recommendation. He nicely sent out a piece of pork rib as a side for me to try when my ramen arrived. That's pretty sweet customer service. 

For a quick ramen fix, Ajisen will do in a bind. But to truly savor ramen, you might need to explore a lil further beyond the mall.
author: Jon L.

description: Not bad ramen. It's mall/chain ramen, but has good flavor. The noodles have a good texture and the broth is tasty. I really like that there's cabbage included. I got the ABC, which includes three types of pork. All were forgettable. Not bad, just meh. So far in my ramen quest, this is the only bowl that I felt needed a little something else and adding some spice improved. I wouldn't make a special trip for this ramen and won't be craving it, but if I was at the mall and was hungry, I'd stop here instead of some other fast food joint.
author: John B.

description: One of my favorite restaurants of all time! So lucky to have one in sf! The food is identical to the ones in Asia!
author: George H.

description: Pretty great for mall food. Not in the top 5 ramen in SF, but.. it's mall food, what were you expecting?
author: Adam D.

description: It's a chain.  It's overpriced and overrated.  I ordered the shoyu ramen and paid nearly $10 for it.  I also waited a really long time for my order.  I guess the ramen craze hasn't hit SF that same way it has in LA because this was the only place at the food court with a long wait/line.  It's really not that good.  The broth is watered down, and the noodles were stuck together and rubbery.  It was nice to have hot soup on a cold, rainy day, but it wasn't really worth the wait or the price.
author: Ambar C.

description: For a mall food I have to give it a five star. What do you expect here? I though it was good for a mall food. What I hate is the line. That's the only thing. Their honey tea with aloe is pretty good too. Price is decent.
author: Ha N.

description: I'm a big fan of this ramen chain! Not only is their ramen pretty good (the combo!) the chicken karage is the best I've ever had, and the milk tea is great here too! Can't believe this is in westfield mall. What a delicious place!
author: Joanna S.

description: I ate here thrice, only when im really hungry. If im not that deadly hungry I usually go to kantaya to eat ramen.
author: Linh C.

description:
You'd be surprised that a ramen place inside the underground level of a shopping mall would be the home of some of the tastiest ramen in the city. The ABC (Ajisen Best Combo) is one of my favorites on the menu, providing you with some premium pork and tender pork ribs which is a must eat when here. The broth is so flavorful - salty, oily, all-around delicious. The fried chicken and gyoza are both good sides but the gyoza is a little on the pricey side. 

Service is a little lackluster, especially during peak dining periods. Don't expect them to visit your table or refill your water - which you have to request btw, or they won't bring you any.

Regardless, this is my go-to spot - will definitely come here again. And again. And again!
author: Jordan K.

description:
For a fast little ramen nook in the middle of a mall, this place isn't too bad. It's pretty easy to get a seat and they tend to you quickly with full service (this is not one of those cafeteria type stands in a food court). 

That being said, the flavor of the broth and quality of the noodles is nowhere near what you can find in other ramen places in the city and Bay Area at large. It's just a decent option that's quick and pretty affordable for downtown workers and visitors who need a salty soup and noodle fix!
author: Christina P.

description:
I'm pretty sure I found my Ramen spot in San Francisco and its the Ajisen Ramen inside the Westfield food court basement.

The trick @ Ajisen Ramen is finding the right Ramen bowl for you, for me:

it was the Fried Chicken Ramen, the fried chicken comes on the side which is perfect and then I add the spicy beef broth for 1$, I also add the spicy beef for another 2$.  The noodles are delicious and after I'm done with them, theres still the delicious broth left, spicy and savory! 

I usually like to order Gyoza, (Japanese pot stickers) with my meal.

To top it off, I'll order a large Thai Iced Tea with Bobba 4.5$
Its so good that I'll another thai tea to go!

All in all I spent about 25$ plus tip for one meal which was well spent.
author: Charlie B.

description:
very good ramen for a mall food. my daughter and I shared the one with corn and it was satisfying to share for 2 people. If you are really hungry a bowl will fill up very well.
Cheap and fast service...taste pretty authentic to me but I don't really have ramen so for me it was very good.
author: Meriza D.

description:
Even with a crowd it's quite quick to grab a seat and their service is fast. You can probably order, eat your ramen, and pay the check in no more than 30 minutes.

I wouldn't say the servers are super friendly or helpful, but they are courteous. They are never around to refill my water, but I guess there are so many people coming in and out.

It's convenient and cheap, but the noodles you can tell haven't been boiled long so they are still partially under cooked.

I've ordered their miso, ajisen, and spicy pork ramen which were all good. Spicy pork ramen happened to be spicier than I expected it to be so be warned as they don't refill your water often.
author: Dorris W.

description:
Pretty good ramen, but not quite 4 stars.  The broth is sweet and delicious.  The noodles reminded me of egg noodles that's in wonton noodles, but the texture is different.  With 3 pieces of pork, seaweed, and half an egg, it makes a decent meal.
Fast service and the Honey aloe green tea was delicious.
author: Karen L.

description: It's a cheap easy bowl of ramen if your desperate for it. They have odd seating rules that they stick to even when it's empty as hell. It filled my stomach but wasn't memorable at all. Better off heading across the way for better food selection at the Westfield food court instead.
author: Joco F.

description: I wanted to give this place a chance after having had passed it several times at the food court at Westfield. The ramen to me lacked a lot of flavor, and the boiled egg was very overcooked. What really ruined it for me were the bugs squirming in my glass of water.
author: R I.

description:
I agree with some reviews that the noodles were a bit under-cooked, but otherwise it was alright. 

The waiter was kind enough to notify me that the broth does have fish flakes in it, but they could make it with a water base instead. Shouldn't the Vegetable Ramen come with a vegetarian broth anyway? Confusing.

My mom ate a side order of baby octopus, and she seemed to enjoy it. I think she just found it amusing to be eating something like that in front of her veggie daughter. ;)
author: Brandi W.

description: Popped in for the premium pork ramen & added spice...it was pretty good. Was it the best ramen I've ever had...no, but it was not bad for a mall meal.
author: Nicole E.

description: Server sucks. Empty tables everywhere. Told us we can't sit in the large table, but there are two people just sitting right next to us using the large table. I asked him why they can use large table, then he tried to ask them to share the table with us. What a douche! Making us the bad buys now.
author: Jim C.

description:
When you want to shop, you don't want to spend too much on food. This place isn't too bad for its ramen. It's a famous chain internationally, so there's a minimum level of satisfaction there. 

Averages out to be $9 per ramen. You have your basics: shoyu, miso, house. Then you have the spicy options with spicy beef, spicy pork, curry beef. On top of that, you have the premium meat. Their soup base is very thick, lots of MSG/sodium/salt/name-it-however-you'd-like. But ramen without soup is like... walking the dirty streets of downtown without shoes. No matter how much you don't want that sodium intake, do drink the soup while you eat your noodles. My favorite is the spicy pork, 1) I love spicy food, 2) you get your serving of veggies, 3) you get the sliced pork and the minced pork, 4) hi half an egg. It's guaranteed to be filling. Generally Japanese places, especially around Union Square, don't serve ramen on their a la carte menu. So if you're craving for some non-instant ramen, there's an okay spot right inside Westfield.

Their noodles aren't too consistent though, nor their service. I feel like their noodles are a bit too undercooked, creating this overly chewy texture. Their service can be bad especially near dinner hours. It took a while to get our check. But there were times where there was barely any wait time other than for the food to cook. 

Do try their appetizers. Fried calamari is great to share, don't wait til it's cold, the calamari gets very chewy that way. It's not overly floured, so you get a bit of the batter taste but it's not like a tempura where the calamari may be drenched in the batter. Their beef enoki is pretty good, but not worth the price for two pieces. Make it yourself at home. Agedashi tofu is not bad either, but it's more worthwhile at a regular Japanese restaurant.
author: Connie C.

description:
I am actually a fan of Ajisen Ramen. I know it's not the best compared to places like Ramen Dojo or Santouka in the Bay Area but it's decent. It doesn't feel authentic since it's located in the mall but the ramen portions are filling and passes the taste test for me!

I ordered the spicy pork ramen ($8.95) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=70kpSXbqNSrxe0zVFF2kBA#8x8LoIsui3S1oSK3Qpn2uw) last time and remember to order at your own risk. This came out much spicier than I had anticipated! At least the noodles weren't soggy and the meat was very tender. My mouth was on fire and I was sweating when I got towards the bottom of the bowl but it was still a yummy meal. 

The bf and I also shared the agedashi tofu (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=70kpSXbqNSrxe0zVFF2kBA#_SjTQyT3mKA0-xifwNPRKw) and this was just alright since the tofu wasn't even really fried. Oh well, sometimes you get what you pay for! 

If I had to choose between Ajisen and Katana-ya, I would definitely pick the latter but I would still grab a bite here if I happened to be hungry at the mall.
author: Karen Y.

description:
Ajisen Ramen probably only has a decent rating because it's in the mall, and when you're eating mall food, you just don't care.  Your mind is elsewhere, thinking about what you're going to buy next.  Also, you are also on-the-go, so you eat quite quickly most of the time.

I ordered the Combination Ramen, which included all different types of pork.  The soup base wasn't so flavorful.  I'm used to eating at ramen places where you can't get enough of the soup/noodles.

Nothing in particular sticks out with the food here.  I'd just come here if you want someplace quick to eat while you're shopping, or if you're in the mood for soup.
author: Andrew H.

description:
the best ramen I have even had. I am recently traveling in this beautiful city.
my friend told me I have to go and check it out. it was very busy there i guess it is because the food is so good. thanks and highly recommended.
author: lady g.

description:
I was happily taken by surprise by Ajisen. I can't believe I had amazing ramen in a food court. 

ABC Ramen
+Broth was delicious, I was given spices to add to my ramen. 
+Noodles were spaghettini style. A thinner noodle, cooked perfectly. Al dente is always the best way to have ramen. 
+Pork was soft, and well seasoned. 
-I wish this came with menma (bamboo shoots) though. 

Croquette
+Very crispy on the outside and a smooth creamy texture on the inside. 
-I wish it had the corn kernels in it though. 

Service 
+Waitresses were friendly, helpful, and efficient. No complaints here. 

Price
+Very reasonably priced for the portion amount. 

I'll be back soon! Thank you.
author: Laura L.

description:
We came here at 8:29pm on a Saturday and they wouldn't take us. We were hungry for ramen and spoke to the manager, but apparently she really wanted to go home so couldn't take us. 

Come on guys. This is a mall restaurant.  It's not like we're going to linger for 2 hours,  You could have made 2 more bowls of ramen and still made it home on time.  Now you get a bad review. 

(We've been here many times before. 3 stars for the food - it's decent though a bit pricey for mall food.)

There are plenty of other places. We're heading to katana-ya.
author: howie f.

description:
I don't know if there's some science to ramen or whatever but I LOVE the ramen here. I've probably been coming to this place since it opened and the taste, temperature, everything never fails to deliver. The food court location I suppose doesn't dictate an awesome experience but I have no problem with it. I shouldn't need to go super out of my way just for noodles. Anyway, I can come here with friends and have great conversations with them or I can just go alone and ear hustle some great stories.

My new favorite is the spicy pork ramen. It's pretty spicy but not TOO spicy.
author: Alano T.

description: I always eat Curry rice with pork cullet,  delicious and I always order to go back home, but this time 3/30 I'm not satisfy with the service. I have rice and pork cullet but no curry, how do I suppose to eat the rice without curry or call curry rice with pork cullet and the money I spent on order to go.
author: Hennessy L.

description: The service is very good. The premium pork Ramen is excellent. The meat was good and the broth was tasty. The tempura Mochi was good. The California roll was well made and tasted fresh. Located in the basement food court of the mall, I had pretty low expectations. This place was a pleasant surprise. I would come back again.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
I ran into Ajisen Ramen while browsing through the Westfield Mall near the Powell BART Station. Since I hail from the East Coast, I was blown away when I saw ramen in a mall. I literally have to go on a 4 hour roundtrip to New York City every time I want to try ramen, so I lost it when I saw people slurping ramen in the food court.

I sat down and ordered the Classic Ajisen ramen and the honey green aloe tea. On my second visit I was also able to try the Dan Dan Mien and their version of Poki (forgot what it was called on the menu). I wasn't sure what I was going to expect, but I found myself pleasantly surprised. The bowls are in the $8-$11 range, and they do not skimp on quantity. The Classic Ajisen broth was rich and salty, and although the noodles weren't as chewy and firm as they are at other places, their soft texture made them super easy to slurp. I didn't like the Dan Dan Mien as much, but man, at $7.95, I think I'm kind of in love with the Classic Ajisen. The sides were also surprisingly delicious.

Service was good, and the food comes out fast. I was in and out in less than 30 minutes. My biggest complaint are the toppings on the ramen. The pseudo-cha siu was floppy and flavorless, and the half egg in the ramen was hardboiled (it should be soft-boiled for maximum ramen happiness!). Basically, just skip the toppings altogether and slurp up that sweet, sweet broth and noodles.
author: Soonwook H.

description:
Love every Ramen they provide. I tasted the heaven After put single drop of sriracha sauce in Ajisen Ramen. 
Service was good, fast and attentive, consider of fast food restaurant, I ll give 6 stars to service. 
Price is ok, typical lunch price
author: Stacy U.

description: We walked in and the server asked us to sit whatever. Half of the restaurant was empty so we two sat on a table of four because other couple sat on table of four, too. The server ame and asked us to sit on smaller table. We told him that other couples did the same but he insisted to ask us to move. Unbelievable.
author: Anya C.

description:
Normally I do not do any reviews as it's just a waste of time especially if it's a bad one. In this case, I'll make an exception. So I'm hungry and happen to be craving some croquettes and the only one I know that sells it near by is this location. Went in and was seated quite fast. Keep in mind, there was a couple leaving as I got there and a table for 2 open as well. As I was settling in, one of the waitress's was asking her co-worker why I was sitting there. Apparently there was a family of 4 who got there first, mind you that they were no where near the entrance despite the sign up sheet that I was not informed about. So after arguing in whatever they were saying, they had to ask me to leave and wait as the seats were already reserved. Now, I don't mind if they were already signed up on the list, what I don't like is the fact that somehow this family left for how long and comes back and the staff at this location just can't keep it together. 

I honestly left the location stating that the service wasn't good and that I just "decided" to leave. I somehow lost my appetite for croquettes. Maybe I should've just not crave them anymore, eh? The service was overall, eh. I'd like to give a 1 but because it was conveniently near by, they had croquettes and was seated quickly, 1 more star was added. I'll try again but I'm hoping their service is better.
author: Altarose C.

description:
Came here because I was craving some ramen and the Fremont location is my FAVORITE ramen in the entire bay area, even better than orenchi in Santa Clara.

Thinking it'd be more of the same set me up for unfathomable disappointment.  It's like you win a date with a playboy playmate and you find out she was featured in the 1945 issue.

small portions, skimpy on the toppings, this is not the ajisen i'm used to!

The chicken karage was crap as well, the fremont location gives you a few huge chunks of succulent chicken, you get chicken nuggets here.

bleh.

So sad, thought I found a taste of heaven, instead got a taste of tenderloin.
author: Tu T.

description:
Really low quality ramen. I suppose it might be a lot to expect a solid ramen out of a mall food court spot, but the reviews I read said it was good. 

I was literally gagging as I was eating the spicy pork ramen. Way too salty, and the meat seemed cheap and undercooked. 

The gyoza I ordered was equally horrible, undercooked, and literally cold inside. 

Yelp has been failing me lately; are there any decent bowls of ramen in SF? I'm from LA and I guess was spoiled with several great options.
author: Andrew M.

description: Order #1, spicy.   Unfortunately not every location is the same but the overall menu is close enough. The location in Fremont is the best in the bay, followed by the SF location.
author: P A.

description: This Ajisen Ramen reminds me of So Cal. Food was good love it and want to come for more. Preferred this one than the one in Freemont (which is a bit dirty) and the pork wasn't burn. :)
author: Christina H.

description: Great place for a quick lunch! I was amazed how delicious the broth was. The texture of the meat was great too! On my first visit, I ordered the spicy pork ramen which was awesome!! On my second, I tried the abc ramen and that went great too!! Dont know when I'll be visiting SF again, but will definitely re-visit this place ;)
author: Grace H.

description:
A bit on the pricey side, but good for a quick bite. Our food came in 5 minutes. I got the tender pork ramen and it really did live up to it's name.

Tip: Order it to go if there's a line and find ample seating in the food court.
author: Eric C.

description:
Nom nom nom. Even though it's pricy, I don't mind spending a pretty penny at this place. Love their boba. Love their milk tea. Love their specialty drinks. Love their ramen! 

Buuuut...I'm almost 75% sure it's not ramen noodles. Pretty sure it's thin spaghetti (lol). It's definitely not the authentic ramen you get from Japan (oh how I miss the streets of Kyoto). But hey, good food is worth it in my book!!!
author: Debbie C.

description:
This place is spectacular. Loved the flavor of their soup, especially, the spicy ramen
soup


The wait can be long but the staff is attentive, fast, and efficient. You'll get your food really quickly.  

 Definitely my go to restaurant now for a good bowl of ramen.
author: Dongyu G.

description: Pretty tasty restaurant. Last time I went with some friends, there was a 40 min wait. Ramen is good but in little portions and light weight expensive.
author: Ricky C.

description: They don't have Scallops Ramen anymore, so I order Ajisen Ramen, it's ok tho. Corn Salad is better than the other Ajisen around bay area, I think.
author: Sloan L.

description:
cool ramen spot at mall. always come here.

customer service is a little rushed but it's only because they are always usually really busy. I get a table and served my food in a decent amount of time  though.
author: Brittaney C.

description:
This place was a staple for lunchtime meals. Whenever I'm unsure of what I should have for lunch, Ajisen was always the place I ended up. For a chain ramen place in the downtown mall, it's actually quite good for a decent price.

My favorite item on the menu is the Spicy Pork Ramen. The noodles here always have the right amount of bounce and chewiness to them and the broth is flavorful.

Their other dishes that I've tried are just mediocre (nothing special about them). The Pork Cutlet Curry is standard fare and the Premium Pork Plate is decent enough. However, both make for pretty boring meals (just pork and rice). The milk tea at Ajisen is fairly strong, I could definitely feel the caffeine after drinking it. I know I'll be back when I'm in the neighborhood and have a hankering for some ramen.
author: Vivian L.

description:
It's just pretty good. The noodles are obviously spaghetti. The broth (at least for the spicy beef ramen) was just a lot of hot oil. The chunks of beef were plentiful and surprisingly delicious, but the noodles leave a lot to be desired. My stepmother got the fried tofu and liked it. I got baby octopus and it was fine. They have a good selection of drinks. I got the Thai ice tea with boba and my stepmother got the same without, and they didn't have too much ice. If you're looking for an authentic experience, avoid this place. If you're looking for an acceptable bowl and you're in Westfield, this place is good enough.

The main reason I'm giving them 3 stars instead of 4 is because they charge for every topping. 50 cents per half egg, 1.75 if you want corn, the spicy beef ramen came completely plain. Come on dudes. It's already $10 for this stuff.
author: Aryana W.

description:
Pros: accepts credit, great service (water refills, other requests)
Cons: very crowded Saturday nights (my experience), salty broth (Volcano Ramen)

A friend and I came here one Saturday night and it was so full. We waited around 10 minutes before being seated. The menu has a lot of variety. I ended up choosing the Volcano Ramen because I saw that they rated it "3" chilies. I like spicy food so I thought I would try that out. My friend got an order of gyoza and he ordered their pork ramen. I don't usually eat ramen unless it is in factory packaging with flavored powder, but overall, eating ramen in a bowl was good. The volcano wasn't very volcano, but more saltier than I imagined. The noodles weren't as cooked as I would have liked either, just a few more minutes and they would have been cooked perfectly. My ramen came with a clump of chilies in oil and if that is how they constitute "volcano,' then I am so confused. The chilies didn't really do much for me but make the soup oilier. I would probably choose the pork ramen, as my friend recommended to me, the next time I come eat ramen here again. The food came out in a good fashion and the servers were very good with customer service. ~$10 per bowl of ramen is okay, but I still would like to see more. Perhaps less salty, more meats/fillings, and noodles that have gotten more time to cook.
author: Alex T.

description:
This place is definitely yummy! A good place to warm up after going through the raging storm outside of Westfield mall.

I came here today for lunch since my boyfriend had to go to the Levi's store at Union Square and he really seems to love this place. We came here around 2:10 and there was about 6 full tables beside ours. Service was definitely quick! Order in 5 minutes, get food in 3 minutes. They were piping hot and full of flavor!
