(: I had gotten their corn ramen and yes, it was SO full of corn on one side and a bunch of cabbage and seaweed on the other. The egg was a bit hard, but that's alright. The pork was also nice and tender and the broth left me wanting more. 

The only reason I don't give this place 5 stars is because in my book, Tanpopo is still the best place to be for good ol' ramen. But hey, this place is my second choice. (:
author: Venus L.

description:
I like this ramen place because it's one of the few that I've found in the city that serves vegetarian ramen (with veggie or water based broth). 

Their ramen is not the absolute best tasting but the convenience of this place in the food court at Westfield mall is awesome. I also like that their area is set up like an actual restaurant...in a food court! It's really cool. San Francisco malls really step it up. However the location in the mall with the restaurant setup does lead to some long waits once in awhile. 

Ajisen also sells boba which I've yet to try. My only suggestion would be that they expand their vegetarian options a bit more. I'd be a total regular if I didn't have one option during every visit.
author: Vidya K.

description:
First time at Ajisen was actually in Shanghai, when we were in a hurry to find any place to eat.  The meal was not memorable. So when it opened up in SF, it took me a while to want to go there, and when I did, it took me a while to think about what to order. 

The obvious is the ramen.  My mom likes the broth.  I went for the eel rice instead. Definitely have had better. And for $13, I can't even say at least it was cheap.  

The gyoza was also just okay.  That one, at least, was definitely cheap, about $3 for 4 little dumplings. 

Tempura mochi was interesting.  If you like sticky savory mochi, this dish can't go wrong. 

The drinks were, formidable. Mango, lychee, cranberry juice came in an enormous cup.  Definitely wasn't fresh juice, but that was to be expected.  

Boba drinks are decent enough to satisfy if urgent craving were to arise. 

Overall, just like the visit in Shanghai, nothing really stood out, but for some reason, I have a feeling I will probably go back, as in, "oh what's there to eat in the mall, let's just go to Ajisen!"

At least the service is quick and friendly.
author: Candice B.

description:
I wanted a quick bite but the service is anything but quick. I was constantly ignored -- from seating, to ordering, to getting my food. My bowl of noodle sat on the counter for a good 5 minutes and one of the servers kept touching the bowl but never distributing it. 

The ramen was ok but not worth going out of your way for.
author: Ann H.

description:
A Japanese friend of ours was in town, and kept going on about Ajisen ramen, how great it was, and how it was all he ate when he was in Australia.  I decided to look it up as a joke, and to my surprise, they had a branch in San Francisco, not far from where we were staying!

First of all, the quality of the meat inside is really, really good for fast food ramen.  I had the pork rib ramen, and the ribs were EXACTLY like so-ki pork served in Okinawan ramen.  It blew my mind that they could get something like that right in the States.

I wasn't a huge fan of the soup base, which definitely needed some vinegar or something to spice it up.  There are limited Japanese condiments available, which is kind of crucial when you're eating ramen.  The noodles were very pasta-like as opposed to noodles, but were good.  Not the best ramen I've had, but it was still very good.

My husband got the spicy pork ramen, which was also pretty good, but again, was missing that little pow that it needed to avoid being just heavy/spicy.  The toppings were all delicious, though.

The chicken kara-age is really yummy, served with kewpie mayonnaise.  To give it a Japanese touch, try sprinkling some of the shichimi pepper spice onto the mayonnaise before you dig in.

I definitely look forward to trying their Los Angeles branch soon!
author: Katie M.

description:
I haven't had much experience with real ramen, and I'm not sure I'm a fan of eating in a mall food court. That said, I've definitely had worse. 

They were relatively quick, and were able to accommodate our rather large group. We went during the busy lunch hour, so I was impressed.

The good: decent ramen.
The bad: it's still a mall, so...expect mall people.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Wow. Racism is alive and well. This place not only screwed up my in law's order five times (didn't bring their food, "forgot" to place their order, brought them the wrong thing when they finally did bring the order etc), they also didn't try too make it right when we spoke to the manager. 

The ramen is ok, it's no Sawaii or Ken Ken, but the shocking ineptitude and bald faced racism (black people do not all look the same!) means I'm giving this place a pass in the future.
author: Loretta S.

description: This Ajisen is located in the Westfield mall.  I've tried the place in Fremont before and I thought the noodles were pretty good.  I was expecting the same quality but it felt like something was lacking here.  The service was basically absent, and the noodles felt off.  I think I would rather go to the one in Fremont.
author: Danielle C.

description: Ramen place hit the spot and was totally surprise just because it's located in the mall. Noodles were fresh and extra spicy just ask.  Just a $1 more
author: Linda B.

description:
I came here twice, both times I was super craving for ramen. The first time, I ordered the beef ramen, which I did not like at all. The broth was way too salty and the beef was chunky and too soft as if it was days old. I was skeptical to come back the second time but I was in the area so decided to give it another go. I got the chicken ramen this time and surprisingly, it was really good. The broth was tasty, not too salty but definitely not bland. There was just a good amount of chicken and noodle. It definitely satisfied my craving and I would definitely come back for the same ramen. 

Dinner time is usually busy where you have to put your name on a wait list. But the line moves fast, people eat and go since it's at the mall. Not a bad place if you want decent ramen.
author: Monica N.

description: My mom took me here for lunch and we ordered the scallop ramen and it was very good.  Two juicy tender scallops, corn and seaweed with a sweet broth.  Last time, I had their tender pork ramen and that was pretty good but the broth was not as good as the one in their scallop ramen.  The tender pork was tender but you could tell that it  wasn't a quality cut.  However, beware of MSG overload.  I got a headache afterward.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
On my way to work Saturday morning, slightly hungover, I left my cell in the bf's car. I forced--I mean asked him nicely to drive it back to me and we would have lunch. I always wanted to try Ajisen and since I am definitely not that comfortable (yet) eating out alone, I didn't want to skip this chance.
We got seated pretty quickly next to a man--who was eating alone and it was totally fine--until he started making some inconsiderate remarks. And we'll get to that in a bit.
After reviewing the entire menu, I noticed they have quite a few different ramens and rice plates and even drinks. I ordered a spicy pork ramen and bf ordered the combo.
After our server leaves, our lone neighbor turns and asks us if he was holding his chopsticks right. Clearly he knew how to hold them, but we politely told him yes. Then he proceeds to ask us if this was exactly how they made it in China. First of all, Ajisen is Japanese ramen. Second, I've only been to Hong Kong about three years ago and I didn't eat any ramen there. How assumptious and ignorant of him, that because I look Asian = I must be from China. Anyway, I'll refrain from posting his picture on the internet.. today.
Back to the important stuff; the soup was pretty salty, but the taste was okay. They added a small scoop of "spicy pork" which is only spicy minced pork which was one of the weirdest things I've tasted. I didn't want to eat the meat, but I wanted the spice it came with so I just mixed it all into the soup and forgot about it. The ramen was different from what most other places serve. Ajisen's were basically Angel Hair. I did not like it at all.. I like the texture of real ramen and angel hair was smooth and round. It wasn't doing it for me.

So all in all, this place is A-ok if I haaad to eat at the mall.. But definitely not something to go out of the way for. And btw, when I gain the confidence to eat alone at a restaurant, I'll be sure not to bother people around me.
author: Athena L.

description: This place is soo good! Their are nice places to sit and the people who work there are kind of rushy but they do pay attention to you if you need something.
author: Kayla D.

description:
I know how I want my ramen: salty, piles of meat, super rich broth, delivered fast and with a huge spoon.  Ajisen delivers. 

Yes, it's in a mall basement, and yes you're surrounded by malltards and tourists, but the ramen is solid, consistent and delicious. The wait can get bad at peak hours, and no one wants to stand around in a mall basement. 

Protips:
1) if there's a long wait, the other Asian spot next door has free samples
2) it's worth the extra change to get the premium pork ramen over the regular pork.
author: Patrick T.

description: Excellent shoyu ramen and great service!  Come early, there will be a line, but it's totally worth it!
author: Justin B.

description: I tried the spicy pork ramen for lunch today and thought it was not bad. The broth and toppings were tasty, though the egg was only OK. The noodles could be better, but overall it exceeded expectations for mall food. I would not mind coming back here again sometime, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: Alice H.

description:
Came here mid afternoon. Thankfully it wasn't too busy. Kinda weird to have table service in the mall but it works right?
Service was quick and efficient. I was seated pretty quickly and the waiters/waitresses are pretty friendly.
I got the volcano ramen. Pretty spicy but satisfied my ramen craving at the very least. The volcano sauce added a nice kick of spice to the ramen.
Overall I enjoyed my meal. 
What more can we expect when people dine in the mall?
author: Kevin W.

description:
Came here for lunch with a friend--was craving pho and Out the Door was closed. Didn't know this place existed before...it's a hop, skip and a jump away from the main food court and my friend recommended it as he's tried the place in Australia. (it's a chain, apparently).

There was a bit of a line, but it moved quickly. The mall-fast-food-court atmosphere is misleading for the delicious ramen that was presented to me. 

I ordered the premium pork ramen and the broth was this beautiful milky looking broth that wasn't too salty and instead, incredibly tasty. I asked them what was in it... the server's limited English wasn't too helpful (it looked like miso but wasn't "swirly" they way miso soups usually are --am I making sense?).... but nonetheless, it was soooo good. And prices are completely reasonable. It really hit the spot.

I'm a big fan of Katana-Ya but this place may steal half my business. 

P.S. They have boba milk teas also. i can kill two cravings in one spot. WIN.
author: Nicha K.

description:
Is it classified as "mall food" if they actually cook and serve you your order? Hmm, and you'll have to leave a tip too.. (sneaky sneaks).

Gyoza: [http://s3-media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ReNBdmaooJ4SyI8_-vqhyg/l.jpg]
I didn't expect much from Ajisen, and I was right. For $3, you get four pathetic miniscule pot stickers, along with a dipping sauce (soy sauce). I'm just gonna leave this with a tip: don't order it.

California Roll: [http://s3-media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/vymNXWkzcaN8_oYrYAXdkQ/l.jpg]
I've never seen CA rolls like this before. It's actually not even a roll, it's squares.. (see picture) BIG-bite squares, might I add. Anyways, it was actually pretty good. Because of the revolutionary new shape, Ajisen sure has room to pack in a ton of imitation crab and avocado in each piece, which is awesome! It took me a good two to three bites to eat one (and that's saying a mouth full because I'm a big eater).

Chicken Ramen: [http://s3-media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/xj7CDOmdgs-d50OM0ypkLA/l.jpg]
A plain and simple ramen for me (since it was gym night and I didn't want a crazy-combo-specialty ramen right before I work out). I was realllyy skeptical because you don't hear of people getting great food in a mall, however, the ramen was not bad. It wasn't your "instant-10c-noodles" and actually had some quality taste to it. Granted the broth was just broth (Chicken Ramen, remember?) so I won't peg them for that, but it was pretty enjoyable. Good amount of white meat chicken too! (which I wanted).

Tender Pork Ramen: [http://s3-media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Cr89SKeVKcOw2-oRVaI8qg/l.jpg]
This was my girlfriend's order. She was hungry, so she wouldn't let me try some. She did however, give me some pork and it was truly-truly tender. It was the same type of tender as a good beef stew. From mall food, you say? Yup, I'm surprised as you are.

The food isn't bad, quite good eatin' from a mall actually, but it is still pricy (the ramen will run you close to $10 per: stupid mall up-charge!). I also ordered a Boba Milk Tea, but it was equivalent to the quality from a Quickly's.. what a shame. However, if I'm spending a day in the Westfield mall and I'm hungry, Ajisen would be my number one choice for food.
author: Albert L.

description:
I've been to in LA and Hong Kong, they were both great.  Not sure why it doesn't taste as good. Shouldn't they all have the same recipe?  

Ordered water but it never came.
author: Eatdrink L.

description: I only come here for their cold soba noodles, which are pretty good. I've tried their ramen and I find it too salty and always leave me feeling incredibly thirsty. Their ahi tuna is okay - the seasoning was good but the tuna didn't taste very fresh. It's located in a mall so it can get pretty crowded. Service was consistently decent all the times I've been here. Not a bad place to stop for some food if you're shopping or in the area, but there are definitely better ramen places in the city.
author: Lena L.

description:
I went there yesterday with my friend, and we ordered a California roll, cold ramen, and Tan Tan ramen. First, the California roll was really bad, too much rice and not as good as it could be. Second, I ordered the cold ramen, it was really cold. And the menu said it was spicy, but when I tasted, not spicy at all, and it tasted a little bit sweet. I was really disappointed. And for my friend's Tan Tan ramen, huh... it was OK, but not as expected. 

One more, I have been there twice, and I ordered the Egg Tofu Pudding, they don' t have it!! 

It is a crowded, noisy, small place. Too many people, and the table is too small, no seasoning, and the services are not good.
author: Yu C.

description:
I think this place deserve at least 4 stars. The customer service is great, their staff is very knowledgable on their Japanese dishes (hint: the waitress knew exactly what I meant when I asked about agedashi tofu, hip hip hooray!), and their set up of the place is pretty neat. They had a good amount of seating for people.

Now to mention the food. I was a little hesitate especially since this place is a small joint in the Westfield mall. Boy was I wrong. I got their fried tofu as an appetizer and the premium pork ramen as my entree. My fried tofu was cooked almost like how my gma used to make it - nice and crunchy on the outside and soft and warm on the inside. A decadent bundle of pure happiness, haha. Then my ramen came, I was immediately surprised with how many slices of pork I had in my bowl. Typical ramen-yas will give you about 3-4 slices tops, however ajisen didn't cut me short. I would say I had like 7 slice minimum, thank you! Now that's what I call PREMIUM PORK RAMEN. The noodles were defiantly cooked right (not too mushy), and the broth was equally great as well. YUMMM.

My boyfriend had some pork rice dish and he devoured it before I even hit half of my ramen. He loved it. My only complaint about that was that I didn't even get a chance to ask him to try it. 

And although I am raving about this place I must say that I gave it 4 stars because I have had better flavored ramen else ware. However, The next time I am in the union square area, I will not hesitate to go to ajisen or recommend it to anyone.
author: Jayme N.

description:
It's a better than expected ramen chain in a food court. That should pretty much sum it up. If you are looking for cheap average ramen with a lot of different meat options then this place can satisfy. I have been to the one in San Mateo as well. The quality at that one is a bit better, most likely a result of not being in a very busy food court. I always enjoy the uniqueness of the somewhat unnatural (mcribish) pork ribs. Their premium pork is tasty and their chashu is actually surprisingly good. They have a nice selection of other dishes and a pretty extensive sugary sweet drink menu. 

Together we had an order of the fried tofu two combo ramens and a peach passion fruit (pretty sure that is the right one) soda.  

Broth - 2.5 (3 with spicy kick of tantan meat)
Meats & Toppings - 4
Noodles - 2
author: Luke O.

description: I know it's ramen in the mall but I don't care as it's the yummiest place to get your warm fixing! I always go for the premium pork in pork broth or the braised short ribs in pork broth. I highly recommend the boba milk tea and the honey aloe green tea. I've tried the katsu curry which was a heaping portion and came with a delicious miso slaw salad, only wish it were offered in medium and spicy choices. Prices average to about $8-10 depending on what you get. The quality and consistency are always good and my husband and I come here at least 2-3 times a month.
author: Petra S.

description:
When I hopped off BART I had time to kill, and it was to chilly out to people watch at the Cable Car Turnaround, so I wandered into the Westfield shopping center to have a snack. And snack I did.

I had an order of Goyzo they were small and tasty, in fact they were so good that I had a second order.  If this was the only thing they served, and despite the spotty service, it would be a 5 star review. But this is a Ramen shop and I did not try any noodles so I am hesitant to give them more than 3 stars.
author: Terry T.

description: The ramen named after the restaurant was bland. The pork was bland too. I don't see how this has so many stars to be honest. It's simply mall food.
author: Cyrus A.

description:
I had no idea I would be eating at a food court. Mike L and I had trouble looking for the place and finally found it inside the food court of SF Shopping Center. He has heard a lot of people raving about Ajisen Ramen so we came to give it a try. The place closes at 830pm and we arrived shortly after 810pm. Of course we got seated, of course we were rushed to order and (no surprise) forced to pay while we were still eating. No, the service had nothing to do with the two stars.

-Shoyu ramen (no green onion, extra bamboo)
-Premium Pork ramen

The ramen was horrible. 

The only thing I liked was my shoyu broth and Mike's premium pork slices. Nothing else edible. My pork slices were dry and rough, and the noodles were soggy and soft to bite. Disappointed much? Not really, I already knew what to expect when I spotted a bottle of Sriracha at a table near by. Ramen + Sriracha?? Ok..

Ajisen may be a popular chain in Asia but not so popular on my list for ramen.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Ramen and snacks are pretty good.
Though I would say the waitress are not that friendly and welcoming.
Anyway still a nice place to go after a day's exhausting shopping in Westfield.
author: Yijia W.

description:
Eating at Ajisen Ramen is like teleporting yourself to malls in Asia where young people bond over a hot steaming bowl of noodle soup. Not only it is very filling and tasty, but the prices won't drain a young student's allowance.  

DECOR:
And of course, at the malls in Asia, the decor is very important to attract these young kids. They have to be cute and cool. Ajisen's mascot is a cute Asian girl who is forever winking at you. *Wink Wink* (Okay, some people find her creepy but I think she is cute!) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=fBDSe3dw8i8YZVMgs2sSYw

SOCIAL SCENE:
Ajisen seems to attract the young crowd and Asian. (It must be the cutesy decor since we share a DNA with Hello Kitty.) And of course, pretty much every hungry mall shopper. However,  the two times I've been there I was sitting right next to mostly very young Asian kids. There were two teens who were having a lively discussion on what to order based on their budget.  They decided to order  the cheapest ramen on the menu so they had more money for shopping. I thought that was cute. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=RQfjQzHAI0VUZ239ZmOTwg

SERVICE:
Contrary to complaints of slow and lackadaisical service posted by others, the service was efficient, quick and friendly. There's a lit up menu board but you get seated first and your server will take your order. No need to go up to the counter. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=NVGwBgXGxpZIc_tsg-Pdpg

SF SHOPPING CENTER LOCATION:
What I really love about Ajisen is the convenience factor. For someone like me who uses BART as the major public transportation, it delivers me right at Ajisen. It is located at SF Shopping Center's Food Court.  I get off BART, slurp my noodles at Ajisen, walk around the mall for a little bit to burn the calories, then jump back on BART without having to step on the streets. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=s_qGZSnaEo-1GKDlNYFgLg

SIGNATURE AJISEN RAMEN:
I've have been to Ajisen twice--first time was on a cold storming day in SF. I had the Ajisen Ramen with pork based broth, meat and veggies.  The broth was very "creamy," pork-y, flavorful and nice. I did not eat the thin pork slices but I heard a young person right next to me saying to her gf in between slurps, "I like the meat. It's good!" http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=A7OLCpZJpeiTJh1apouI5Q

VEGGIE RAMEN:
Last Friday, on a super gorgeous day in SF, I came here again  after shopping in SF. Since my guy is working a little later I decided to not go home yet. Although the weather was warm and sunny,  I had the Veggie Ramen. This was a pretty and colorful bowl. The shoyu broth was lighter than the pork-based one but very nice and flavorful. It was loaded with veggies including shitake mushroom that added a nice earthy flavor to the ramen experience. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2WImgWUXjKq0OKhu9hWhOA?select=kV5G0FijV-PqnPZV4cFF3A

LOWDOWN:
Contrary to some of the reviews that the ramen at Ajisen is bland and lacking in flavor, I found the soup to be flavorful,  comforting and filling --just like how a bowl of soup should be.  The noodles are okay; neither soggy or chewy.

PORTIONS: The portions are generous and enough to satisfy your hunger. 

SNACKS: Ajisen also sells apps like gyoza, fried tofu, etc. and rice plates like eel, pork katsu,  etc They also sell flavored iced teas and bobbas. I had the Mango Iced Tea ($3.50) with my veggie ramen and it was refreshing. 

PRICES:  About $8.99 to $9.99 per bowl. A little bit more expensive than pho, but very reasonable for the portions, IMO.
author: Leah E.

description:
The food here is actually decent for mall Asian food! It's a nice change from the typical Panda Express everywhere. The prices are also reasonable and the wait for a table isn't very long. 

I tried a ramen dish and a California roll. Both of them were good and satisfying. I also had a boba milk tea and it was good. How convenient! I love having the option to order boba without having to trek it all the way to Chinatown. I'd definitely recommend this place if you're looking for an affordable sit down lunch option downtown. 

The only thing that turned me off was the rude waitress. She spent several minutes loudly reprimanding a foreign couple for leaving a bad tip and lecturing them on American tipping customs. I'm sure it's upsetting to get a bad tip but tipping isn't even customary in other countries. I felt pretty bad for the couple. They actually sat back down to redo their check after that public verbal beatdown. How embarrassing. There really isn't even much service here anyways. They take your order, bring your food, and you're done. I actually had to ask several girls for the check before I finally got it and they didn't check in to refill water.
author: Nancy C.

description:
(See pics)

Well, can't blame the mall giving food courts a bad name (sounds like a Jovi song!) but I had been eying this place for some time but never went in til this time.

The bright colorful signs of all the noodle soup bowls and milk tea, slush, specialty style iced coffee, iced tea, I was mesmerized. Of course, as most would wander to Westfield, this side of only a few food places make it less busy and each eatery has its own seating.

The premium pork ramen was with very very delicious rich and flavorful broth, something I rarely experienced. I wish there was more pork but it's plenty of great taste noodles. I could easily have 2 bowls of those next time. This is possibly because I was used to the pricier Katana-Ya version. The beef noodle soup had a lot more meat than the first time I visited.

Beef with enoki mushroom and deep fried squids were okay.

Also got the mango slush, a perfect hot and cold experience.

They have a good number of tables and actually have a server taking orders and serving food which is very nice. Did notice they had a waiting list filled with names and figured it must be busy during certain times.

They actually stop taking customers around 8:30pm as they have to close up the shop as part of the mall rules. They did make a few exceptions but a few folks were turned away when they were already closing down the kitchen and were cleaning it. They did apologize very nicely to everyone who was turned away as well as when they had to give the check while people were still eating.

While this place has a Japanese style name and very possibly originated from a Japanese concept/owner, this branch is definitely a Chinese own place as the receipts were in Chinese. It does not make a difference to me as I am always just looking forward to great happy food. And Ajisen delivers it!
author: T L.

description: This place is tasty. I got the veggie Ramen with shoyu broth and it was delicious. The tempura mochi also hits the spot, so crispy and chewy. The service was fast, but the place is a little cramped. It doesn't bother me, but may bother some. I'm down for this anytime I bart over here.
author: Courtney A.

description: Nothing else in the food court was calling me, so I decided to try here since it was a rainy day. The wait was minimal, but there was still a line. I tried the grilled scallop ramen. Definitely got the smokey flavor and the scallop itself was good. I also enjoyed the milky broth and was happy the soup came with corn too. Not overly salty, and the service was nice and quick. I wasn't a huge fan of the noodles, but overall it was a warm and satisfying meal. And I was happy they let me carry my tea in that I had ordered from another store.
author: Veronica C.

description: Who would have thought there'd be a decent ramen place in the basement of a shopping mall? I was pleasantly surprised by this place. I really like that their broth is not too salty like the majority of ramen places. I've tried the Ajisen ramen, ABC ramen, and miso ramen. I think the Ajisen ramen is actually pretty good. The broth is the most important aspect of the ramen to me and it's pretty good. So much better than a lot of other hip, cool places I've tried lately. It's hearty and creamy but not too fatty or salty. The noodles are decent too. We ordered the fried fish last time and both kids loved it as well as the ramen. This place is pretty quick and cheap and kid friendly. I'm always in search of a good ramen place but we always come back here...
author: Linda C.

description: I'm definitely a fan of their spicy pork ramen here! The meat and broth is super flavorful, but sometimes they make it spicier than I can handle. Sometimes, they make it just perfect. The regular ajisen ramen is also very flavorful that even my mom, a non-ramen fan, loves it. Their drinks are also a huge reason why I love to come here when I'm downtown. Their honey green tea aloe drink is super yummies! I love chewing on the aloe most. This place always has a line, but it goes by pretty quick. Definitely recommend coming here if you're around.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Their Ramen not to bad, only the broth kind salty and doesn't have rich flavor in it.
it's a ok place to eat when you shopping at mall.
author: Momo G.

description: Ramen craving for lunch. Convenient (location is close to office) fast service & reasonable prices
author: tuan t.

description:
First of all, service was just fine. Prompt table service that was polite. Food came quickly after ordering, which met my expectations for a casual ramen restaurant.

I ordered the Ajisen Ramen, which is essentially the pork broth (tonkotsu) ramen with a different topping set. I also did a side of gyoza. Ramen appearance was decent. Nothing interesting here: cabbage, 3 slices chashu pork belly (round format), hard boiled egg, some scallions. Pork broth was smooth and enjoyable (I really liked it!), but the base sauce (tare) was far too mild and contributed little to the bowl. The tare should support a great pork broth and add dimension to the flavor of the soup, but this did neither. Oil amounts and flavor were nothing special. Noodles were cooked to a satisfying firmness with nothing that particularly stood out. Chashu pork was far too dry but had decent softness. Flavor of chashu was just fine. Gyoza was not bad. Both ramen and gyoza served at a great temperature.

I was tempted to do 2 stars, but I guess 3 would be more appropriate, considering how overwhelmingly average and boring this ramen was.
author: W. P.

description:
How did Ajisen make it to up north?

I was surprised to see an Ajisen in a mall, despite the fact that it's not really mall food, and that there isn't a lot of Asian shops around, but lots of Asian people who need their fixin' of ramen.

Comparing to my earlier trip to an actual ramen shop (Katana-Ya), the ramen selection did have more toppings, but the ramen was lacking something. Possibly it was overcooked, or there wasn't any seasoning when the noodles were boiled, but something wasn't there.

Comparing to branches in SoCal, this branch is FAR better than Temple City and about the same with San Gabriel. At least you don't have to worry about parking at this place.

Closing up, this place is a nice reminder of how much I missed home, but I can do without coming here.
author: Tom T.

description: I'm always a fan of ramen! The broth, noodles, and ingredients are never too salty or over done. The service is quite fast and polite. Reasonable prices for what you get. I haven't tried other ramen places in the area but I'd say this one is pretty good!
author: A W.

description:
I would like to die...

(a) in my sleep
(b) at age 105
(c)  with a belly full of carbs, salty broth and pork, in my sleep at age 105.

This place is the bomb - the salty-pork-noodle-soup bomb.  

For fast, quick and dirty mall ramen, it's actually quite edible if you've calibrated your expectations and blood pressure meds to match.  

You can order to go at the counter... But if you want to sit inside, you must sit your butt down and wait for somebody to acknowledge you and take your order, which is annoying.  It's even more annoying if you've already waited in line behind other people to place your order, only to be told to go sit down and wait for a server.

Waiting for your bill is also inefficient, especially if you're staring down a time crunch.  Do yourself a favor and ask for the check with your order. 

Hydrate, hydrate, hydrate and take Tylenol before bed, unless you want to wake up at 3am, terribly parched with a sodium-induced migraine.

Ramen, "I wish I knew how to quit you..."
author: Kim D.

description:
2.5
we were hungry and in a time crunch before having to catch a bart train.. went here for convenience before they closed up shop for the night

ordered:
-premium pork ramen: it wasn't bad but not amazing either

i'd rather go to other places in the area for ramen.. you should too!
author: Raquel T.

description:
Ahhh! I ordered the spicy pork ramen. It was spicy and super dee dooper yummy goodness! I will be coming back for some of the ramen again.

The bad part: it's in the mall i have never seen basically restaurant with waiter service in the mall, in the food court and it's expensive out total came out to 21 something for 2 bowl of ramen. It was $8 something each.

the waitress is also the host who seats people. But she was nice. Other than that no complaints except how expensive it is.
author: Anna P.

description:
I recently had ramen at Ippudo in NY and came back home wanting nothing else but. 

I love Ramen Dojo in San Mateo but i hate to drive all the way there, then wait an hour. The constant crave of ramen continues. I was skeptical to eat a ramen place in a mall; and a chain at that. But it's actually not bad! I had very low expectations but I would def eat here again. The usual order: BBQ pork with corn ramen (minus the cabbage; way too much in there for me). Mediocre but an easy quick fix for my cravings. 

The service is not that great-- but like I said, my expectations were very low. I don't care so much once I get my bowl.
author: Rosalee C.

description: Came in on a whim since it was close to the Bart station and I felt like eating some ramen. I ordered the Premium Pork Ramen & some fried chicken. There's really nothing premium about the pork other than it's lean pork and they really cheap out on the amount they give you, perhaps it's because I was there close to closing time. Either way it was dissapointing. The broth definately has MSG in it and the flavor is alright, nothing comparable to the real deal in Japan. For mall food I guess it isn't terrible but it also isn't anything amazing. The fried chicken however was decent, but on the pricey side nearly 5 bucks for a tiny and i mean TINY plate of fried chicken. So would I go there again? Nope..
author: Jini Y.

description:
My homegirl (who is addicted to ramen) and I have been here quite a few times already. Their food is better than most of the choices at the mall and sometimes when the mall is packed, you have to wait for a table. The restaurant is clean and the servers are very timid but nice. The food is served pretty quickly, so it's perfect if you want a fast sit-down meal.  They carry other items as well.  I tried their potstickers and those were decent but not the best.  I really just go here for the ramen.  

The ramen is quite expensive for a fast-food establishment, so it is safe to say that this place is not for people who are on a "ramen budget".  I really like the sesame sprinkles they provide with their noodles so I douse my ramen with sesame whenever I can. I like the texture and taste of the noodles and it is not too soggy or soft when compared to noodles you get from other establishments.  The ramen really sucks up the flavor of the soup. The meat is always tender and flavorful. The broth has that savory umami flavor that I really enjoy and it is not too salty. The serving size is pretty big so it's really hard to finish one bowl. Sometimes I end up taking half of my order home if I'm not being a littly piggy.
author: Shirleyanne A.

description:
I've enjoyed many a decent meal at Ajisen Ramen in Singapore, and so I naturally expected similar at their San Francisco outlet in the Westfield Mall. Now I realize this is a chain restaurant in the center of a mall food court, but I guess I still had high hopes. 

Well, I was disappointed.  I ordered the standard Ajisen ramen:  noodles and meat were decent, the soup incredibly salty.  I must have had four tall glasses of water in the span of our 25 minute meal!  My friend felt the same way about her miso ramen, and she also mentioned that her flavored iced tea was syrupy sweet and didn't finish that either. 

In conclusion, no thanks. Next time if craving ramen, I'll head over to Katana-Ya instead.
author: Joanne G.

description:
******************* REVIEW 461 *************************

          Ajisen Ramen shop located ont he basement floor on San Francisco Shopping Mall. This mall has 6 floors total! It's a good place to swing by when you are shopping and it's raining outside. A quick ramen soup fix is good!

         Ajisen Ramen has shops all over Los Angeles and Orange County where I first tried it, but I was surprised to see one here in San Francisco.

         They offer take out & dining in. Their ramen menu is extensive. I like the broth, tasty & flavorful but at the same time it's rich, fattening as well! 

- Tender Pork Ribs Ramen
- Seafood Ramen
- Assorted Vegetable Ramen       
- Miso Ramen With BBQ Pork
- Corn With BBQ Pork Ramen
- Ajisen Spicy Pork Ramen - love this, add on corns for extra $1.50! However, I couldn't finish the bowl myself.
- Ajisen Ramen
- Premium Pork Ramen
- Spicy Beef Ramen
- Shoyu Ramen
- Beef Curry Ramen 
- Beef Ramen 

          Beside ramen, they also offer rice dishes with BBQ pork, beef, grilled fishes and veggies.  Their snacks menu is good as well with 

- Beef Enoki Roll
- Fried Tofu
- Seaweed Salad
- Croquette
- Pork Cutlet
- Fried Calamari
- Baby Octopus - love this snack here!
- Baked Eel - good. 
- Gyoza Dumplings

          Their juices & teas selections are great too. I like the Mango juice the best! All ramen and luncch dishes are around under $10, juices is under $3. Service is quick here. The bring bill to your table and do except credit card.
author: Manda Bear B.

description: Came around 2:30pm on a Saturday and it was slightly busy. I had a group of four and we had to wait longer than half an hour to be seated. They let groups of two go ahead of us many times when seats opened when they could have put those tables together. Once seated it also took a while to get our orders taken and receive our food. Thankfully the ramen was so delicious that we ate fast and I wasn't late to work after all.
author: Sandy N.

description: Great ramen! Absolutely love this place, very fulfilling and flavorful, the tapioca tea was really good too as well as the appetizers! Will have to come back here any time I'm in the area! Highly recommended :]
author: Rose C.

description:
Date/Time: Friday - 6:45pm
Occasion: Hungry for dinner  
Party of:  2
Ordered: Premium pork ramen & Chicken ramen  
Total: $24

Having traveled to Japan several times and dine at some of the most popular ramen houses in the Bay Area, LA, & NYC, I consider myself a somewhat expert at this bowl of soup.

First of, a great bowl of ramen must have fulfill two key criteria -- noodle & rich/flavorful broth. Sadly, this place missed out  on 1 of 2. 

The noodles at Ajisen were straight and thin, made in the Hakata style; it lacked the firm chewiness. My fav ramen noodles are the yellow, wavy and have just the right diameter, which makes for a substantial noodle that has the perfect chew.

The broth at Ajisen was delicious! It was flavorful, rich, and was somewhat fatty; the way good ramen is suppose to be. Yum!
author: Anh N.

description:
I'd recommend the veggie, pork ribs, and spicy beef ramens.  The meat ramens are super super meat-heavy, and very light on veggies. But the service is shockingly good (mall or no mall) so they'll hook you up with more veggies if you ask for it.

Tasty, big portions, with quick and attentive service. I'm all sorts of pleased...and visibly rolly polly.
author: Teresa Z.

description:
Very interesting place to have a "please wait to be seated" sign at a mall. While I do like being served at the table, I'm somewhat more used to just ordering at the counter and bringing the food to the table. 

I might have a certain preference for the type of ramen served. I really like the curly kind and it must be al dente because I'm a real picky eater when it comes to ramen. This is more of a spaghetti type of noodles in broth. I had the miso with bbq pork and my friend had the premium pork. Mine came with egg but his didn't. Hm... that's kinda questionable since he paid more for his. 3 stars for the pork, broth, and flavor. The jury is still out on the noodles.
author: Tim G.

description:
Tried the Ajisen Best Combo Ramen at the Westfield Mall and OMG, it was absolutely delicious! Full of yummy pork and pork belly in a light, savory broth, it was an incredible lunch and I'm definitely coming back for more!

Wasn't expecting such a yummy meal at the mall, but hey- I do love surprises!
author: Lucy C.

description: I tried the to tonkatsu ramen and thought it was okay. Then I saw the warning. Great. Well, we didn't get sick last night. Glad we didn't go back for seconds.
author: H C.

description:
For the most part, I really like this place.

For a spot on the bottom floor of the mall, it's pretty good.  The quality of the ramen and soup base exceeds my expectations for anything in the food court area.  I have not tried any of the rice dishes yet, but I'm sure those are pretty good as well.  The only drink I have ordered from here is the milk tea which is pretty standard.  

If you come here during the first hour of opening, be prepared not to be able to order any of the appetizers/snacks.  Usually you will have to wait a bit for that.  The busiest times from experience is between 12-2PM.  Although, the wait shouldn't be all that long.

The service for the most part is really good.  

One of the better choices in the mall.
author: Bernie C.

description:
Deserving of its 3 star rating. For mall ramen, you can't complain. It's no Ramen Dojo or the other 4 star ramen spots in the Bay Area, but it'll do if you want a quick fix. All the bowls are around $9-11 and they have a ton of selection.

The three meat combo bowl was solid. I enjoyed the meat, all three types of pork, chicken and beef were tender and juicy. The noodles were average as well. The problem is the broth was too plain. I doubt they made it overnight or used a special chef's recipe. Not bad.

The spicy pork bowl was slightly better, 3.5 stars. The broth was spicy and salty the way I like it and the pork cha shu done well. I'd get that next time.

Service is poor, though it is a mall.
author: Chuck N.

description:
This is a decent ramen place, especially since it is located inside the mall.  Nothing amazing, but not bad either.  It satisfies my craving, the waiters are nice, and the service is fast.  If there is no wait, I would defiantly come here.  But, it's not worth my time if I had to put my name on a waiting list.

I ordered the Miso Ramen, which I thought was okay.  I've had the Premium Pork, which I thought was way better.  I also got to try a bite of the Spicy Beef Stew Ramen, which I thought tasted really good.  I'll defiantly be getting that for my next order.

The tables in the middle are a little awkwardly close to the next table.
author: Lynn L.

description:
I first ate at Ajisen in Hong Kong in 2003. It was a convenient place for a snack that wasn't too expensive and it was pretty speedy. Haha. I remember it being tasty at the time. The beef wrapped enoki and curry katsu noodles were things that I liked. 

I believe Ajisen opened up in Fremont a couple years ago, but I've never made it down there. Imagine my surprise when I saw it at the Westfield food court.

I ordered a butter corn ramen ... and I have to say, what the hell happened? The Ajisen in Hong Kong is pretty good. But the one in SF... oh god, where do I begin?  The ramen soup base was chock full of MSG. It did not have the depth of a good ramen broth. The broth was just salty from MSG, gross. The pork was also fatty and not very good tasting. Um.. 

The price also was not cheap considering the quality of the ramen. I think it was around $8.50 or $9? I forget... the bowl is also kinda small too if that matters. I don't eat much, so it was more than enough for me... but it might not be for bigger eaters.

This place ranks 2//10 on a worldwide scale, especially since this is a chain. Would I come here again? Maybe if I was really desperate and about to faint from hunger. But I think I'd rather have fish and chips at the other food court for $5.50 instead. :P
author: michelle l.

description:
Good for a quick ramen fix in the mall if you'd rather not wait for Katana-Ya a few blocks away. Service is relatively quick and nice/professional, but depends who's working. Some of the servers (younger ones) don't have a clue what they are doing while others even take away the straw wrappers off your table and check on you once in a while. They do have a variety of ramen (with pictures) and tapioca drinks on their menu.

- Spicy Pork Ramen: spicy, pork is OK and i like the ground up pork along with the sliced pork, noodles not firm or dense enough, but it's a good size bowl of noodles
- Spicy Beef Ramen: spicy, big pieces of overcooked beef, overall OK
author: Linda C.

description:
Hands down, pound-for-pound, bar none, Ajisen is the best ramen in SF that I've ever tasted.  Don't listen to the other high-maintenance chickenheads knockin' this place with 1-3 stars.  The only thing is it's in the mall, all the way downstairs.  But definitely try the tenderous rib and roast pork ramen.

I've been to Halu, Hotei, Genki, Tanpopo, Izakaya, Mifune, and all the other ones in fuckin' Japan Town and believe me Ajisen got these places beat in terms of flavor, portion, and service.

Try it.  If you don't like it, I'll pay for it, fuck it...email me your receipt.
author: John E.

description: premium pork ramen is amazing and my goto... wish it came with an egg
author: Jonol S.

description:
Ajisen ramen has a simple decor of magnified japanese kanju and chinese characters on the wall.  at the entrance,  a smiling,  cartoonish japanese girl holding a bowl of ramen oversees incoming guests.

menu: ramen, appetitizers, boba drinks, tea

sampling:
-curry rice with fried chicken aka karaage(8.50)
curry mostly mild/bland with some spiciness. mixed with tender potatos and carrots.
*cole slaw salad with dressing: fresh tasting
*pickled veggies, ok
chicken was tender, moist, almost juicy,not overfried, light brown in colour
-curry rating 3, chicken kaarange 3.5 (tender but no flavor).

temaki:
-typical friendly japanese greeting upon arrival and courteous "thank you" upon departure
-menu items are set. no adding toppings, (boiled egg, corn, bamboo, chashu, etc)
-clean dining area,  seating 40ish, bench or tables. standing room with counters outside ajisen.
-fast food environment.
-service friendlier than fremont (server was chinese).
-no waiting prenoon.
author: Victor G.

description: If I could give a zero I would, I'm huge on service almost as much as I'd like a delicious meal, if the service is bad the meal itself will be an after thought. That being said my experience with service here usually was alright but today I was told after ordering  at my table then deciding I want it to go, that I was no longer allowed to remain seated at my table and I'd need to get up to wait. I think they think that because they are located in a mall, granted a busy location, that that somehow means that you do not extend the smallest of curtesy to a paying customer. I promptly took my partners suggestion and left. Save yourself the trouble and pay the same price for better service elsewhere.
author: Johnny H.

description: Literally just came from eating here. I was craving ramen bad so decided to try this place based on convenience. I got the volcano ramen, level of spice was moderate not too hot. They don't use ramen noodles more like spaghetti. Does it take longer to cook? Haha because I find that weird. Broth was rich and enjoyable. The bowl was accompanied by only cabbage and egg.  For some mall ramen it's alright. Would only come back here if I was craving it since its on the way home from work.
author: Leanne E.

description:
We finally had the chance to visit Ajisen after hearing so many people rave about how good it is here. We came on a Saturday afternoon and only had to wait about 5 minutes for a table of 2. This is a place where people sit, order and leave- not much chitchatting going around.

Their menu is quite simple so it didnt take me long to order. We both got ramen and enjoyed the broth, but not the noodles. I will have to agree with Christine C. and Lolia S. that it was definitely lacking the firm texture and just didnt seem right.
author: M W.

description:
Came here few times already, since I work at downtown!  It's a cute, trendy ramen place compared to the others ramen restaurant in SF. Anyway you could not compare it to the one in HK, HK always has best food.  

The ramen, soup base and snack are average! I always order beef ramen, it was prertty good, YUMMY!  But my friend ordered spicy beef ramen, she said it was tooooo spicy. I had it before, but this time seems over spicy, we are trying to mix the spicy soup and  my regular soup to make it less spicy.  So if you can't eat spicy, DO NOT order spicy soup base!!!

I like some of their snack too: beef mushroom roll, tofu, fried chicken.....

Will come here again when I miss "Ajisen Ramen" !!!!!!
author: Lam K.

description:
This location is in the mall but not in the food court so it doesn't get very crowded.
I ordered the miso ramen but I didn't taste much miso in there.  The ramen noodles were great though - perfect texture and consistency.
California rolls were pretty blah.
author: Michele S.

description:
Not too bad. 

Went to the chain in China and it was basically the same experience. 

Ramen wasn't too bad, noodles were a little too spaghetti-ish but it didn't take much away. Broth was not too bad. For a fast joint, this place has it down (other than the seating system, which is bananas around lunch). Also had the octopus salad and it was awesome. The US needs more fast, good ramen joints.
author: Shane A.

description: 2.5 stars. Decent bowl of ramen despite being on the bottom floor of a mall. It's a chain and I've had it down in socal before so it made me feel better about eating ramen at the mall. Service was a little slow, and it seemed silly to have to wait to be seated since there were so many open tables. I guess they're trying to make it feel more like a real restaurant, but come on. You're next to the food court! Spicy pork was pretty spicy, though it tasted a little like the spice was covering up a lacking broth.
author: Kathy L.

description: I wanted to try it out since I love their San Mateo location. It's very different, their ramen is bland, it looks like they use angel hair noodles, and they don't have many rice dishes or fried rice but can't blame them since they are inside a mall.
author: Vany P.

description: It's a food court ramen place... not horrible by any means. Pork was very tender, but also pretty fatty. Broth could have had some more depth. Service was very kind and quick.
author: Shanna S.

description:
If you don't want over priced food from chain restaurants (yes this is a chain), don't eat at mall food courts.  

That being said, I ordered the chicken ramen to-go.  Needed to refuel after a retail therapy session. 

Ambiance was....well...a food court.  Service was very fast.  Broth was packaged separately.  Came with broth, chicken breast, cabbage, green onion and noodle. Very simple for $8.95 pre-tax.

Overall it was pretty decent.  The broth was tasty, the noodles were quite nice, cabbage reduced the guilt factor.  The chicken was moist and tender, though obviously had contact with some sort of meat tenderizing product.  It really would be three stars if I could have stomached the weird textured chicken...but sorry Ajisen...that Chicken is gross...

Overall, mission instant comfort food--Completed!  I'd still take this over a Big Mac any day!
author: Susan C.

description: I was there with my friend for the first time. There was lots of people on the list before us, but it took about 10 minutes for us to be seated. The waitress is a friend of my friend's, and when I said "idk what to order!" she asked me if I like spicy food. I said hell yeah! So she recommended the volcano ramen(?) and it was awesome! I like the spiciness! It was just right for me! I really liked the broth and the ramen noodles! If I were to go back, I'm gonna order the same ramen!
author: Howie J.

description:
I've gotten the sparerib ramen a few times. The broth is not too salty and the pork ribs are sooooo tender and delicious.  It's super flavorful.  I love it.

The food comes out very fast. Only downside is they don't serve hot tea.

The broth is pretty good, I wouldn't say it's top of the line but definitely one of the better food court choices EVER!

Would come back.

However the bowl is expensive but so is everything else in SF.
author: Joanne L.

description:
Solid 3.5. This ramen house is on the lower level of the San Francisco Shopping Center, between Chipotle and Panda Express. There is line infront, but don't be tricked. There is actually sign-in sheet. Make sure you sign-in, before you start waiting in-line. 

There were four 2 person tables infront and one 5 person group. And the wait was about 20 minutes for the Wednesday night around 7PM (day after Christmas). 

I was mildy surprised at how fast I ordered and got the food. It was FAST. Probably got my noodle in 6-8 minutes or ordering.

We ordered:
* Spicy Beef Ramen ~$9 (3 of 5) - Tasty, but the spiciness tasted very powdery. The spiciness reminded me of an instant noodle packet's hot spicy powder. It wasn't that great. It wasn't that hot and tasted a bit chalky. The beef chunks were tasty and very tender. But I would put a pass on this next time.
* Ajisen Best Combo Ramen ~$10 (4 of 5) - Really liked their Hokkaido white ramen soup base. I was so surprised I liked it that much. It was flavorful. I could taste the white broth and minced garlic infused in the soup. It actually complimented the noodle and meats very well. I don't have complaint about the texture of the noodle, it was neither a wow or a nay. I do wish it was a little curlier, it is rather straight looking like a spaghetti. I figure there was a lot of MSG, but it was pretty delicious. At the end of the night, I didn't overdrink water, so maybe, this place doesn't overuse MSG. One can hope.

For the cafe version of ramen, this place was pretty yummy, especially the Ajisen Best Combo Ramen. I would go back when feeling tired of shopping and needing to rest and filling the stomache with a hardy hot bowl of ramen at SFC. This place takes credit cards and serves ramen TO GO.
author: Janice T.

description:
We stopped here on black Friday. I was hungry and exhausted and my only comfort was noodles. 

It took awhile to get seated..but I thought the food was pretty good. 
The ramen tasted fresh..and I enjoyed the broth. The fried squid was probably my favorite. 

I am not a fan of spots in a food court set up..but would overlook it just for the good ramen.
author: Mimi T.

description: Been here twice and both times left satisfied. The combo ramen is very tasty, as well as the dragon roll.  The service is quick and attentive and the prices are pretty cheap.
author: David T.

description:
Why go here?
It's in Westfield downtown. Very convenient location. The food is great. 

What to order?
1) Hot ramens are good. Ajisen combo or spicy pork are my defauls. I tried the cold one once but didn't like it that much.
2) Gyoza is a must. (4 pieces/order)

One thing that keeps me from going here?
The queue can be long during busy hours. (for example, Friday evening or weekends) but the queue moves quite ok.
author: Krist W.

description: Got seated 15 minutes before closing and I'm glad we did! Been searching for good ramen since we hit an amazing spot in Hawaii, and though I'll still be searching, this restaurant was pretty good. We got a combo ramen and curry pork cutlet dish. The ramen had a good broth, and while the beef was tasty there was more fat on it than I would have liked. The noodles were firm, and softened only a little bit while sitting in the broth. The curry was delicious and the serving much larger than pictured on the standing menu outside. Score! Leftovers for me! Would definitely come back here the next time I'm at Westfield shopping it up! :)
author: Meryl C.

description:
I am a ramen snob. My favorite bay area ramen joint is Orenchi, and I've been to Ippudo and Hide-chan in New York, Toki Underground and Daikaya in DC. In SF proper I think Kirimachi is okay but I am still searching for a decent bowl that doesn't require a trek to North Beach.

Ajisen was bad. I ordered the deluxe pork bowl. The broth, despite being milky in appearance, was watery and flavorless and was missing the cloudy appearance of really good tonkotsu broth. I added an egg which was marinated but overcooked. The chashu was just thinly sliced pork loin, no flavor or fat. I had to squirt in some sriracha to get some semblance of flavor to no avail.

Service was aloof. Despite the restaurant not being very busy, I had to flag down a server to get attention.
author: Albert Y.

description: Love vocano and dandan noodle, love the milk tea. Good service, good price.
author: Fiona L.

description:
It is in the food court area on the Nordstrom side of the mall. 

Quick service, good portions, reasonable prices.

Corn and Pork Ramen: Really yummy. Broth was amazing and pork was tender.
Miso Ramen: If you like a more creamy broth, get this one!

**Ask for the Chili Powder if you like that because they don't give it to you right away.
author: Amy Y.

description:
I actually come here for their Honey Aloe Green Tea the most. It's one of the most refreshing drinks around, and it's simply so conveniently placed because I can't seem to find an alternative in downtown! (No other boba/aloe/tea places nearby).

The ramen here is good and is definitely my goto place for lunch in SF downtown. Not the absolutely best ramen in the world, but it's worth what you pay for!

Had the scallops ramen today, which was pretty good. Stole some of my friend's spicy pork ramen broth, which was better.
author: Bijun A L.

description:
I LOVE this place. Definitely suggest the premium pork ramen. Its delicious and the pork is thin but its very tender and yummy. The soup has loads of flavor and is way better than other ramen dishes I've tried. The price is decent and the service is great too.

There's a gentlemen in particular who gets you seated and takes your order but i don't believe he brings your order other than the drinks but whatever. He's super kind and would come by to ask if everything is alright. Always smiling and super nice. The waiter/waitresses are great too depending on who they are. Always greeting you with a smile and ask you if you are finished before taking the bowl/plates away. 

What I DON'T suggest is the sushi. The sushi there is disgusting. I got the dragon roll and will never get it again. It was basically a california roll with whatever it was on top and the sushi was not your typical small little bite sized sushis.. The rice was about half an inch thick and there is no way for you to shove that shit in your mouth in a bite or even 2 bites. Overall the sushi was terrible. Mind as well splatter rice and crab meat on a plate and serve it as a rice bowl or something. 

But the drinks are really good! I tried their flavored sodas? I forgot the name but it had peach in it... heh. The green apple slush was lovely. It was so soft and full of flavor and wasn't sour. 

Will definitely come back for more ramen n__n.
author: Angela M.

description:
For mall ramen, it's good but not exciting.  Someone comes to take your order - yet it looks like a quick service restaurant.  The menu has pictures of about 14 kinds of specialty ramen, including bbq pork, tender pork, spicy pork, beef curry, spicy beef, seafood, etc., rice plates, appetizers  I didn't see a list of ramen toppings (to add on if desired).  They had drinks like milk tea (with boba if desired), fruit slushes, and flavored ice tea.  The kimchee ramen is pictured but unavailable.

* Premium pork ramen ($8.75): The best part was the extra thin, tender, fatty Kumamoto pork but it felt like there was too much of it (guess I'm used to getting one or two slices in my ramen) and/or it would have been a better bowl of ramen with other types of toppings.  The noodles were straight and thin; they weren't mushy but they weren't firm/chewy enough either. The tonkotsu broth was milky, creamy, with pork flavor not overly salty with an average depth of flavor. A small amount of bland shredded cabbage and some scallions were also included.  The ramen just wasn't interesting enough (why just the pork) and they didn't even have the red pepper flakes that I like to add.  

* Milk tea ($2.50): Standard, nothing special, I'd rather drink water next time

The signature napkins and bowls with the ramen girl are cute.  I guess Kumamoto isn't my preferred style of ramen.  My ramen would have been much better with red pepper flakes.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I definitely wasn't expecting to find a ramen house inside the SF Westfield mall and certainly wasn't expecting it to be anything special considering, but I was delightfully surprised for the most part. 

I ordered the premium pork ramen that featured some delicious and savory thinly shaved slices of pork on top of a pile of very straight and slender ramen noodles within a cloudy, milky-white broth.  This particular bowl of ramen had three components with which to judge it by -- the noodles, the broth and the shaved pork.  Two of the components were good -- I really enjoyed the shaved premium pork slices and the broth was tasty and rich.  The ramen noodles however were much more similar to Italian angel hair pasta in appearance, texture, and even taste rather than the ramen noodles I've grown accustomed to at such places as Katana-Ya, Ramen Dojo and the like.
author: Erich D.

description:
Aji-sen fulfills the quick fix need for a bowl/plate of noodles.  The apps here are so/so and it can get crowded.  When it does get crowded, you can expect to wait.  Also, have had an order get mixed up with another table (the staff corrected it, so no worries).  The quality is decent and the price is moderate.  Yet, they are not claiming to be "gourmet" ramen and I can respect that.

Also, glad that they offer buckwheat (soba) noodles.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
Tonkotsu broth is pretty good.  Lacking a little salt, which I think is due to the lack of the the braising liquid of the pork, which is usually added to the bottom of the bowl.  It has the more classic noodles for tonkotsu, which should remind most people of a paitan ramen, or a Chinese noodle soup.  I also had the fried chicken.  It was their take of karaage, which again could have used more salt, but I did like the addition of lemon and kewpie mayo which reminded me of some places in Japan.

THE LOW DOWN
- I would come here over any other place in westfield mall for lunch.
- Not the best I have had, *The best being a place called Ippudo in Japan and I think New York*, but it was satisfying.
- If you haven't tried it give it a shot.
- Broth could use some umph, so some shoyu *soy sauce* could  be added to those who are used to salty foods.


PS. As I was walking out, someone ordered the katsu curry which looked AWESOME.  I will have to try that next time.
author: Andrew A.

description: On a chilly SF day,  I enjoyed ramen with two co-workers.  Got here at around 11:35 am. Got seated in the back and the menus were presented to us.  We ordered fried chicken with ramen,   Tonkatsu  with ramen, and the special Ajitsen ramen.  Miso flavor in my ramen soup was quite flavorful. I used the soup spoon to drink down the broth.   Finished my entire bowl and now ready to get back to my afternoon projects. Efficient, fast, and no nonsense establishment.  In and out in about 45 minutes.
author: E. C.

description: I'm glad I found Ajisen Ramen in SF. I ordered a spicy pork ramen and it was delicious!!! Pork was very tender and tasty. The pork broth was well flavor and right amount of heat. Definitely falls under my comfort food list.
author: Becky K.

description:
I heard that this place is super popular in Asia and was excited to get a Ramen place within walking distance of my workplace.  The first time I went, I had the chicken ramen.  The second time I went, I took the advice of friends and got the spicy pork ramen.  I'd have to say that I was very satisfied after both visits.

I haven't had any trouble getting seated - it's kind of weird going to a ramen place in the mall that seats you like a real restaurant, but they are very efficient at it and handled big groups well the both times I was there.  I wanted to drink the bowl of broth each times I ate here - they give you a lot of ramen and a lot of meat, especially in the chicken ramen bowl.  The next time I come, I am going to get the Premium Pork Ramen as I've heard great things about it.

I wish I could compare it to other ramen places but i haven't tried Katanaya yet - however one of the friends I came here with the 2nd time said that it is way better than Katanaya.
author: Sonya T.

description:
Update:  After I wrote this review the waitress sent me a private message apologizing and saying that she went to her manager and explained what happened.  She was far adamant that she did not get in trouble with management about the incident, and that they didn't ask her to respond to me.  She sent me the message LITERALLY that day.  In my opinion, it seems like someone in management reads the reviews and makes the staff respond.  This poor girl sounded terrified and coerced.  I feel bad that she may be punished for my review, but the experience solidified for me the feeling that these business owners are not good people.  Another "Yelper" privately commented to me a couple of days later that "this must have been a mistake and an isolated incident".  Ummmmm nope.  I doubt it.  

Original review:  

RARELY, if EVER, do I not leave a tip.  But this was ridiculous.  

Let me start by saying that given the time and effort people put into writing reviews, I'm offended when a company hasn't claimed their listing and joined the conversation - show your customers that you care what they are saying.  Ajisen hasn't claimed this listing, which indicates to me that they don't give a shit what people are saying.  Shame on them.  Quite honestly, I used to sell advertising at Yelp, and Ajisen was a prospect of mine.  They never answered calls and I couldn't even get in touch with anyone at their corporate office.  That is, until they wanted to complain about bad reviews, and then they were lighting up my phone.  Yet they don't care enough to claim the listing and actually respond to reviews.  

So my experience today.  I went with a friend for lunch.  She ordered a Ramen soup dish, and I ordered the cold soba noodle salad, which comes with tofu.  I asked the server if I could have the tofu fried (Who really likes a slab of raw tofu?  Not me), and she said yes and walked away.  When the dish came, it was a slab of raw tofu.  No biggie - I mentioned it, and the guy serving it (waitress was right behind him) says it comes like this.  I stated that the waitress said I could substitute it, and she responded that she thought I was ordering the fried tofu appetizer.  Um....really?  Because you're delivering my dish, and I don't see fried tofu appetizer on my table.  She asked if I still wanted it though, and I said yes.  Okay.  No big deal.  It's $1.95 extra - I can afford that.  10 minutes later she comes back over to the table and asks again if I still want the fried tofu.  Yes Please (I'm getting confused here, but still calm).  Then, as she is turning around and walking away she mumbles "Okay, I'll go place that order".  WHAT?!?!  Seriously?  But now she's walked away and doesn't look at me again until another 10 minutes later when she puts it on the table.  

At this point I had two choices.  1. Ask for the manager and explain what happened, and maybe not pay for the extra tofu.  2. Just don't tip her.  By this time so much time as elapsed that I had to get back to my office - I had a meeting.  So I made sure my friend was comfortable not leaving a tip, and we paid the bill and left.  No tip.  

It's unfortunate.  If management is reading reviews, I am always happy to give a business a second chance (1 star reviews are not something I like to give - I realize it can affect business).  I am always appreciative of  a response to my reviews, and usually update my reviews accordingly.  So claim your listing and start listening to your customers.  For now, I won't be going back to Ajisen, which is unfortunate because they are so close to my office.
author: Cori D.

description: This is the closest and reasonably priced ramen joint I could find near my work. I usually come here during lunch time and it always have a long line of people waiting. I usually order the premium pork ramen. I have tried that so far and the broth is very good with flavors. It is not salty, just about right on the salt. Of course you cannot compare it to Orenchi or places like that, but this will satisfy my ramen craving on weekdays.
author: Elaine C.

description: I came to this place with my friend, I ordered the pork ramen and she ordered the chicken ramen. (Supposedly comes with fried chicken). By the time we were halfway done with our ramen, the chicken came. It took forever for a small dish tray of chicken. And when we paid our bill, we paid the usual tip for lunch, and they pretty much chased us down saying it wasn't enough. It even was on the bill. They calculated it for us and we also did the math ourselves to check if everything was correct. My pork ramen was decent, which is why I'm giving two stars.
author: Katie F.

description:
I gave them three stars in my previous review, but alas, I think today was probably the last day I'll ever go here. Granted, I wasn't really in the best mood, but it irked me so much.

So, my bill came out to $8.65. I gave them $20. Waitress picks it up and when it came back, it had only $1 in change--not the $11.35 I was supposed to get back. So I went up to the waitress and told her I gave her a twenty. She apologized and took back the checkbook.

Now this time, I got $11 back--but still without the remaining 35 cents. I was in a hurry because I was supposed to meet up with a friend at the movies, so I just grabbed $10 and left, leaving a dollar for tip (though $1.35 really, had they given me the correct change). I honestly don't even think they deserve that dollar.

If it happens once, it won't bother me, but if you're still coming short on the change that I was supposed to have after I brought up your mistake? I think you're being shady as hell. So either gurl couldn't do math to save her life, or they're skimming off the top from a customer's change--whichever it is, I get that being in the service industry sucks and tips help a lot when it comes to the paycheck, but even a penny counts when it comes to honesty. So nope, never coming back.
author: Sylvia S.

description: If you are craving ramen and are shopping in the mall, it's not half bad . It's okay for mall food so just grab some if you in the area and want some ramen!!
author: Jeffrey L.

description: It's good enough to give you a ramen fix if you are craving for it. I do wish they would use a different noodle. The noodle they use just doesn't have the same chewy texture as ramen should have. The soup however is pretty good.
author: Andy W.

description:
Yum!  Pretty good ramen for a food court.

Table service in a mall was interesting.  Ordered the Premium Pork, Chicken, and Volcano ramen.  Service was quick and the ramen was delicious.

The pork was amazing as was the volcano....chicken, meh.
author: Lynn P.

description:
A hardy bowl of salty, oily ramen.  

I originally wanted the kimchee ramen but they were out so I ended up with the regular pork ramen...to go.  It wasn't terrible but was definitely fast-food status.  The noodles were chewy and the broth was very flavorful but I felt extremely guilty afterwards.  The greasy broth made my lips feel like I was wearing lipgloss.  I hate when pho and ramen places put lettuce/cabbage in their ramen.  Are they trying to cheat me out of other ingredients?  *shrug.  It changes the consistency and flavors, in my opinion.  Overall, it was a filling bowl of ramen that I probably won't be coming back for.  I can't get myself to pay $8+ for below-average ramen when I can get $0.50 packaged ramen at home that tastes alot better.

Maybe I'm just really picky with my noodles/ramen.  Although the wait was a bit long, everyone looked like they were working as quickly as they could and were friendly.  In the end, though, it didn't work out for me.
author: Kat C.

description:
I love ramen and I work in the Westfield Center so it's a no brainer that I would check out Ajisen Ramen.  

My co-workers and I have been anxiously waiting the debut of this eatery for a couple months now, ever since we saw the demise of Steak Escape. The mall food court needed an injection of new blood badly and Ajisen Ramen might just do the trick.

Today was grand opening day and the first day jitters showed--no chili flakes for the ramen, things were a little slow to come out, waitresses were a little inefficient--but all these were minor points.

All in all the service was good--with all the staff being polite and offering service with a smile.

Now, on to the food! My co-worker and I split an order of chicken karagge and agedashi tofu--both were really good considering they were from a "fast food" ramen place. I opted for the spicy pork ramen while my colleague got the BBQ pork with corn ramen. Both were great choices! Big portions, lots of meat, and my spicy pork was just spicy enough to tickle my taste buds without having to constantly reach for my milk tea (which was the best boba I've had at this food court!).

All in all, Ajisen has quickly joined the ranks of Out The Door and Coriander as my food court favorites. I know my co-workers and I will be making many trips back to this place--I just hope we won't get tired of it. That would be a shame.
author: Tayson H.

description: Part of a larger chain, the Ajisen Ramen in Westfield Mall is slightly overpriced for an average bowl of ramen. I had the spicy pork ramen, which came with half a soft boiled egg, cabbage, spicy ground pork, and a few slices of BBQ pork. The broth was extremely flavorful, but definitely on the more oily side. I loved the spice that the ground pork added, but the slices of BBQ pork were probably more than 50% fat. The cabbage added a nice fresh crunch to the bowl, and the noodles were cooked to a good, chewy texture. Overall, it was an average bowl of ramen, especially considering the better ramen options in the vicinity.
author: Ashley T.

description: VERY LARGE PORTIONS. Quite tasty, service was just okay. I ordered a California roll and a Curry Chicken rice plate, the rice plate was much bigger than expected.
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
Ajisen is in the mall.  But in this case I'll make an exception for the mall court because Ajisen is actually pretty good.  The broth is tasty and the premium pork is sliced super thin.  If you get take away they nicely pack up the broth, noodles, and toppings separately so the noodles don't get soggy.  You have to be quick though or the noodles will stick together.  The portions are big, though not really big enough to share comfortably.  If I'm feeling like a light lunch then I'll make two meals out of it but that probably wouldn't work for most people.

Ajisen is also convenient because they take credit card and there aren't many good places to get a quick lunch around Union Square where you can get away with no cash.
author: Jean K.

description: Had the scallop ramen with veggie broth, very underwhelmed. The noodles are spaghetti, not chewy ramen! The soup had a one note flavor, and you only get 2 scallops that do not look appetizing (even though the menu says "grilled," no evidence of char). A friend had the seafood one with veggie broth as well,  and she didn't really enjoy hers either. Both were edible, but nothing to write home about.
author: Muniba A.

description: I came here on a whim after an event at Bloomingdales, I didn't want the usual Panda Express. I tried the chicken ramen, the soup was soy sauce based and pretty salty. I wasn't impressed. I felt like this was something I could make at home, and probably better.
author: Briana W.

description:
Pretty good Raman for mall food. The food was good, the staff was friendly, and their boba was fairly priced.
Like everyone else said the seating was pretty bad, but the wait was less then 10 minute so it wasn't unbearable. 
Other then that I feel like this was a great lunch place for a few friends. Not to expensive and you still get a decent quality!
author: Jade F.

description: I like it spicy so the volcano ramen with an extra piece of tender pork ribs is my usual.
author: Rachel C.

description: A little overpriced for the quality you get, but a decent place for a mall and good for a quick fix if you ever have that ramen craving. The tender pork rib ramen is probably the best bang for the buck. I will say that their milk tea (without boba) is better than average.
author: Mark L.

description: For a food court food this ramen place is awesome! Had the shoyu ramen, The best Combo ramen, dragon roll and Milk Tea! Thumbs UP!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
I was walking up to Nordstroms and Ajisen happened to catch my eye. Mmm, ramen. Why not give it a try.

The broth and the shaved pork for the premium pork ramen were okay. But the noodles were just flat out bad. They had the consistency of overcooked angel hair pasta, not ramen. 

The lettuce in the ramen was unexpected. Not something I would ever ask for, but not at all bad as you would think.
author: Cristofer P.

description: Great flavor and textures but I think they are using spaghetti instead of real ramen moodles
author: Cerraeh L.

description: I had the Seafood ramen. I couldn't finish it and it wasn't even ramen, it was spaghetti. Subpar quality.
author: Mariam S.

description:
Came here after a friend raved about this place, saying he preferred it over Katana-ya.  I was very skeptical since it was a mall ramen and sadly it didn't live up to the hype for me, but it was still decent.  

I ordered the Spicy BBQ Pork Ramen...spicy and the broth was better than average but I wasn't a fan of the noodles and that's usually what I inhale first when I eat ramen.  Noodles make the ramen!  Their fried chicken was good too...loved the sauce they serve with it.  Seemed like an aioli-type sauce.  

Just come here if you're already in the mall and starving for ramen...otherwise take time to walk to Ramen Underground
author: Jane N.
