description: It's nothing amazing, but it's relatively cheap and fast. Good ramen is hard to come by, so I do appreciate it being so accessible and available at the food court. Though in the food court, you are serviced on and expected to tip. It's spacious and you are seated immediately. There is a variety of ramen offered, though some are pretty similar. Most have barbecue pork and some others have beef. I liked the noodles. it was not soggy at all and I'm glad they erred on the side of al dente. Both the miso and tonkotsu broths tasted good, but probably because it was so salty. I don't think this place uses MSG, but I was very thirsty after eating. The barbecue pork was soft and tender. The croquettes were yummy too, but the oil could've been more fresh.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Great ramen. Delicious soup base. The tenderness of the noodles change a bit every time but compared to Ramen Underground. I pick this place. Honey aloe tea is refreshing :)

Great ramen. Delicious soup base. The tenderness of the noodles change a bit every time but compared to Ramen Underground. I pick this place. Honey aloe tea is refreshing :)
author: Tony L.

description: Not a huge fan of fatty cuts of meat, so I'm glad that they have a premium pork option. Switching from regular miso to spicy miso is an additional dollar, worth it.
author: Melissa M.

description:
So I first had Ajisen abroad in Shanghai, and omg, it was delicious. And after getting back to the States, I had a craving for it. So I dragged D here after he got off work (and since we had some time to burn).

I got the regular Ajisen and D got the Pork in Miso Soup. Mine was pretty good, it needed some of those roasted garlic flakes, but I guess they don't have that in the U.S. D didn't really enjoy his too much, I guess the miso was a bit too much. He tried my soup though and liked it a lot more. So definitely avoiding miso in the future.

I was kinda a bit taken back by the waitress. We told her we didn't want any drinks and she replied with "Not even water?" in a sassy tone. Maybe I just took it the wrong way, but definitely didn't appreciate that.

Overall, Ajisen good. and Ajisen yum.
author: Jessica H.

description:
After shopping downtown and preparing to attend an evening event at the Asian Art Museum, a friend and I decided to go here for dinner. I was surprised when I saw that it was an actual sit down restaurant in the middle of the food court.

The service is very fast paced. We got seated immediately and asked what we wanted to drink. Soon after the server came back to take our order. I wasn't exactly sure what to get, so we told her to come back in a few minutes. She came back within seconds. I decided to order the beef ramen.

The food came pretty quickly.  The noodles were good and the beef had a lot of flavor. There was also cabbage which is good because you can't forget about the vegetables. The quality of the food exceeded my expectations. However the broth was a little oily and I had to drink lots of water.

The server was rushing us out so fast that he brought over the wrong bill! They cleaned out our plates and asked if we wanted any more water before getting rid of our cups. 

It was a good experience and I'd like to go there again and try something else.
author: Doris W.

description:
If San Francisco wasn't such a weak ramen city, I wouldn't be slumming it at a basement mall food court for my fix!  For mall food, this is probably your best option.  For ramen, it pales in comparison to Tokyo or NYC but represents well for the underrepresented tonkotsu broth by San Francisco standards.  Pretty filling too.

Premium Pork Ramen: The broth was actually impressive.  It was a cloudy white like tonkotsu should be.  Very rich and fatty like I like.  The noodles were chewy, way better than any dried package stuff though not as good as those places that hand pull in house.  The pork itself was both disappointing and enjoyable.  It was disappointing because there was no thick, fall apart pork chunks.  It was enjoyable because those wafer thin deli-like pork slices kind of grew on me.

Beef Enoki Roll: I know this is pretty inauthentic, but that doesn't stop me from loving it.  Anything wrapped in thin marinated beef would taste good to me.  The enoki did a good job, like any mushroom should, of absorbing the meat juice and providing a chewy inner texture.
author: Adam B.

description:
I guess I had to see how really bad it was for myself. 

This might just be the best mall food in SF Westfield basement Emporium (what a crock) in some cases. 

In retrospect, I should have gone to Katana-Ya for slightly better mediocrity...and get knived instead of shafted. 

Ajisen San Mateo is better than this location. The two are not affiliated....the SM branch is owned by the same folks who operate Ajisen Fremont. Ajisen SF is part of the chain from SoCal (with locations in SGV, Temple City, Irvine, Santa Monica Westfield...with the first 3 locations aiming for the Taiwanese American and Asian American ramen luvin' demographic). No wonder Daikokuya Monterey Park and Shin Sen Gumi in SGV are not so happening anymore.

You can tell this place has Chinese staff...the waitresses are all Asian and say "welcome" in Japanese with an accent. It is supposed to be "Irasshaimase!" (eee-rrrrrashei maaa seeei!) and spoken with true gusto and lung power, especially important by shokunin (professional sushi chefs for life) who are proud and want you to eat at their establishment. 
 
But somehow when the waitstaff say it, it came out sounding like "ma-say, ma-say".
Perhaps they got too used to saying "moshi moshi", which is not too far off from mochi mochi.

Stuck with the fail safe order of #2, pork spare rib ramen. The best part was the pork ribs (no bones) with a few giant pieces with a lot of jelly like tendons on them. Everything else was mediocre. The noodles were too thin for my liking, and was more like Cappelini. WTF I am not eating fusion yoshoku and ramen! The broth...super white (like super white tuna) with unrecognizeable brown bits inside (supposed to be darkened shallots or bonito flakes maybe?) shredded cabbage, and that was it. The broth had no depth, and was fairly one. Ajisen San Mateo at least made their broth tastier (maybe MSG?) Well at least I didn't walk out thirsty.

The beverage menu was a clear giveaway this was a Chinese or Taiwanese operation....iced milk teas, iced tapioca teas, slushees, iced coffees. Was I at Lavender Kow, Boba Boyz, Quick Lee, Express Tapioca, or Bobaville? Ahhh why not....tried the lemon honey green tea....and sadly a $2.75 WATTE (wah-tay....water with several shots of tea, tasted more lemon juice and honey flavored sweetener). I wasn't expecting TPumps, but man Chinatown Ten Ren could do a little better than this.

It is fascinating that one of the Sogo department stores in Taipei recently and finally got their first ever Santouka Ramen (with lots of anticipation and anxiety) where I'm sure it tastes better than the one in San Jose, and yet the best we have in a mall is a craptacular Ajisen.

Ajisen = Taste of Thousands, a Thousand Tastes in kanji....more like a tastedud. Doh....
author: Ken K.

description:
Would be good for a quick lunch for the people who works in the area...too bad the service is slow.  It's really hard to get the waiter's attention, it took a while for us to finally tag one down to put in our order.

I love spicy food so I had the Volcano ramen.  Broth, noodles, and meat were all average tasting.
author: Emmie N.

description:
Premium pork ramen is the ONLY ramen worth getting. 
Service also needs to be worked on. I've had worse, but i've also had far better. 
P.S. This is the only place i've ever come across that puts cabbage in their ramen.
author: Susy C.

description: I was very hopeful before trying but ended up being disappointed as to me it looked like they used the same broth for all the dishes and say just added chili if you wanted it spicy. My point is that if you got chicken ramen then perhaps the broth should taste like chicken, pork like pork and beef like beef. Or is this just me?
author: Joe B.

description: Very good ramen for mall food. The service is extremely efficient and the staff very helpful.
author: David C.

description:
I still make regular pilgrimages for my boba fix. Flavor is as good as ever! I've had the chance to try the brown sugar and green tea milk drinks and they are just as solid as the milk tea. Right amount of sweetness but milk and tea flavors. Tapiocas are nice and chewy, never hard/too mushy. My friend LOVED the yogurt tea so that will be my next try. 

However, the food is disappointing. Their ramen and curry rice dishes are bland. In fact, I felt the curry was of the instant variety and I can make that dish any night for dinner at home. I have concluded that this is my go to spot only for tapioca drinks.
author: Thomas L.

description: The variety of food court options in this mall is crazy. Definitely took advantage while shopping in this big ass mall. The ramen is alright, I used to see this place on instagram all the time; but maybe I should try a chain not in the mall? Idk if it would make a difference. I like my noodles to have taste but this didn't really. I liked the spicy broth. A-OK just like the rating says.
author: Jlyn T.

description:
The ramen here is not good nor bad. Just average, but it is definitely worth it when you are in the mood for decent ramen and don't feel like waiting for 2 hours in line for it.

I will definitely come back when I feel like having average ramen without the wait.
author: Anthony N.

description: Based on other reviews I tried the premium pork ramen.  Holy explosions of delicious porkiness all in my mouth!  I would eat here every day if it wouldn't make me weigh 300lbs.  Definitely check this place out if you don't mind eating in a mall food court.
author: Kristin B.

description:
Tried it for the first time last week.  Ordered the miso bbq pork ramen to go, and asked them to hold the pork which they did; but charged the same price.

You're given a pager so you can walk around somewhat while you're waiting.  About 5 minutes later, the pager went off.

The ramen is in one container and the miso broth in another so needs to be mixed before eating.  There's 1/2 hardboiled egg and some chopped cooked cabbage atop the ramen noodles.

I liked what I had but thought somewhat pricey ($9.75+), but seems everything at the Westfield shopping center is around the same price range.
author: Shirley N.

description: Pretty standard ramen that seems like it's made by Chinese people (probably is). What I like about Ajisen are the options. So many noodle options! Like the add-ons too. Pork is pretty good, though extra fatty. Broth is not super watered down, but not thick and flavorful either. For mall food, this is about as good ramen as you're gonna get this side of the Pacific.
author: Sherry L.

description: The food suck   and the service is so  bad   they give seat to other people who are came after me     and the food just taste like the 0.99$ from the supermarket     they suck!!!!!!
author: Dingzhi F.

description:
Had a bad experience on the 21st. I love the food and me and my co-workers usually eat here once a month. In December, we bought a cup of volcano sauce for $10. We asked the waiter if we could buy another cup for $10 after we ate our meal. The waiter asked the chef to prepare it for us, but the chef wouldn't do it this time. Afterwards, the chef agreed to do it for $15. We said that was ok. Instead of a cup full of Volcano sauce, we got a partail cup supposedly worth $15 of "scoops". Worse, during this whole time, we could see the Chef and his cooks laughing in the back. The poor waiter named Geoffrey did the bast he could and should not have been put in this position. 

Your chef at the Westfield Mall location is a good cook, but is a total jerf who lacks both buiness and customer service sense. I probably will still eat here, but not as often and not as enthusiastically!
author: Christopher A.

description:
This place isn't that bad for mall food. Got it to go so the portions were pretty small.

Corn with Bbq pork ramen. I love the corn, love the soup base. Needs better noodles.

Pork Rib Ramen-eh
author: Karen H.

description: Your standard quick ramen joint - nothing fancy, but gets the job done when you're looking for some hot noodle soup.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Outstanding Ramen place - and in a mall!

Went here after reading about it on GrubstreetSF. Really great quality ramen - noodles weren't overdone - great broth, too. Fantastic value and great flavor. Highlight recommend this - for ramen lovers.
author: Victor Z.

description: The food wasn't great. Service was fast, but certainly not friendly. I regret eating here.
author: Brian C.

description: Their ramen is not good, you can make better instant ramen. The boba was definitely 2/5, way too sweet. The grilled eel appetizer tasted wrong. The sushi was the best part and still a 3.5/5
author: Victoria G.

description: Ajisen Ramen is a must have every time I visit this mall. The tender pork ribs is probably the best ramen on the menu. The ribs are so soft and the soft bones taste amazing. Appetizers such as goyza and sushi rolls taste wonderful when paired with ramen. They also have a wide variety of beverages to choose from.Personally I really enjoy the caramel milk tea. Even though it gets crowded and busy on the weekend, people work in the store still remained friendly, helpful, and efficient, especially Eileen! Food quality and customer service is superb and everyone should give it a try!
author: Chao X.

description:
This place is thoroughly mediocre. I consider the broth of the ramen to  be of utmost importance, then the meat, then the noodles. 

Maybe I've been spoiled by ramen in the LA area,but I thought that the broth in the Ajisen Best combo , while flavorful, was WAY too salty or maybe there was a bit too much MSG. After I ate, I couldn't help but down several glasses of water. The pork in the soup itself was tasty and well cooked, but that broth ruined it for me. The noodles were fine too. Just normal regular noodles.

On a bit of a tangent, there was this beautiful girl with glasses working there that was totally my type. If I return, it'll be for her ^^'
author: Andy C.

description:
This restaurant has amazing quality and service for a Korean restaurant. If it were not in a mall, I'd probably give it three stars because the noise level is a bit high, but I think that given that the location is in a mall it deserves a four star rating. The service is quick and polite, the food is in ample portions (and is absolutely delicious), and the price is right. It's remarkable that such a good Korean joint is in the Westfield mall. 

The only downsides are the noise level and how crowded it can be (so crowded that the next table is a mere inches away from you, making conversation slightly awkward).
author: Kate P.

description:
I was a bit skeptical when I first went to Ajisen Ramen for dinner. I've been to other mall ramen restaurants and honestly they're usually not that great. However, I felt that Ajisen was actually pretty good for mall food. I ordered the chasu pork miso ramen, and I really enjoyed it! The broth was flavorful, but strangely enough it was missing that miso flavor I was looking forward to. I also ordered the bubble tea here, it was pretty tasty! I actually loved that the tea was brewed dark because most bubble tea places make really light teas. 

If you're looking for a place to fill your ramen craving you should stop by here :). Don't be fooled by the fact that located in a mall!
author: Lina E.

description: Not too crowded in the middle of a Friday afternoon when I got here but as I sit here its filling up quite fast and its barely noon. I ordered the tender pork ribs ramen ($9.95). The broth is light and quite tasty while the meat is semi overcooked in some parts. The noodles aren't exactly the same ramen I remember having in Asia. They just seem like normal dried noodles to me. All together this bowl of ramen isn't bad but I wouldn't pay as much as I did for it. The best part is the broth and the fast service.
author: Kelley H.

description:
You may be enticed by the cute girl waitresses but beware! They suck!

Stick with the awkward friendly Asian waiter. He is on top of his game!

The ramen is delish. I like it more than Katanya.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I'm a big ramen fan, but Ajisen is definitely only an okay place.  I have been to one in San Gabriel, CA once and the SF one twice.  

During my first visit here, I ordered the premium pork and from what I remember, P's tender pork ribs tasted SO MUCH better.  The ribs were tender, juicy and had that melt-in-your-mouth sensation.  So I craved and craved and craved for almost 4 months until we finally went back this past weekend.  Interesting thing is.. I never go to the one in San Gabriel even when it's so much more accessible.  Guess you always want what you can't have. 

This second visit was a horrible experience.  This time, P got the premium pork and I got the tender pork ribs.  The "tender" pork ribs were hard and dry, basically on the other end of the "tender" spectrum.  I was super disappointed. 

The service is alright.  The waitress was a little rude in approaching us to ask if we wanted to place any more orders because the kitchen was closing.
author: Emily W.

description:
This place is alright.

My first experience with Ajisen was in asia and they definitely did it better there. The Ajisen here, although not bad, was lacking in a few departments. Their broth is not up to par and tasted bland to me. Their ingredients were pretty good and were supplied in standard amounts. The thing that gets me is the price! Too expensive for the quality and quantity of food provided. I think I might be better off finding somewhere else to satisfy my ramen cravings.
author: Sannie L.

description:
Since it's mall food, I already knew not to expect much, and I was right. 

Came here with boyfriend and his friends before a movie and I got a rice plate since after being spoiled by San Mateo's Ramen, this just wouldn't wouldn't be able to compare. I got the pork cutlet rice plate and it was just okay. Nothing special, and its not horrible where I can't eat it. 

This place is just average, I don't think I'd come back here again with all many other better options available.
author: Harriet W.

description: It's ok to come here. And I dont care about servers, which are not nice sometime. Just care the food, bcs they have a good Scallop Ramen :-) and I love it
author: Liam T.

description:
Love this place! Despite it being a franchise, it's dependable and reliable comfort ramen when you need it. The premium pork is always a good bet with thinly sliced pork and a flavorful broth. They also have good side dishes/apps to order like fried tofu (agedashi) and fried calamari. They also have various pearl drink options.

I first tried Ajisen in Shanghai and noticed that they don't carry the same menu at their different locations. Bummer - but they still have some good offerings.
author: Anna R.

description:
Pretty good ramen.

I've been to the Ajisen in Fremont a couple of times so I thought the menu would be the same. That was not the case though. The menu here is pretty limited. It's probably because this one is located inside a mall. Most bowls are $8.50-$9.

I didn't see the item I usually order at the other Ajisen (volcano ramen) so I ordered the corn with bbq pork ramen. It came with a pork based broth and it was okay. The noodles were thin and looked like angel hair pasta and it came with only a few slices of bbq pork.

Overall the meal was okay.
author: Angelica P.

description:
2.5 stars for me.
Service was good, nice and quick.  The quality for the price, not so good.  You won't get a lot for your $10 nor will you feel it was worth it.  I had a better bowl of ramen at Lee's Sandwiches for $5.  

This place is downstairs, by Panda Express, where Rubios use to be.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Not the best bowl of ramen ever, but it isn't bad.  
No big complaints, but no wow factor.

It's enough to fulfill a ramen craving.

Gets super packed during weekday lunch, so you gotta get there early.
author: Steven F.

description:
For a ramen place located inside a mall, this place is actually not that bad. We were seated quickly and the girls were eager to take our order. 

I ordered the spicy beef ramen. It came with three slices of fatty pork, half an egg, seaweed, sliced cabbage and spicy ground beef. The broth was very light, but the spicy beef definitely gives it a lot of heat. 

Not something I would go out of my way for, but if you happen to be in the mall and want something different than your typical food court, this would be a good place to try.
author: Lyn L.

description:
It is your typical mall restaurant but better.  It's a Chinese runned Japanese restaurant.  I would have given it one more star if the service was better.  High school inexperienced style service staff.  Offer a refill but does not return to refill...why bother asking.

So far, this is one of the few ramen place that serves a spicy soup...others claim spicy but fall way short.  The portion size is perfect for lunch but slightly small for dinner.

I definitely like the extra meat and veggie....soup portion bearly covers the noodles.  If your like me,  you want enough soup..

Million dollar question....would I go bad.  YES but not for dinner...but now I know to ask for a little more soup.
author: MickYee M.

description: Heads up! This location uses spaghetti noodles in their "ramen." The egg yolk was powdery & charsiu was dry. Their portions are on the stingy side. We ordered agedashi tofu and it was only two small cubes, so the cost was no worth it. This location serves curry which our kids said was decent. We frequent their San Mateo branch on 3rd ave. which is way better than this location..food wise. Save your money and eat instant ramen if this location is your only option.
author: Robie B.

description: One of my most favorite ramen places! The bowl is pretty big, and the ramen is incredibly tasty. I love their broth! Its tastier than other ramen places ive been too. Ive tried different ramens here, and theyve all been spectacular. I love this place! Oh, and theyre the prices are bery affordable compared to other ramen places. Who doesnt love great food for a great price?!
author: Briana N.

description:
gah I love this place.  I love that you can walk up, get a table (no wait if you go at non-peak times like after 1p), order your food, slurp it down while staring blissfully at the giant menu above the registers pondering your next meal options, and leave within half an hour. a girl can only take so long of a break from shopping.

the menu has been updated, with lots more items added. my boring self ordered the ajisen ramen. again. but this time with spicy broth! I am so spontaneous! was firmly deterred from the 'volcano ramen' which is apparently, well, em, volcanic. service is much more adorable and attentive too.
author: Sasha R.

description:
this place seems pretty legit, me and my gf tried their strawberry and banana milkshake and it was pretty good, it was pretty sweet, i think some might think its gonna be a bit too sweet.

place looks good tho definitely gonna come back and try some actual food
author: Jaime D.

description:
When I think of this place, I literally feel rage. Rage which I recently relived in a conversation with my friend about how spectacularly bad the ramen is. 

In some ways, I am to blame for this horrific ramen experience. I could have walked to Katana-Ya. Correction: I SHOULD have walked the extra few blocks to Katana-Ya. Mall ramen?! What was I thinking?! Granted, this is the Westfield Mall and the food court at the Bloomingdales side of the mall is fantastic. Ajisen Ramen is in the crappy chain food side of the mall (under Nordstrom, near Panda Express). The proximity to Panda Express should have been another indicator. Basically, I was on my lunch break, I wanted ramen, I didn't want to walk to Katana-Ya, and I wanted to give this place a try. 

I can't remember what exactly I ordered. It doesn't matter. The noodles themselves are the problem. So basically all the ramen dishes are problematic. I can only describe the noodles as having the consistency of angel hair pasta. It took me a little while to pin this down, but basically from the first bite I knew something was wrong. If you order "ramen" at this place, you are basically getting angel hair pasta in soup. Yes, it is as disgusting as it sounds. Yes, thinking about angel hair pasta in soup makes me want to flip over tables in rage. 

The service was mediocre at best-- I can't really remember. I think I was literally blinded by rage in this experience. And I most definitely did not finish those disgusting noodles. I could have gone to the grocery store and bought either Maruchan or Cup of Noodles and it would have been better and considerably cheaper. In fact, if you have a hankering for ramen, do yourself a favor, bypass this place, walk straight to Walgreens, and buy a Cup of Noodles. Seriously. 

After my father eventually bought from "fresh" ramen from the Asian store, I realized that those noodles too also had the same angel hair pasta-texture. So Ajisen's secret is they probably buy their ramen from the Asian store as well. This makes me calm down a little more, as part of my rage was due to thinking that Ajisen clearly thinks that we are all idiots who don't know better and will serve us angel hair pasta in soup and call it ramen. It is now more clear that Ajisen is intent on serving an extremely sub-par product. Blech!

Bottom line: I actually hope they go out of business. I'm not a picky food person in the least. I'm really not. I've not had many bad meals, and this is definitely in the top 5 of my worst meals (excluding my mother's cooking. Sorry Mom!). I'm luckily not in that side of the mall often, because I get mad every time I see it there, still in business...
author: Jia min C.

description: This is the better of the two Ajisens in the bay area, and hence the more crowded. Expect a wait of anywhere between 10 to 30 minutes, depending on the time. What makes them superior are the unique menu choices (ultra-spicy Volcano Ramen, for one) and its remarkably central location. Otherwise, as with most Ajisens around the world, it's a suitably fast, cheap and reasonably satisfying lunch/dinner option.
author: Edwin C.

description:
A place like this is all about expectations. Up until now there hasn't been a chain ramen place in SF. It's all been one-off Japanese restaurants serving ramen using their unique, family recipe, etc., very SF. Ajisen is a very un-SF restaurant, given that it is supposed to taste reasonably the same all over the world. So I think people are judging it a little harshly.

First of all, the price. The prices roughly match (within $1) those at Katana-ya, which arguably has better ramen overall. But it's expensive to rent property at Westfield, so I am not counting that against them. The price is par for the course for a bowl of ramen in the city, and you can either choose to live with it or move away! Second, most eateries in the mall - except for Panda Express, which is most certainly taking a loss at their Westfield location - have higher than average prices. 

Second, the service. It's blisteringly fast. Within less than 5 minutes, I had my bowl of ramen and was slurping away. This is the heart of ramen: It's fast food by nature, guys.

So today, I tried the beef curry ramen. Here's the breakdown:
- BROTH: tastes mildly like curry, mildly like shoyu broth, but overall tastes like not too much in particular. This broth is just not deeply flavored enough to keep up with the rest of the stuff in the bowl.
- MEAT: the beef is straight out of the yoshinoya beef bowl cookbook. Floppy thin slices, marinated and simmered forever. They tasted OK, and as a testament to how weak the broth is, it was actually stronger-tasting than the broth itself.
- NOODLES: Not bad, though maybe a little overdone.  Very consistent texture. Would like a bit more bite to it.
- EXTRAS: cabbage was unusual but a good change of pace. Again, the cabbage's natural flavor was stronger than that of the broth's. Spring onions gave a good kick.

So it seems I'm giving this place a bad rap. But in all honesty, I wasn't displeased with my meal at all. It's fast food: I expected it to be fast and I expected it to be food, and surprisingly, it didn't entirely disappoint like what I'm used to from other chains. It got the job done. I'm confident that Ajisen can produce a consistently decent product while offering a good selection. The ramen menu is actually more interesting than Katana-ya's -- I definitely crave the pork rib / premium pork ramen and will be coming back for that.

If the prices were lower, it would be a 4 star. But unfortunately it doesn't seem like they can do much about that, unless they can really find some way to get more customers in their place and widen their margins.
author: Josh K.

description: Service is great. Ramen is so delicious at a reasonable price.  You get what you pay for, compared to other places in the food court.  Spicy Pork Ramen was delicious.  Bubble tea was sub-par, so I won't order it again. However, will be back for ramen again. Definitely a hole in the wall...never would have thought to find a good ramen place in the same area as a Panda Express.
author: Ryan Y.

description:
I was delighted to see an Ajisen at the mall, since the last time I had it was when I lived in Hong Kong over six years ago. Definitely a must-go every time I see one of these.

I ordered the spicy beef ramen and lychee ice tea with boba. It came to about $12 which is pretty pricey for the portion I received, thanks to the mall markup. The amount of food I got was significantly smaller than in HK, but there was a lot of meat so I was happy with that. I love the broth that they use, especially with the spiciness added to it! The noodles were very well cooked (I judge by how elastic-y they are) and the beef was the perfect tenderness. I just wish they gave me more! The drink was on the sweet side and the tapioca was too mushy. Service was good and the food came out pretty quickly... too bad it's so damn expensive.
author: Katie M.

description:
I'm a big fan of ramen and whenever I'm in Hong Kong, I always go to Ajisen more than once a week because it is just so yummy!!!

When I saw it opened in the shopping centre, I was beyond happy!!! Of course, the taste is somewhat off from Hong Kong and the atmosphere as well (it is very popular in Hong Kong and it is more lively and busy) but it does satisfy my craving! I always order the seafood ramen and it is delicious!

Although my mom always complains about the msg, I still love it!
author: Laura L.

description:
what i ordered... combo ramen with pork ribs, 'premium pork' and bbq pork.

good serving size, broth was ok,a bit dilluted that it tasted flat at times, pork rib is yummy and tender that even the bones were edible, bbq pork was bland in taste.


ambiance... so-so (cluttered dining area with a view of a food court)
service... so-so (drop and go and a smile when they hand you the bill)
cost... $ (fair)
author: Gors P.

description: Tired and hungry from shopping, I was lured in by the delicious looking menu. I came here with my mom and grandma. We order 3 different things and all were very good. I am not sure if this is authentic but I love the taste.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Yum!! Ajisen ramen knows how to make their food flavorful. Only downside is that this is in the food court area, so they had to cram their seats together. There was a medium sized line around lunchtime, but the wait isn't so bad.
author: Katherine W.

description:
4.7.2011
3:00 PM

Special Pork Ramen
Gyoza

Seriously!?!?  The best ramen in SF is a Chinese chain in the food court at the Westfield mall!??!  

Yes.  

It is.  

Don't bother with Katana-ya.  That new spot Ramen Underground is over priced and bland.  Santa in San Mateo is garbage.  The Special pork ramen at the place is (sadly) the best bowl of ramen you can get in SF.

It's in the style of southern Japanese ramen called tonkotsu...pork based broth with thin noodles.  You wont be disappointed.
author: William R.

description: THIS PLACE ...... Was ok.... Service sucked and my "volcano ramen" was .... Well let's just say the toilette didn't like me very much .... My milk tea boba was pretty good .... Enjoy
author: Anthony C.

description:
It has the best spicy pork ramen I never had! I will come back for it again!!!
Btw, the service was good and fast, the waitress called Amy is very nice!
author: kiki l.

description:
I've eaten here twice and the second time was better than the first maybe because I was hungry the second time. 
I got  their chicken ramen with miso soup. The soup is flavorful, but the ramen is definitely not ramen more like pasta noodles. It's lame. 

The service here is slow, but I can see that the servers try their best to cater to everyone since it gets busy. 

I wouldn't come here ever again though.
author: Lisa T.

description:
The menu looks pretty much the same. Has almost the same thing and I personally think it's difficult to choose because everything seems to be mixed together. 

I really like the setting of the place and I like how the place feels once you are seated and waiting for someone to take your order. 

The service is good and they won't ignore you like other restaurants do.
author: Gia P.

description:
My sister was anxious to try another ramen place, so it was only a matter of time until we came to check this place out. I had was very excited to try the corn w/ B.B.Q. pork ramen and the peach passionfruit soda. I should point out that the noodle is not like the traditional ramen that I have had before. 

The broth was pretty good .. it didn't taste as salty as all the other ramen I have had before. Everything was pretty good except for the corn .. 

Corn is one of my favorite vegetables. I love it the most when its out of the can because there's that nice little crisp to them. I absolutely hate them frozen because they are soggy and taste like mush.
author: Jen P.

description:
My bill totaled $13 , but they have charged $19 to my credit card?!
Come to this place, if you want to get overcharged...
author: Xiaofei P.

description:
I hate to say this but.........I'm too spoiled by LA Japanese ramen. 

I'm sure Ajisen isn't considered "TOP RAMEN" in San Fran, but it is quite hyped. 
I would consider it the equivilent to "Shinsengumi" out here in So.Cal, except Shinsen is 1000x's tastier. 

But I digress.....I'm not here to review Shinsen. 

If you're a huge ramen fan OR if you're like me, someone who doesn't really like ramen but if it's really good, you will like it, then yeah, Ajisen just doesn't cut it. I got the Ajisen ramen their "default" ramen soup flavor. It was so bland and tasteless that I almost felt like I was eating just the noodles without soup. Two of my friends also had Ajisen and both of them seemed to think 'decently' of it. 

I'm sure SF has better ramen places. I just didn't like it.
author: Lora J.

description:
During the lunching hour this was one of the places that we'd definitely have to come to once a week. Slowly it's kind of dropped from our radar since the service is sometimes slow. Still though it was always kind of in the back of our minds. That was till last night.

I ordered my usual and it just didn't seem right. The broth was too watery and the noodles didn't taste as good. The service was good and it was much faster than usual but the food seemed to decline in quality.
author: Shauna S.

description:
Why does this place only have a 3 stars average?

Anyways, I always order the ajisen ramen which is the standard tonkotsu/pork one. Lots of veggie, some seaweed, a few slices of pork, half an egg and a savory broth. The noodles are perfect. I haven't really found fault with the ramen the multiples times I've been here, although the soup can be a little salty (in a way that makes me want to drink the whole thing up!) The only thing is it's not "traditional" if that's what you're used to.

Plus their milk tea boba is one of my favorites in the city.. so so satisfying, at least for my preferences. Super soft and slightly sweetened boba balls with milk tea that is not too diluted, a good balance of sugar and tea. I would personally ask them to put in less ice cubes next time because it gets watery if you don't finish it quickly.
author: K. N.

description:
This has become my in-town go-to place for ramen because (1) it's walking distance from where I live, (2) the wait for a table and for food are fast, (3) everything I've tried is good, (4) they serve bubble tea, and (5) you can walk around the mall afterwards to burn off some of the calories you just ate.

For a little under $10, you can choose from a large variety of ramen flavors. I've tried at least 5 different kinds by now and none of them disappoint. Spicy Beef barely qualifies as spicy but Spicy Pork will give you a good kick in the back of the throat, so choose accordingly.

As I mentioned above, this place serves bubble tea AND a huge assortment of other beverages, like Peach Passion Fruit Soda. Like their ramen selection, you really can't go wrong with any of these drinks. I usually get a Caramel Milk Tea or Brown Sugar Milk Tea, which costs $4 after I add in the $0.50 tapioca pearls. These two milk tea drinks always come out on the VERY sweet side but I don't mind because I can keep drinking and adding water to it throughout my meal and still have a full cup of overly-sweet milk tea at the end! How nice is that? It's like 2 drinks for the price of 1.

I'm taking off a star because, as most others have said, the food and drinks here are a bit on the pricy side. I guess that's the price of convenience (the other good ramen places I know are at least a 20 minute drive south of SF) and helps keep the lines short-ish. The tapioca pearls are also always a gamble - sometimes they're too soft, sometimes they're in a giant clump, but never are they perfect. Still, as the only ramen place I know that serves bubble tea, I am not going to complain and will continue to order them every time.
author: Amaryllia L.

description: I don't know if I'd count this as real Japanese ramen.  Disappointing would be an understatement. The spicy garlic pork broth was worse than what you get from the powdered, DIY, 55 cent ramen packages at Ranch 99. The texture of the noodles was off, and, overall, there was way too much sodium.  I was also in a bit of a rush that day and asked how long the order would take and was promised "5-10 minutes"... however, I ended up waiting for over 20.  I'd recommend passing on Ajisen, unless you already happen to be in the area (and aren't within walking/driving distance of the other, better ramen places in the area).
author: Sarah T.

description:
I came here for lunch on a Sunday. The staff (who far outnumbered the customers) were friendly and I was seated quickly. I ordered the premium pork ramen and a green kiwi slush. 
The food came promptly and I soon dug in to my big bowl of tonkotsu ramen. They gave a generous portion of the tender pork which was a big plus. The broth was also milky and tasty as is expected with this dish. I added a bit of sriracha just because I like most things spicy (but was disappointed to realize they didn't have the Japanese chili flakes available). I wasn't a big fan of the cabbage added to the soup, but that wasn't too big of a hindrance for me. 
Overall I'd come back.  A strong bowl of needles especially with consideration of being in a food court of a mall.
author: Egan B.

description: I ordered the Seafood Ramen and my cousin ordered the Assorted Vegetable Ramen. I was pleased with my bowl since the shrimp and scallop seemed fresh and the broth was also tasty.  I wasn't very fond of the noodles since they weren't even ramen noodles. They were obviously pasta noodles and I was very disappointed. But overall, if you are looking for a quick place to  eat in the mall then I would say give this place a try.
author: Tiffany V.

description: I came here for their boba while shopping in the mall, so this rating is more for their drink rather than their food, which I have yet to try. They have very limited choices (two or three), including milk black tea and Thai milk tea. I ordered a milk black tea with boba, which was nicely prepared within 5 minutes. The milk tea itself was fresh and cold, and the tapioca pearls are what you would expect -- chewy and sugary. However, there was too much ice for my liking, so perhaps one would do better to ask for less ice next time. This place does a fine job in quickly satisfying your boba cravings while in Union Square, but if you have more time and the means, I would travel elsewhere for more offerings and higher quality boba.
author: Hurnan V.

description: Quality has gone down since I last was here. Broth is no longer to die for and the noodles are just ok. $1.75 for a scoop of corn seems ridiculous. I asked for hot tea and they said they didn't have any and they also didn't have any blended drinks even though it was on their menu. No bueno.
author: Ruth L.

description: This place has the best Ramen in San Francisco. People will want to hate on it because it's in a mall.... But if you think about it the ramen places in Tokyo are similar (underground, in train stations, etc).
author: Matt S.

description: I was surprised by the noodles. It's pretty light. I really liked it. Overall my spicy pork ramen was pretty good. I've had better soup base, but I enjoyed my bowl. I am always looking for really good ramen and if I'm shopping at Westfield Mall, I will always stop here now. There is a wait, but it wasn't bad. I am here on a weekend so I suppose this is normal. The service is good.
author: Larissa W.

description:
Ajisen ramen is a bit unstable in terms of level. I've had Ippudo, Orenchi, Daikokuya, and Shinsengumi, in addition to other famous ramen stands in Asia, so my basis of comparison is a bit skewed, but Ajisen's ramen is rather meh. Sometimes, it's hardly better than a bowl of instaramen, and other times, it's pretty decent. However, the noodles aren't that great. They're better for people who like things al dente. This particular Ajisen is pretty bad.

Food: 2.5
Atmosphere: 3
Price: 3
Wait: 3
Overall: 3
author: Rinslet W.

description: I was ready to hate on Ajisen because I'm generally not a fan of mall food, but damn you for being so good.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Their premium pork ramen is the best tasting one in my opinion. It's cool that they have tapioca drinks because they don't have alot of that in the downtown area. 
Too bad they don't offer Wi fi for customers. 
The drinks are a little expensive but their is really no place than that in the downtown area.
author: Wendy Z.

description:
Bun told me an Ajisen Ramen opened up in the Westfield mall.  She persuaded me to check out this ramen shop instead of easily walking over to Katana-Ya.  When I see an eatery inside a mall I automatically think of food court food.  Food court food narrows down to something on the lines of fast food and unhealthy with a sprinkle of low quality.  

To my knowledge, Ajisen Ramen is a chain restaurant.  It's basically the McDonald's of ramen.  Actually the comparison of TK noodle to a pho establishment would be more suitable.  There was a line there and a signup sheet wait list in front.  After 15 minutes, we were seated.  We sat across from a pair a Japanese speaking folk and watching them try to order in English to the waiter who was Chinese was an interesting sight.  God bless America.  

I got their "special" Ajisen ramen and Bun got her usual miso.  Both of our bowls looked very similar from the ingredients with the distinct difference being the color of our broths.  I gave her broth a try and likewise hers to mine.  The word "canned" came to mind when I sipped it.  Anything beyond a couple scoops swallowed of the salty liquid was way too much for my taste.  Ingredients in the bowl which included the normal staple of assorted vegetables and cha su also included an overcooked half slice of egg.  All of the listed all tasted like it was packed with preservatives.

Overall taste is the same exact sensation of eating a fast food version of ramen.  It's good for food court level food.  Unfortunately, I'm not a super fan of food courts.  Out of convenience, heck, I'll go again because its right there.  I wouldn't go out of the way for it though.
author: Arnold T.

description: We tried syoyu ramen. This wasn't like good ramen we have in japan, but it's not bad. It was like old-style Japanese syoyu-ramen, and I think I can rate 5 stars for its price. We also tried tuna-wasabi something, which is also good.
author: Kazuki N.

description:
My husband and I accidentally stumbled into this place 10 minutes before they were closing and the staff was so kind and accommodating. I felt bad because we were obviously arriving at the moment they were closing but they served us regardless.

Although we slurped down our noodles and broth rather quickly, I have to admit it was pretty tasty! I had the beef curry ramen and the broth was very rich and flavorful. My husband, Mike, had the spicy pork ramen and I was jealous that he got a smoked egg with his. He shared it with me and it was delicious. 

Yes it has a fast food atmosphere, but it was fun, filling and delicious and I love their branding and graphic. I recommend stopping by for a quick meal anytime!
author: Frank B.

description: After shopping and you're hungry, where do you go? This place! Super convenience since it's in the mall at the food court. For the spicy lover, try the volcano ramen, you will not be disappointed. But be careful, heartburn can come later lol. Oh! I love their big spoon for the soup. Go before or lunch/dinner rush because the wait can be long.  Quick service.
author: Bao N.

description:
Don't really understand the hype and lines for this place. $9 for a bowl of noodles and a few pieces of meat? Broth was not that great either. I guess for being in the center of the mall food court, it should deserve a relative amount of business but enough to have people waiting in line for 20 minutes? Given that the place is small and has limited seats i suppose it has limited seating, but i would never wait for it. Watching the line makes me feel like i need to rush and eat so others have the opportunity to eat. Although there was no line when i went here with my brother, it got full fast and the wait began not too long after. 

My opinion of the food is that it is not much better than any other japanese place around the block. Nothing special. Small portion of meat and noodles and extra vegetables that comes with the meal for the price. I was not full, rather It barely managed to keep my stomach from growling further. Meal for my brother and I was $22 + tip for 2 bowls of ramen and 2 waters. 

Honestly, the noodles I got were pretty much ramen. Toss in a few pieces of meat and you are set. Not to crazy about the place and probably would never come back I rather take $8 and go next door and get some chipotle to fill myself up.
author: Kevin W.

description: A friend brought me here on my birthday. I love the ladles. They're very cute! Especially how if you order a black bowl, you get a white ladle and if you order a white bowl, you get a black ladle. I believe I ordered a Sho-Yu ($8.75). Even though there are only three pieces of thin small circular meat, it doesn't contain much of the fat on the meat itself. The bowl looked big, but there weren't a lot of noodles, so I finished it quickly. I also ordered a milk tea, which was $2.50 without the tapioca pearls. Overall, it was pricy, but it still satisfied my hunger. Also, they were understanding because we brought cake to eat for our party of five, so it took us longer to leave the place.
author: Vicky P.

description:
I love Ajisen Ramen. Is it the best? No (for knock your sock off ramen see Katana-ya in SF or Totto in NY). But it's good, not too expensive, consistent and they serve bubble milk tea (which I love to drink with a salty meal like ramen). 

I have tried the spicy beef and buttered corn ramen. Both were good but I come here for the chicken ramen. It's nothing spectacular or super interesting: chicken, noodles, cabbage, green onions and broth. But like I said it's consistent (not to mention close to my work). 

I recommend this place to anyone who doesn't want to wait a long time (there is a wait at lunch sometimes) and isn't looking for anything fancy (this is in a mall, next to a Panda Express people, so be prepared).
author: Brittany M.

description: I was really hesitant because it was at the mall food court but ended up giving it a try considering the long line and constant table turning. Big mistake I should have known better than eat ramen from a food court. Tables were so close together I practically ate with the party next to me. The noodles were weird, definitely not your normal ramen noodles. The thing that bugged me the most was giving me a ladle as a spoon!!! I mean I do love to eat but I do not shovel food down my throat, literally with the ladle they gave me they must expect me to shovel it all in. The gyoza was horrible ling ling the panda gyoza from costco is better!!!
author: Julie C.

description:
I'm sooo a fan of this fast food ramen spot. Inside the West Field Mall, it's quick and easy. Tasty and up to par with the other ramen places - I am fa sho a fan. 

- Corn w/ B.B.Q. Pork Ramen
- Miso Ramen w/ B.B.Q. Pork
- Premium Pork Ramen
- Lychee Slush *ALWAYS*
author: Monalisa M.

description:
I had the premium pork ramen ($9.75).

For starters, I have to say that this place is quite overhyped -______- the ramen is not the best and yet it costs so much. They give you quite a lot of broth, too. However, service is pretty quick (although the wait to get a table might take a while, depending on when you go). The premium pork itself is also very delicious and tender. 

However, I wouldn't pay this much for a bowl of ramen.
author: Jenny M.

description: The first time I ever been to an Ajisen was in Hong Kong and it was pretty great considering it is fast food ramen. I always wanted one over here in the city and I stumbled upon it the other day and decided to try it out and see what`s different. Well the price is pretty similar, pretty pricy, but the food was pretty up to par, although the portions could be bigger. But overall it was enjoyable
author: Alun C.

description:
I've been to Ajisen Ramen twice and both times were just OK.

Off the menu, I've tried the Ajisen Ramen and the Premium Pork Ramen. Nothing to rave about... the best part was the broth! I didn't think the pork was very good in the Premium Pork Ramen. While these ramen bowls are large; big is not always better, as in this case. 

The service here was quick, and the food was at our table within a few minutes. The tables here tend to turn fairly quickly, so its more of an "in and out" type of restaurant. 

If you are looking for an excellent bowl of ramen, this is not your best bet. However, it is good for those who want a quick meal in the mall and something hearty that will satisfy their hunger.
author: Mari S.

description:
It's at the mall (Westfield center -old side). 
Place was crowded- poorly managed. Customer service not up to par.Ramen (we had pork ramen and veggie ramen) was just ok, nothing special. 
i will not go back t this place. It does not taste as good as previous ramens i've had!=) I would rather go to Japantown for awesome noodles (ramen).
author: C A.

description:
Love it...
Recommend Premium pork. The soup is awesome and not too salty.
Finally I found a good Ramen restaurant nearby, so I don't have to drive 2 hours to eat Santa Ramen.
author: Jirawat S.

description: Good for a quick bite. Good luck if you have any dietary restrictions though.
author: Zach K.

description:
Currently sitting in Ajisen while eating a bowl of premium pork ramen. It's okay.

What's NOT okay is waiting for 20 minutes while everyone else gets their orders in within minutes. It's bad when it's not busy but when the guys who were on lunch had to take our orders, I was appalled.

Sorry, never again.
author: Flava D.

description: I've recently become OBSESSED with all things ramen. And especially this ramen. Their premium pork ramen with spicy soup is absolute perfection. The broth is so tasty and the pork really is "premium" - lean, thin sliced, and perfectly cooked.  I honestly can't get enough of this stuff. Luckily the mall is a stop on my commute home, which means I get to enjoy my favorite ramen at least once a week, if not more. It's THAT good!
author: Natalie N.

description: The broth and premium pork are sooooo delicious. Get the spicy one but it's pretty damn spicy. This place is so good.
author: Chau L.

description: I came here last Friday after an intense craving for ramen. I did my research and found this spot. Thus, my travel with a mission started. There was a line but I decided to stick it through. The premium pork ramen is yummy. The tonkatsu side dish was also yummy. Will I come back? Yes!!!!
author: Leslie M.

description:
I had the spicy pork ramen with added corn.  Corn was almost $2 on top of the ramen.  Felt alittle ripped off, but corn makes the noodle taste that much better. 

My noodles used, were not or did not taste like ramen.  It seems like they used angel hair pasta as the noodle.  The spicy base tasted like the chinese hot sauce that is given to you during dim sum.  It didn't have a rich tasting base to it. The noodle bowl was edible and it did taste good,. but its a tad bit misleading to call it Ramen, it was just noodle soup.

If I am feeling EMO and do not want pho.  I will def come back here for the NOODLE SOUP.
author: Chanel L.

description: Food is good. But, unfortunately services are not good. I was asking a water since beginning. Asking them again. But they just brought water with bill. Yup. Finally I got a water before almost leaving. I didn't put money on a tray yet. But a waiter was already asking I am ready to pay or not. When I wanted to order and gave them attention. They saw me several times. But keep ignoring. I even don't want to give them 1 star but Yelp didn't give us half star option. So I kindly give them 1 star.
author: Hide U.

description:
Good ramen for a chain spot; definitely one of the better spots you can eat at in the mall, or the Powell tourist area for that matter.

Appropriate portions and prices. But, how come if I order a 'spicy' broth it costs $1 more? I imagine there are just different cauldrons of broth in the back, and you ladle them each the same way... am I wrong? Also, your gyozas are tiny. That's what she said. -1

Service is aiight I guess. They seem to forget things often or take a while to take our order. -1

Still my #1 choice for ramen for lunch, so long as I continue to work downtown.
author: Harold C.

description: Really long wait. The service was subpar, as I had to ask twice for my water and the waitress took a while to come by. I also did not appreciate that the restaurant is not willing to make any substitutions or changes, but that was made worse by her blunt, almost rude attitude. Nonetheless, the ramen is pretty good.
author: Katsurina C.

description:
You know, for a place that's located in the food court of SF Center, you'd think Ajisen would be easy to find.  Well, for most people it probably would be.  But for Jenny K. and I, as embarrassing as it is to admit, we had to do a little bit of wandering.  Meeting up for our latest food excursion, I'm pretty sure we probably looked more like tourists trying to find our way than locals.  Whoops.  But hey, we found the place and got in before they closed, so I guess that's all that matters, right?

Having peaked at what was the most popular item among the Yelp reviews, I already knew I was going to order the Premium Pork ramen before we even found Ajisen.  When it was brought out to the table, it looked pretty darn good - a mound of sliced pork topped with scallions, noodles, and cabbage (yeah, cabbage...I know) with a tonkotsu broth.  Sadly though, I didn't think the ramen backed up its tasty appearance.

As far as the positives went, I thought that the pork was the highlight of the meal.  Thinly sliced, I was really impressed with the flavor and how moist it was.  Any thinner, and it would have been like paper, but any thicker, and it probably would have felt dried out.  As for the tokotsu broth, it tasted okay, but it wasn't any different than what you could find at other ramen joints (Izakaya Sozai and Saiwaii come to mind, and theirs are better). 

On the flip side, I thought that the ramen noodles were really disappointing.  I don't know if it's supposed to be a different style, but it's nothing like what I'm used to nor what I like.  My biggest issue was the texture/consistency - I like when there's some bite to it, and these were really soft and gummy.  It might be from overcooking (though I doubt it since they weren't coming apart), but my guess would be that it's just the type of noodles (how it's made or what ingredient).  Whatever the reason, I didn't like the taste much either, and so the noodles really killed the whole thing for me.  Well, that and the cabbage.  I understand wanting to include some sort of vegetable so that it's not just noodles and pork, but it felt misplaced.  I don't know of any other place that includes it in their ramen, and they would have been better off leaving it out or using something like bean sprouts or spinach.

For someone who works nearby or that's doing a day of shopping downtown, Ajisen would be good for a convenient lunch or as a food court option.  However, as a destination (and compared to other ramen joints), it's not worth the trouble of finding/paying for parking on its own.  For ramen in that area, you're better off making the walk over to Katana-ya (even with the wait).
author: Mike L.

description: Thought this place was good. I had the special combo and the broth was a bit light, but the pork was very tender and I enjoyed the texture of the noodles. Will I ever crave this enough to make me want to go back? Probably not, but I may swing by if I'm shopping at the mall and don't feel like a Chipotle burrito.
author: Cody M.

description:
I came here for a Lychee Boba Tea yesterday, but the boba was a bit too hard, definitely not as good as Out the Door: http://www.yelp.com/biz/out-the-door-san-francisco

And then later (after running a couple errands at Nordstrom), decided I was too starving to go on with my errands in Noe / the Mission w/o eating. I tried the Miso Ramen with BBQ Pork, but the broth was kind of strange - not as clear as I'm used to, more milky & definitely not as flavorful / tasty as Katana-Ya: http://www.yelp.com/biz/katana-ya-san-francisco
author: Sally M.

description: It was good and that's about it. I feel like it's kinda the McDonald's of ramen. However I would return if it's near and I'm craving ramen, just wouldn't go out of my way to go.
author: Sondra E.

description:
HOLY TOLEDO!!!  a ramen joint in a mall, and this was not even Japantown.  My friend and I eyes rubbed our eyes in disbelief, then I rubbed them some more because they itched.  I initially came here to eat Great Steak, however, either Ajisen or Panda Express replaced that place.  What a travesty.  Expecting to walk up to the counter, I was in for another surprise.  This was a sit in restaurant and there was a clipboard outside to sign your name.  Because we came at the tail end of lunch hour, we were immediately seated.  Our waitress was extremely gracious and attentive.  I ordered the bbq pork ramen while my cronie ordered the spicy pork ramen.  The wait was not long at all and in short time, two piping hot bowls of ramen were before us.  Sipping the tonkatsu broth, it was pretty good, exceeding expectations.  It was hearty and rich, in flavor and MSG.  The bbq pork was very tender, however, while savory, the portions were scant.  Each piece was cut razor thin.  The corn was plentiful and buttery.  The egg was a little tough and the yolk solid.  Usually, I like the yolk watery and the egg whites to be softer.  This felt like a hard boiled half egg.  There were bits of cabbage in my ramen also which added a nice crunch.  The only complaint I had were the noodles.  The texture was not too my liking.  They tasted like packaged ramen noodles.  For food court food, Ajisen is pretty good.  The bowls are a little small for the $10 price tag, however, for a lunch that won't induce food coma, I definitely recommend it.  I nearly finished drinking the broth because it was that good knowing I shouldn't because the MSG content would make me so thirsty.  Half an hour later, eternal thirst set in and 4 bottles of water were downed.    

I found out that Ajisen Ramen is the McDonalds of ramen.  It is a chain restaurant.  The sad thing is that this mall ramen spot is better than some of the more specialized ramen joints I've had, some that are rather heralded.  

A rad thing they have is that you can order to go and they hand you one of those tokens that light up when your food is ready like BJs.  Oh yah, they give you mini ladels to eat your food.  I am not a person who eats in small nibbles.  I like to load my spoon up with shit and the ladel is wadDUUUP.  Ajisen is a solid 3.5 restaurant.
author: Brian V.

description:
3.5 stars. 

For it being in the mall, its GEWD. I like the creamy broth. The noodles werent that great, too soft for my taste but the broth is delish and makes up for that. 

Also tried the crochettes and the friend chicken. Yay to the chicken and Nay to the crochette--it came out cold and a bit tasteless.
author: Amy S.

description:
I'm giving it a better review than I was thinking because the ramen was actually pretty tasty. And I hadn't seen tonkotsu (pork bone broth) ramen in many places before (I normally have to buy it fresh-frozen at Berkeley Bowl), so I was so happy when I saw Ajisen at the mall!

Service was OK, relatively fast considering how busy they were (even though it was like 3pm), not very friendly but not bad I guess.

The gyoza were tiny and overall "meh" (not bad but not good). Won't order them next time.

But the ramen... Mmmmmm what flavorful broth! Love it love it. I had the normal Ajiden Ramen. Chashu was great, and it even had half a seasoned egg - I hadn't had one since Japan! I was very happy when I saw it.

Less happy with the bowls - which trick you into thinking you have a huge bowl of food in front of you when in fact you can feel the bottom much sooner than you'd anticipate... - and with the near-raw cabbage (but maybe that's just me).

Price: Not too cheap, not too expensive. If I hadn't had the gyoza it would've been pretty good! 7.95$ for a good bowl of ramen is pretty good, I just wish there had been more of it. I'm used to not being able to finish the noodles, or finishing them and them rolling out of the restaurant from being so full.... Not here.

Overall: I'm giving it 4-stars for the amazingly tasty broth and the miraculous seasoned egg; if not for that, I'd give it a 3 for sure.
author: Marta M.

description:
Have you ever had a boyfriend/girlfriend who seemed to have all the right ingredients, but somehow, something was missing? Sure, they tell you they love you, you have good conversation, you share common interests. But, for some reason you can't put your finger on, you are miserable. It's hard to articulate why, but you know something is missing.

That is how I feel about Ajisen. As a self-proclaimed ramen whore, I was so excited to learn there was a ramen joint at the mall. Because I love to shop and I love ramen. Duh. And also because downtown SF sorely lacks decent ramen options.

So I ordered the pork with corn ramen. It came out. It looked good. It had all the right ingredients. But as I slurped the bowl, there was nothing but emptiness. A literal "meh" of ramen dining experiences.

Why, Ajisen?! We could have been SO good together! I could've had your baby!

I realize Ajisen is "food court" ramen, but why must they taste like it? The broth lacks flavor. They skimp on the noodles. The seaweed overtakes the flavor, giving it a slightly fishy taste. It's barely a 2.5 star.

Ajisen, I think we're better as friends. When I pass you in the food court, I'll say "hey" and pretend to care how you've been. But that's about all. There's no chance for us.
author: Mariela D.

description: We ordered take out Saturday 1/2/16 night. The girl who took our order behind the cashier was not friendly and seemed bothered when we asked for more bowls and chopsticks.
author: Jenny F.

description:
First of all, Ramen is decent here. Not mind-blowing but damn good when it's cold out. Unfortunately, we had terrible service from our server Wendy so the entire experience was ruined. (Small note, in case it WASN'T Wendy, it was the waitress who had the longer hair of the 2 yesterday morning).

The shop opened at 11am though it was supposed to open at 10am. This was not an issue for me as I arrived a few minutes before 11. What became an issue is when the host/waitress started berating me and my friends for walking in to sit down as I had never been here before and didn't realize they actually prefer to walk you to your table. For this I apologize but, to be fair, nothing there makes it clear that this is how things are run as this is in the middle of a mall food court versus an actual restaurant-style sit-down. She was passive aggressive and made negative comments to other patrons about not understanding why we were walking inside. Why not simply tell us directly as we clearly aren't doing it to anger anyone? That was extremely rude and embarrassing. I'm not sure the owners would expect this kind of service coming from someone they hired. The kicker was that 15 seconds after she made fun of us for walking in to sit down, she grabbed the list of customers and read off the first name... which was from our group of friends. So we were seated immediately after anyway.

It's obvious when someone is having a bad day but I don't believe that was the case with this particular waitress as the day had just started. I believe, unfortunately, she is just unhappy there and it shows through her service to the customers. Whoever else was there was EXTREMELY nice, just to be clear.

4/5 for the ramen. 1/5 for the unfortunate server we were paired with. 2/5 altogether.

Cheers.
author: Skyy E.

description:
Have you been to Ajisen in Asia?  You have?  How dare you eat at this place!

If I had never eaten at Ajisen in China then I would definitely be more comfortable giving this place an extra star.  But there's no turning back now.  (The ramen on the mainland is not only cheaper but it tastes so much better.)

What does resemble the Ajisen I know is the fact that none of the waiters are Japanese (I'm pretty sure y'all are Chinese).  Oh yes and the winky girl logo!  

Go to Katana-Ya!  It's not too far a walk I promise.
author: Fei L.

description:
This is the ONLY franchised ramen place I know, and it really isn't bad, but it's not amazing. It's great when you're cold and want to eat something light.

I've been here twice, and the first time was good, the second time not so much.

The prices are much more than what I would pay for, but considering the location, I can understand why it's pricey.
author: Mary N.

description: Whenever I am in San Francisco, I always stop here for some ramen before hopping back onto the Caltrain. It's definitely not the best ramen I've had but the broth is tasty and there are a lot of choices! The customer service is also very good here, all the waitresses are always so happy. Definitely come and try this place out if you ever crave ramen and you're in the area.
author: Vivian T.

description:
For a mall location, this place surprises.
Reasonably priced and tasty.
When you are in a rush and want to get something at the mall, then this place is a good choice.
author: Nick L.

description:
The Spicy Beef Ramen here is AMAZING . i've tried so many other ramen places & its never the same . i don't know what i would do without ajisen ramen lol i really don't . i crave the ramen here about 3 times a week . my college is right across the street from the mall so each time i have classes all i can think about is coming here after i get out.  Some ramens could be a little bland, though but I definitely recommend the Spicy Beef Ramen or the Spicy Pork Ramen . That's all I ever get when I come & its never too spicy but just a perfect kick of flavor in the broth , perfectly cooked noodles  and the beef is braised and just melts in your mouth . 

Their drink selection here too is great they have so many options from Watermelon slushes, to Kiwi , to Passion Fruit , to different flavored milk teas . it's just really such a great place & the 3 stars definitley under rated .
author: Jose T.

description:
It was a family day and we decided to try this place out. First off this is nowhere near Santa Ramen.. it's not even Maruchan Ramen.. $10 bucks a bowl.. you're paying because it's in the mall and downtown not because of the quality.

We arrived with a bunch of open tables and ordered our food few minutes after looking over the menu. And we had decided to take a bit of extra time to look over the drinks, so we just asked for water. About 5 minutes later more people arrived and tables were filled up. We decided to order 2 drinks. My sister had some sort of ice tea drink and I ordered a Peach Mango Soda.

We finished our food 20 minutes later and asked one of the waitress where our drinks were. She said she would check on it. 5 minutes later we told same girl our meal was finished and asked where our drinks were and she replied 'your checks?' No OUR DRINKS! At that point I was so mad already that I decided I didn't want the drink anymore. When she finally brought our drinks, my sister took her drink and I asked for the waitress to take mine back and take it off our bill.

Then I'm guessing who was the manager came. He asked if there was anything wrong with the drink and I told him 'No, but we're finished with our meals and you just brought it out, we don't want it anymore.' Then he tried to make excuses like 'Oh, it was busy.' And I told him if it was busy then why did all these other people got their drinks already? To which he replied 'Oh, well you ordered it last right?'

'Ordered it last!??!?' We came in before all the other tables and ordered the drinks as they were being seated. 'Ordered it last.' I'm sorry since when does a Syrup Soda take 20 minutes to make? That's all it is... You squirt syrup, add some mango jelly type things, and fill it with soda. It does NOT take 20 minutes to make I don't care when I ordered it. It takes less than a minute.

This Asian guy with glasses was insulting my intelligence and testing my patience. How hard is it to take the drink back and take it off of the tab. It was only $3.50 for christ sakes. And we're not ones to argue over 3 dollars considering our bill came out to almost $60 for 4 people. But it was just the guys attitude and his failure to admit his fault that he simply forgot our drinks. Don't try and cover up and give us lame excuses.

Cleanliness = 6/10
Decor =  5/10
Quality = 3/10
Service = -3/10
author: Kathleen C.

description:
For chain restaurant mall food, this ramen place ain't bad. The service is lacking a bit during lunch time (why do we have to wait to be seated when there are 3 open tables just sitting there?).  I think they were just understaffed.

I ordered the spicy pork ramen. It wasn't too spicy but it had a nice flavor. I loved the soy sauce egg on top. The pork was a bit fatty but I just ate around it. You only get a few slices which was fine with me cuz I was busy slurping up all the yummy noodles. I slurped so much I think I splashed broth on my lunchmate more than once.  Oops!  We also ordered a side of gyoza which were tiny! Not your usual gyoza since they seemed to be filled with veggies instead of meat. They were just OK.  The milk green tea with boba was good.  I love being able to chew my tea. It was very sweet & tasted just like green tea ice cream so I got my drink & dessert all at the same time. 

I'm not sure if there are any other ramen places in this area, but this one will do in a pinch.
author: Erin S.

description:
At the suggestion of a coworker, three of us signed up at the line up board for a ramen lunch here at the Westfield Mall.  For my first "real" ramen experience, I have to say, it was pretty damn great!  I ordered the vegetable bowl and received a huge bowl of noodles and broth, topped with corn, two types of mushrooms, carrots and some nori pieces.  Along with a peach tea, I had so much food, I could barely finish it all.  My coworkers tried the Spicy Pork and Shoyu, and they ordered a side of Gyoza as well.  

While it's in the mall and technically "food court", this is a restaurant of sorts where you can sit down and get your food freshly made.  The line up outside dictates how long it will take you to get served, as the service itself was pretty quick.  There appeared to be takeout as well, if you want to grab and go.

We'll probably be adding this onto our list of lunch spots to go to regularly, as it was good food and a decent price.  Only drawback for me, there's one vegetarian option available in the ramen. It's definitely worth getting more than once, but I fear I'll get tired of only one choice each time we go.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Meh. I've experienced better. Or at least that's what yelp said. :)

I was aware this is a chain restaurant especially my very first experience of Ajisen was in China! Though China's Ajisen had a more extensive menu with so many different ramen and rice dishes, noodle soups and appetizers, I did my very best NOT to compare it with SF's Ajisen.

Because of meeting up with a friend and deciding where to eat for brunch, she chooses Ajisen since we're already inside the mall. It was not crowded when we were seated with menus placed in front of us. With only one side of the menu offering different ramen dishes, it was a very limiting choice for me since they had only one chicken, one vegetables, and one seafood ramen noodle soups. I decided to order the Chicken ramen while my friend ordered some shoyu pork ramen. Apparently, if you want your ramen soups to be spicy, they charge you $1-2 for it which I thought it was lame. Of course the waitress did say she was going to get some hot chili sauce (the rooster kind) for me to add in my ramen. 

Ramen comes out. My friend seems to enjoy her bowl very much. I, in the other hand, not very much. Either I was not in any mood of eating ramen, or did not order the ramen dishes they're known for. Anyway...

Friend: "How was your chicken ramen?" 
Me: "Tastes like something died. I mean, the chicken's not fresh at all"
Friend: "Uh...."
Me: "The soup base smells too gamey. Maybe it's not gamey, but rancid-like"

I don't know how I managed to finish up the bowl. But I can definitely tell you I was not feeling too well afterwards.
author: Kim L.

description:
I get the spicy pork ramen with extra steamed cabbage on the side.  It is pretty darn good.  I prefer this ramen to Katanaya now, but that is mostly because I love cabbage.
Service is slow so make sure you order everything you want at the very beginning.  If you ask for anything extra later on, you won't get it in time.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I'd give this place a 3.5 stars for food, service, and convenience (it's in the mall).  I bumped it up to 4 because I thought their average of 3 was on the low side.

Out of all of the Asian noodle soup options, ramen is my least favorite and I'm not sure why.  I keep trying different places in hopes of finding one I'll like.  I would say this is on the higher end of the scale for me in terms of tastiness. 

The tables are pretty close together, but the service is fast.  It's in Westfield mall so it's a convenience place to grab a bite if you want something better than your typical food court meal.
author: B. Y.

description:
This is a chain ramen spot in the Westfield mall but I like it more than Katana-Ya. I get the Premium Pork Ramen and ask for them to make it extra spicy (they charge something like 2bucks to make the soup spicy). 

Good after a night of drinking :).
author: Chau T.

description: if you are hungry after power shopping, this will fill the bill. If you are hunting for your next great ramen fix, keep looking. Serviceable noodles and broth. Too soft for my taste. The best thing is that you get a not skimpy hot bowl.
author: E. W.

description:
For a mall place, not that bad. 

The noodles are a bit thin, the chicken was decent but could have been flavored better, but the broth was good. The Spicy ramen was actually spicy. If you're looking for a ramen place Ajisen isn't all that bad a place to hit up and honestly if you're in the mall for food, I recommend this more than any other place in there. 

The service is always awesome and the waitress was super nice. 

I just wish like other ramen places they gave me free kim chi (apparently that's not standard, who knew?)
author: Rohan D.

description:
It's A-OK. It's mall food so what can you expect? 

I work in downtown so I only come here because 1. It's convenient and..  2. I'm just craving ramen haha 

It's not the best ramen in town that's for sure but it satisfies my cravings. 

I usually only get the Spicy Pork Ramen and it wasn't as spicy as I would have liked it to be. The pork is always a hit or miss. Sometimes it's fatty and sometimes it's meaty. The calamari is pretty good for a place that specializes only in ramen so that's cool. 

Service is meh. Only really check on you if you ask for something.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Date/Time: Friday - 7:45pm
Occasion:  Dinner while shopping
Party of:  Two
Ordered: Premium pork ramen; added spiciness.  
Location:  Located right in Westfield Shopping Center in the food court.  
Total incl gratuity: ~$27

Having just come back from Asia not too long ago, I was very excited to learn that Ajisen Ramen had opened in SF.  I'm not sure how long they have been open but I was eager to try.  It makes me nostalgic of the happy memories I have of my trips and food adventures overseas.  

Unfortunately, I was quite disappointed.  Perhaps my expectations were too high but it was nothing like HK!  I went with the premium pork.  I must say: the pork was very good and sliced nice and thin however I was not impressed with the noodle nor was I impressed with the broth. Oh, and the cabbage?  Skip it!  It made the ramen taste gross!  The noodle was a strange texture.  Not very enjoyable.  I ordered my ramen with extra spiciness and it was far from it.  There goes $2 I'll never see again.  It's definitely not horrible...but I guess I should have known better than to have high expectations.  Prices were a little steep too.   

The service is what you'd expect from an eatery located inside the mall foodcourt - pretty minimal and unenthusiastic.  If you're in the mall and are really craving a bowl of ramen, give it a try.
