However, if you don't mind the walk and possible wait-time - skip Ajisen and go for Katan-Ya on Geary.
author: Jess C.

description: Very very disappointed!!! Service really sucks!!! We waited in line for 10 mins to get seated. We understand they are busy. When we finally got seated waitress got our order then for about more than 20 mins waitress came back and confirming our order again. When we asked if she hasn't place in our order she said she was busy!!! A good way to lose your customers!!!
author: Lhyn L.

description:
I'm going to compare this place to Katana-ya like everyone else and also say that its much better than K-ya, like everyone else. Personally, I like tonkotsu style ramen the best and that's what they serve here. You can't go wrong with the Ajisen ramen, but I'm pretty sure the other choices are good as well. Also the curry rice plate with fried chicken is pretty tasty too. The only thing that's not up to par are the flavored tea drinks, which are overpriced and blah. 

It's nice coming here when its freezing cold in SF and I can just hop on Bart to go home after without having to go outside again :)
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Had the premium pork ramen.  Nice generous portion of pork, sliced thin.  I was happy since I can never have too much meat, but for some, it might be a bit much.  Tonkotsu broth was okay, didn't really wow me although I did finish it all.  Personally, I guess I was expecting some more depth of flavor....perhaps a little more umami.

Noodles were kinda skinny, the size reminiscent of those dry ramen packs.  I definitely would have preferred a slightly more substantial noodle.  A little more backbone would have made all the difference.

They were sold out of Diet Coke so I had a Ramune marble soda.  Wanted to save the bottle since my friend makes jewelry out of those marbles, but didn't feel like carrying it around.

Lastly, wasn't crazy about their table service policy.  The servers were attentive, but this a shopping mall and it's a mall restaurant.  It should be like all the other restaurants here where you order at the counter, especially considering that this is just ramen.  I'm sure counter service would also increase efficiency and profits due to better table turnover.  Rather than have servers bring checks early and then have them come back right away to turn tables, one must realize that people have a tendency to linger less if it's counter service with no need to wait for a check, especially for something like noodles in a mall environment.
author: Roy N.

description:
meh, it's ok. not anywhere the best ramen in SF even, but it's still not a bad choice when you're in the mall; it'll get the job done.

also, they have really really good boba tea
author: Mark A.

description:
I was actually looking for Rubios at the mall (hey gotta love the Asian Sesame Fish Taco) when I ran into Ajisen Ramen! It was a pleasant surprise, and totally unexpected. I wish there are more ramen restaurants in the bay area, and i was happy to see this place. 

It is a no frills restaurant, more like a typical mall restaurant in atmosphere and scenery. I ordered the Ajisen Ramen (original) with extra noodles, extra Chasu Pork and egg. The price was among the lowest I have seen at ramen restaurants. The noodles were decent, but not quite at the quality that you would get at Orenchi or Ramen Dojo. The broth had good flavor, but it was a bit on the salty side. Like Sawai in Richmond District, the ramen lacked in the topping department.

I get random cravings for ramen, so overall, while Ajisen isn't the greatest, if you need a quick fix, its definitely a decent enough place to grab a bite. 

Underground Ramen - your next!
author: Ray K.

description:
No folks, this ramen stand isn't in the new Bloomingdale's mall, it's in the old Nordstrum's mall. Look for it near the panda express on the basement floor with the BART entrance. 

That was the hardest part of my night when I was out looking for Ajisen, I thought it was in the newer mall with Beard Papa's. The meal is good as usual. I say Ajisen is my barometer for decent ramen. I've been to their store in Fremont and I think that's a solid establishment as well. We ordered shouyu ramen and the spicy pork; both came out quick and flavorful. I'd say the spicy one was a bit too spicy for me, good thing I didn't order that one. 

Looking at the wall, I saw four Chinese characters. "Pork, Bear, Bone, Book?" What does that mean? OK, I'm just kidding. You'll have to read it from right to left, and top to bottom. So that'd be "Bear, Book, Pork, Bone". Making sense now? OK, I'm kidding again. It's Kumamoto Tonkotsu, which means pork stock flavoring from Kumamoto. You can tell your girlfriend that the next time you want to sound smart; or like a dork. Enjoy!
author: William H.

description: Their ramen is very average. And it's tiny so be sure to get additional items. It can get busy, and the employees can get overwhelmed. It's ok for mall food.
author: Vol T.

description:
My friend recommended me Ajisen Ramen in this location so we went for a try.

We ordered Corn w/ B.B.Q. Pork Ramen, Shoyu Ramen, Ajisen Ramen, Premium Pork Ramen and Premium Pork Ribs Ramen. None of us was satisfied. The noodles tasted OK. The broth was kinda lukewarm. The taste was OK but a little bit blend. Our BBQ Pork and ribs were not tender enough. We had Ajisen Ramen in different stores in Asian countries and those experiences were much better than this one. 

I originally gave 2 stars but added 1 star for the convenient location.
author: V L.

description: My bowl of corn and barbecue pork ramen was quite possibly the most unsatisfying bowl of ramen I've ever eaten. Ramen usually never fails me. Brings comfort, warmth, happiness. But their tonkotsu broth lacks depth and complexity. Basically, one flavor and that is a little bit salty. I don't feel any love and attention in the broth. I do like that they use thin, straight noodles but they could have cooked it less. The three thinly sliced pieces of barbecue pork were bland and dry. And though the egg was tasty, I've never been a fan of hard-boiled eggs. I want that creamy, yolky goodness in the center of the egg, please. The best part was the canned corn. Can't possibly mess that up though.
author: Joyce W.

description: For where it's located it's not bad at all. I mean it's not as good as your usual 4 star ramen place, but I give it bonus points for it's location. And I heard that it's a chain, and if the one in a mall is good, I can only imagine how legit a restaurant version of this would be. I have to admit I was pretty hungry when eating here, but it was super good. Seating is very limited, but if you're shopping and you don't want to trek very far, this place is hella good.
author: John C.

description:
Surprised this place only has 3 stars, it's at least a 4! I've been on a search for ramen ever since moving to SF and let me tell you, it's a long hard journey. Tanpopo in Jtown is aite, and Katana ya is definitely over hyped. I am not waiting 40 minutes in the cold just for a bowl of average ramen, doesn't matter how authentic it is. On the other hand, Ajisen may be owned by the Chinese but they know how to make their broth (and its delicious). Pretty sure they add some sort of dairy to make it creamy but who cares, it tastes good and the dairy's probably good for your bones anyways. 

There's never a wait, it's nice and warm because you're in a foodcourt, and there's tons of other stuff if you don't want ramen. 

The two pork ones are my favorite.
author: Nattie X.

description: Service is awesome and fast. I ordered the seafood ramen, it was mediocre. Nothing special, it tasted like the pre-packed instant noodles that comes with seasoning inside that I always cook at home.
author: Lora M.

description:
I have been in search for the best ramen spot in SF since moving here from Chicago, however Ajisen Ramen did not do it for me. For a mall food and a chain restaurant, Ajisen was decent. I had the Miso Ramen with B.B.Q. Pork and the noodles was not the standard noodles used in authentic Japanese ramen, which was disappointing. The soup base, however, was actually pretty flavorful and was the B.B.Q. pork. Although, the queue was long, service was pretty quick and the ramen came out piping hot.

I would rather hit up Katana-Ya for better Japanese ramen, although still not the best, but probably the better one in the downtown area.
author: Charles C.

description: Three stars for the food and that's it.  It is sorta "mall food" but has a sit down and waiter.  Problem is the service is slow and they messed up our order.  Our "quick" lunch during work ended up to be a long one.  Westfield Mall is right by a lot of offices - they should be much quicker.  lesson learned - order to go and eat in the office... will be back a lot in the winter though I'm sure
author: Amanda K.

description: Quick and decent for the Ramen fix, but not exceptional by any stretch. My search for the best ramen downtown continues...
author: Joel D.

description: Horrible customer service. very rude to customers. ordering customers around when they were doing nothing wrong. we were ordering to go and we sat down at an empty table there were many tables unoccupied but they yelled at us to go outside. Food isn't that great.
author: Elyse L.

description: This place we tried when we stayed visited San Fran for the day. It's located at the mall which is convenient if you get hungry after shopping. I usually get the soup with beef. The prices are reasonable. The service is so-so. The boba is great! and i also tried the mango tea they have with mango jelly. They have a variety of selections to choose from. Usually come here for lunch to have something light.
author: Lorraine C.

description:
you know, surprisingly pretty good for mall quality and also for being in downtown..

don't expect super great broth, etcetc but it hits the spot if you're craving for some ramen. the wait on the weekends can be pretty ridiculous tho. also not in the foodcourt..it's next to chipotle. 

worth a try!
author: Janet Y.

description:
I love this ramen place!! Even though I try to avoid eating mall food, and at chains, i can't help but come back to this place. I'm not even a really big fan of ramen. Growing up in Hawaii I would avoid eating it, but here in San Francisco, I started craving hot ramen for chilly days.

For some reason the ramen here is my favorite, compared to different ramen places I've tried so far in San Francisco and in the bay area even the ramen places in Japantown. I guess I'm just a real big fan of their soup bases, they are very flavorful and don't taste bland like all the other places I've tried. So far I've tried the shoyu ramen, the spicy beef ramen and the tender pork ribs ramen. The tender pork ribs are just as described, very tender and delicous. I love the spicy beef soup base with the ingredients in the shoyu ramen, for a dollar extra I was able to change the broth out. The spicy beef broth has been perfect for this cold I've been having lately.

Service is fast and polite. I don't have to stand for too long before someone greets me and seats me right away.
author: J R.

description:
Tried the premium pork ramen and pork rib ramen, requested spicy.

The broth was creamy but not porky enough, it lacked depth. The noodles were straight and too soft for my taste. The only veg in the premium pork were scallions and cabbage!? Why cabbage? 

But the premium pork slices were really good, tender and delicious.

The pork rib meat was tasty too and tender with soft cartilage. The spiciness was minimal, just a bit of chili oil added to the broth. This bowl at least had seaweed, but also a bunch of cabbage!?

If I was at the mall and REALLY craving ramen, I'd come back. But Santouka and Ramen Dojo are my favorites for tonkotsu broth ramen.
author: Derrick V.

description: Had lunch and it was delish! Premium pork ramen was excellent and the service was very good and fast. I shall return and try something new.
author: Ladyreyes R.

description:
Heard that this ramen spot took over the location where Rubio's used to be in the Westfield Center. Got there around 11:40 and waited about 5-10 minutes in line. The place was packed. The menu is pretty straightforward and short. Several types of ramen, some apps, a couple rice entrees, and a bunch of specialty drinks. 

I was about to order the tender pork ramen, but decided to ask the waiter what he recommended. He told me that it can be too filling so he suggested I order a regular ajisen ramen and add half tender pork to it. Perfect suggestion. The tender pork was rather good actually, but I could see how eating a full order of it might be too heavy. The soup broth was a bit garlicky. (I still prefer Katana-ya). The chicken karaage was actually pretty good. There was a good crisp to the breading.

Overall, for serving ramen in a food court in a shopping mall, I was pretty impressed by it.
author: Rick T.

description:
One of my favorite Ramen Noodle places in SF. Love the food here. Beef curry ramen, spicy beef ramen, and corn w/ B.B.Q. pork ramen are among my favorite dishes here. The staff is friendly and the service is pretty fast (most of the time). 

Not sure why some of the reviews are on the negative side. I actually prefer this place to Katana-Ya (another ramen noodle place on Geary), especially considering the fact that there's always a long wait to get seated at Katana-Ya.

Definitely worth checking out. The only annoying thing is the location. This place is located in the westfield mall in downtown SF so unless you're willing to pay $10 for parking at the nearby garages or are taking the MUNI, you're out of luck finding parking nearby.
author: Ali A.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Ajisen ramen = yeah it was okay. haha. Somehow the Fremont one was so much better. 


SERVICE:
Actual table service although they have a take out counter? Server was good. Food came out hella fast.


ATMOSPHERE:
It's in the foodcourt of the Westfield Mall.. feels kinda fastfoody, except it has table service :P 

1220
author: Angela L.

description:
Often times I want ramen but don't want to spend the time at a sit-down restaurant, especially when I'm by myself, this place solves that issue!

It's quick service and pretty good food. The price is pretty reasonable, considering the could charge more because of their location. The broth is kind of on the salty side and the hardboiled egg it comes with looks gross but the meat is good.
author: Shayna Y.

description:
I actually like this place. I came here several times and have no complain except wait. They do get crowded something and lots of people waiting to be seated. They are reasonably priced and very generous with their portions. They excel in RAMEN only, I do not find their appetizers appetizing at all. 

Also, there was a review bashing food court restaurants and I think that is not true at all. It is not just I who like this place but also my husband and brother. Two people who has big appetite. We like their Ramen and hope that they stay in business for a while :)
author: J C.

description:
This ramen place is right inside the mall. It's a weird place for a ramen restaurant, but it works I guess. 

I had the miso ramen soup which comes with cha siu here. The noodles aren't really great here and neither is the cha siu. The cha siu seems like it's cheap quality. The egg.... tastes like a rubbery overcooked egg. The soup is surprisingly pretty good though.

Inside can be dangerous since they have waiters and waitresses walking back and forth with hot bowls of ramen. They try to have as many possible tables/chairs in this place that it's so compact looking.

They do ramen take out which they put the soup in one container and the ingredients in a bowl container.
author: Steven B.

description:
I love this place! Every time I go shopping I have to eat here because its delicious!!! Servers are nice and helpful.  If you are a spicy person like me, you must try their spicy pork ramen! I also love to add corn to it.  You can add any toppings to it for extras! 

Its the best ramen I have eaten so far.  The gyoza is a good choice for appetizer. They have a long list of drinks. Most importantly, they have BOBA!!!!!! Overall, if you happen to be in this area, highly recommend you to try this out!
author: Shirley C.

description:
I tried Premium Pork as well as Miso with BBQ Pork.  The Premium order had enough meat but the Miso order only had about 3 pieces.  

I also ordered the lychee iced tea; I recommend that you mix it up before you drink it.  The first time I ordered that drink, it was too sweet during the beginning but pretty bitter near the end.
author: Julie Y.

description:
SIMON SAYS "EAT THIS!"

Whats wrong with these people? This Shiz is Tasty!

I've eaten at Ajisen in Fremont once, Japan once, and half a dozen times in Shanghai and i liked it everytime...

will it compare to the mom's and pops of japan? hell no...

does it compare to the shiz Katanaya serves? hell yes....katanaya is by far the most overrated ramen place around...

and does it rank up there as a solid ramen place in the bay area? i sure would think so...santa went downhill, katanaya tastes of prepackaged ramen, maruichi does cut it, and few others rank high (santouka is good!)

its damn good meat, tasty thick broth oozing of pork flavor, and solid quality ramen noodles...what else do you need? 

Must Try - any ramen with pork...any pork is tasty...i especially love the premium meat...crispy edges and tender meat...u can't get it anywhere else

Negatives - the price...i say its $2 more just cause its in a shopping mall. 

Dining Tip - When you come try the ramen, please just turn a blind eye on the decor and China-ish service and feel of the place...just come for the food. its good stuff as long as you allow your taste buds do the testing and leave your snobbishness at home
author: Simon L.

description: I had the miso pork ramen and my dad had the beef curry. Both were awesome and hit the spot on a cold day in San Francisco.
author: Pinky L.

description:
This place is located in a Mall.. Yeah its a bit pricey... This is a mall... Even water cost 3 dollars in certain parts of the mall.. Well not really, but just throwing it out there for you guys that is reading..

Ramen:

For a mall, this place isnt so bad. They allow you to have what kinda texture of the noodle you like. Hard.. Soft...

Snacks: Tofu, Gyoza, Croquette. Really affordable, not too expensive. Under 3 dollars. 

Price: Mall.. Look around you, everywhere is the same.

For a mall to have a joint like this. Sometime it get really crowded, but its not as bad. Maybe, if this place was located somewhere else, I would rate differently, but since it is in the mall. Its not as bad as you all think it is. I usually talk to the waitress and have them recommend me something, and different ways of making my ramen enjoyable. You be surprised of the things you wouldn't know, if you dont ask. Small stuff like the onions cannot be taken out from the beef ramen or certain meat taste better with different soup.

Sometimes i would tease them to see do they pay attention. Overall, I have an enjoyable experience, so i approved.
author: Ernest S.

description:
Not bad for being mall food....and not bad for being a chain restaurant. (I think the chain is originally from Japan.)

I had the Tender Pork RIbs Ramen ($9.75) and my friend had the Spicy Pork Ramen ($8.95). The pork ribs were really tender and fell apart with my chopsticks. My friend's spicy ramen had a good kick to it (probably more spicy than your typical ramen house).

This is a good alternative if you don't feel like waiting in line at Katana-Ya. We placed our order with the waitress and had our food delivered to our table in about 5 minutes.

I probably would not go out of my way to eat here...but if I'm shopping at the Westfield mall or happen to be in the area, I would definitely consider coming back.
author: Lester W.

description:
For sf, this ramen gets 4 stars. i didnt want to like it but i've been here a couple times and the broth is better than decent. i'm taking this over asuka, sawaii, tanpopo, and cue gasps- katana-ya.....
and yes they have tonkotsu broth if anyone was wondering. 
btw selena W, sometimes, u just gotta roll with limp noodles!
author: aron w.

description:
SO DISGUSTING!!!!

FYI guys, manager/owner SAID "TO-go orders are not reccomended" they frown upon to go orders because they don't have the mental compacity/items to pack it right

so eat there (at your own risk!! Or eat somewhere else, it's mediocre.)

they do not have the right containers for it. 

so if u want to order, you should order somewhere else

My sister and I have been going to this restaurant since it opened. So maybe 4 years? We only go because We are craving ramen, not because it's delicious. REALLY EXPENSIVE!! We will no longer return and I will tell all my friends and co-workers who work in the offices around here not to come anymore either. Meh. There's better places anyway, such as Panda Express (and they do to-go orders). 

Anyways, i  ordered a to-go order, some noodles. The lady handed it to me. As I was walking out my sister said the soup was leaking and it also leaked all over my jacket and arm.  (I DId not get far, just to outside of the restaurant) I told the lady what happened because I didn't want to bring the order in. It was leaking everywhere. I realized it was a loose lid. She came out to look and asked "were you holding the bag upside down"  Wtf? It's soup. Of course I'm not gonna hold it upside down. I'm not a retard. I know theres soup inside. Like I said, I didn't get far. She was really rude and asked if she should make another one. WTF again! a significant portion of the soup spilled on my Burberry jacket (which i now have to get dry cleaned, thanks b*tch) so those stupid noodles end up costing me $20. I was really angry at the fact that she blamed me for a loose lid on the soup!!! Of course I want another one, most of the soup spilled!!! I was so annoyed that she was shaming me for a loose lid, like I said. I didn't get far, just a few feet. (I understand it might be less believable if I was home already or if it happen minutes later but this was 30 seconds later. Then she tells me that she usually recommends customers not to order to-go. I have worked as a waitress  in my college days and was appalled at her behavior. and if you asked me, if that woman apoligized? pfffft, ill be lucky if she didnt spit in my food!
author: Nancy M.

description:
This place is fantastic.  I honestly don't know why it's only getting an average of 3 stars as of this writing -- maybe it's the mall-food-court ambience, or the fact that it's a chain (an international chain even).  But when it comes to the food, it's just "wow."  So all can be forgiven.

The key here is to stick with their core competency, namely the ramen, and more specifically the Premium Pork Ramen.  The soup is tonkatsu ramen -- the broth is simmered with pork for many hours, so long that it takes on a buttery, creamy texture and turns white.  The pork is tender and delicate, salty and sweet.  The noodles are firm enough to chew but soft enough to please.

Needless to say, I never miss an opportunity for a little Ajisen Ramen.
author: Marco C.

description: I love their volcano sauce ramen and that's about it. They recently added boba/jelly drinks to their menu and they're okay-ish. It gets really crowded at times, but the service at the tables are fast, and friendly.
author: Kylie G.

description:
San Francisco needs more ramen!  Correction: San Francisco needs better ramen!
I was psyched for this place to open (since I always have trouble finding somewhere to eat while shopping downtown).  Then I realized I'd already been to this place.  In NYC.  And I was disappointed then.  And I'm disappointed now.

Its set up to be sit down and we always get seated quickly but actual ordering time varies.  All the meat is cooked nicely but the broths are just not that flavorful.  Need more MSG or something...I dunno.  They're just not bowl slurping good.  And I've had a couple now (spicy miso, premium pork).

And its not like its super cheap either-- pretty similar prices to the far superior (albeit far more difficult to get seated at) Katana-Ya.

Boo.
author: Kristin P.

description: Soup was too oily, noodles were okay. Nothing special! But decent for a mall type of food.
author: Alyce l.

description:
This is not a review of their famously good ramen, as I've had before in their store in So Cal. This is more a review of their Passion Fruit Slushy. Yeah, I went inside this place just to order a drink..it's silly, but it was what the Prince of Taiwan was in the mood for. 

It was slightly on the more expensive side, but I understand, with this being the SF Shopping center and all. Good, sweet but has that essential sourish puckering taste that real, authentic Taiwanese style Passion Fruit drinks ought to have.
author: Jerry C.

description: Came here for  lunch today thinking I'd give it a try. The Ramen was average, the California roll was eh... The croquette was DELICIOUS.. I'd come back and try different dishes this place has to offer but not in another 1-2 months.
author: Tina S.

description: My husband and I tried their Volcano Ramen, karage, gyoza, and California rolls with masago.    I am not a fan of Japanese ramen so I didn't order my own ramen and get stuck with a big bowl with no interest... So my husband shared his and I absolutely loved it.   Next time when we come back, I will be getting my own bowl.  The sides dishes were ok,  nothing mind blowing but decent.  This ramen was sooo good.  Warning on te volcano one, this can be super spicy.  We asked for the chili pepper paste on the side just incase but we ended up using all of it.   For once I wish I had the big bowl to myself.
author: Judy L.

description:
Ajisen Ramen is not terrible for a food court place and for a place that is not run by Japanese, but not impressive either.
But I have to compromise to eat here once in a while since there is not a one good Ramen place in San Francisco in my opinion.

One thing I must tell you, they are missing two of the most important spice/garnish.

1) White pepper. this is a MUST for ramen, period. I asked for white pepper and they brought me black pepper. It has to be white pepper.

2) Red pickled ginger (not a pink pickled ginger for sushi). this is also a MUST for tonkotsu based ramen. 

Missing these is like eating a hot dog without ketchup and mustard.
author: Hide S.

description:
Came here once to try the food. The drinks looks yummy, so I guess thats what pulled me into the place. I was immediately greeted, asking if I was ordering takeout or eatting in. I said eatting in and was told I could sit anywhere. The place is bright and theres music in the background.

The prices are a bit high. There are a bunch of choices for ramen but only maybe 3 choices for rice plates. Theres some appetizers and a menu for drinks. I was thinking of ordering one of the rice plate and was told it wasnt time yet and they only have ramen, not after 11am. Same for the drinks, asked for a boba milk tea and was told that the boba was ready yet. I end up ordering the Miso Ramen with BBQ Pork ($8.50) and a ice milk tea ($2.95). When the food arrived, I can probably hear my stomach growling. The ramen smelled so good and it tastes even better. The noodles was yummy and the pork (only 3 pieces) was soft and moist, and not hard to chew. There was half an egg, some seaweed, some lettuce, and some green onions. The milk tea tasted very good, probably because I havent had a milk tea in like forever.

The total came to $11.45 + tax = $12.54,  tip a bit generously since the waiter was very helpful and friendly. Will most definitely come here again =)
author: Jen M.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped by this place after a day in SF but we weren't impressed by the food served here.

From the outside, it looks cute and reminds me of one of those little noodle shops in Japan but the food was just a-ok.

I ordered the Miso Ramen Soup with BBQ Pork and my boyfriend got the Spicy Pork Ramen and they were both pretty bland except for the spiciness of the pork. 

The portions here were pretty small as well.

However, the overly-priced Enoki Beef Roll was pretty delicious! We only got 2 small pieces cut in half for like $5. 

I didn't think this place was anything great, I guess the looks of the place is just a little misleading.
author: Sarah P.

description:
Ramen as "mall food?" Definitely!
Upon entering, though it looks like you can seat yourself, the employees prefer that you wait at the entrance until they seat you. You'll recognize the employees by their bandanas and aprons Or, you can order to go by walking to the counter in the back.
One you sit down, you are presented with a one page, double sided menu with graphics to aid you with your decision making, along with a napkin printed with the logo. Cute.
There are about 10 flavors (more or less) of ramen; the rest are appetizers and drinks. Service is quick--barely a wait. 
Highly recommended if you don't want to spend as much on food as you would on the Bloomingdale's side of the mall, yet you don't want to eat Panda Express.
author: Brittany L.

description:
I had such high hopes for this place and was eagerly awaiting its opening throughout the Summer when the sign went up in the food court of Westfield Center. I had great experiences eating at this chain in Hong Kong and in Sydney.

Bottom line, international chains just don't translate well. I chalk it up to the difference in quality of ingredients, even down to the water used.  The noodles at this domestic location are more like the packaged ramen ones you find in the refrigerated section of an Asian supermarket. I also really don't remember the use of raw cabbage in the ramen bowls I had at Ajisen outside of the country.

If you happen to be in the area, give it a shot. However, do not, under any circumstances, make a special trip to eat here.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
i dont know why i was excited to go to this place even though i dont even frequent this place when i'm in asia or in LA...  in chinese, we nickname this place  "mei jing lai mean" (aka MSG ramen) and it's also cuz it sounds close enough to their real chinese name... 

one word describes the food... MASS PRODUCED! 

if you are true ramen fan... you'll know what i mean.  I got the premium pork ramen ($8.75), yes it came with  A LOT of meat... but it was just eh to me... broth is MSG... it's not the type of broth that's been boiling over night with tons and tons of pork bones... it's not creamy and full of that good pork fat flavor... reminds me of instant tonkatsu ramen I can get for $0.59 at Sunset Super...  ramen... well.. hmm... bouncy on the first bite.. but that's it... gets soggy and ugh... 

the karragge was ok ... it was juicy... but the chicken is not your organic free range chicken... you can tell its from mass produced foster farm quality... if even foster farm quality... 

hey... i'm sorry if u like this chain... but to me, this is another ONE AND DONE! i'm not gonna waste another 10 bucks on this joint when I KNOW there are better ramen places out there to be devour!
author: Kelly H.

description:
This might not be the best ramen joint in this town, but for an international chain, located in the crappier part of SF Centre, this place rocks! 

I've had the premium pork ramen twice and it was awesome. They give you a ton of pork too. Also had the fried chicken curry which was decent. The chicken is literally just american style fried chicken, not karaage which has a soy saucy flavor. The curry was good and think with big chunks of potato and carrot. Muracci's is way better, but if you can't get all the way over there, Ajisen is a good standby. Also had the negimaki which was just ok and the agedashi tofu which was awesome! 

Another great thing about this place is their boba tea drinks. Their boba is almost perfect with great selections of drink flavors. I always opt for the boba milk tea, but have been wanting to try the caramel milk tea. I see a visit in my near future. 

Customer service is ok, but don't expect much.
author: Jen D.

description: Their best combo ramen is a must try! Soooo good and addicting. I just wish they can add extra more meat in it, but nonetheless it's still very good. Not a fan of their iced tea thou but it's no biggie. My husband and I took our family from Canada here so they can try it... That's how much we like this place. Highly recommended for those who are short on time but looking for a good place to eat. Service was fast and place is clean. Worth driving almost an hr for.
author: Arlyn C.

description: I have to wait extra 15 minutes because they messed up my order.  So, total waiting time is 35 minutes for a bowl of Ramen.
author: Kit P.

description:
I've heard some good things about this place so I tried it out.  

I was surprised to find this place inside the food court.  From its name, I was expecting some small papa-san place near the mall, but not inside the food court.  

Anyways, I liked the speed..  service was friendly.  If you'd notice, servers at this joint is way better looking than any other food joints in the food court.  I was bit surprised.  :)  refreshing...  

They've obviously tried to bring 4 star experience to this place, but sadly, the food is 3+.  I'd be fair to say it's really good for a chain.  Being inside a super mall in the heart of sf downtown, they couldn't bring down the price to the chain restaurant price.. yet, considering that it's a chain, I'm surprised at the speed of delivery, presentation of the dish, service quality, and cleanliness of dining area.

I'll definitely give another try and see if I can give them another star..  Great job.
author: E P.

description: Decent Ramen Place.  Spicy Pork Ramen is prob the best dish here.  I also like how they serve boba drinks here.  Reason why 3 stars? Considering that there are so many more delicious ramen places in SF, it's hard to rate this place higher.  But if you want a quick ramen fix, def a place I'd consider trying out!
author: Joshua P.

description:
Place is alright. I'm not a huge ramen fan outside of a styrofoam cup...but I do enjoy the fancy kind from time to time.

This place had a amount of choices of noodle soups with rice plates and "snacks" available. Their beverage choice was just as robust. Boba, tea, ice tea, soda...pick your damage. 

What was funny about this place being in a the food court a mall was that they do table service. Walking in, I almost cruised right be the "Please Wait to Be Seated" sign. It was a pleasant surprise to be served at a food court, but unnecessary.

I ordered the miso ramen with BBQ pork along with the fried tofu as my snack. The ramen was actually really good. I enjoyed it thoroughly. I'm not an expert but the noodles were straight instead of the typical curly kind. Almost spaghetti-like. I know people are very particular with noodles, so that might be a useful tip. The tofu was not good. It tasted bland, even for tofe, and the seasoning on it was too gingery and fishy. I was expecting agedashi, but instead, got mushy yucky.

Would I come back. Sure. Not my first choice, but sure.
author: Jon C.

description:
I'm still a bigger fan of Katana-ya (Even with the wait!)!!  I'm originally from So Cal and I never visited Ajisen Ramen down there.  Also, I frequently visit Hong Kong and I've actually never paid a visit to this ramen joint either.  Well, after I tried it at the Westfield Shopping Center, I definitely left disappointed.  Disappointed enough to write a review on it!  

We ordered Fried Tofu and Fried Chicken to start off with.  The tofu was just okay but the fried chicken batter was not very good.  For our main course, we ordered the Premium Pork Ramen (added $1 for the spicy soup base).  First, it wasn't spicy! :(  I didn't really like the texture of the noodles because it was very ordinary almost like spaghetti-like texture.  Overall, I think I would have been happier with a bag of korean ramen noodles at home for no more than $1.  I would definitely not go back to this spot!
author: Vicky C.

description:
The ramen is not bad. I would say it is better than a lot of other places I have eaten. What really made my little noodle adventure really amazing was the service. Yuliani (sp?) was a total sweetheart and helped answer a lot of questions I had about the menu. 

Skip the cluster F that is the main food court and have a nice bowl of decent tonkatsu ramen between getting a new pair of jeggings and an alexander wang bag.
author: Nat S.

description:
Woohoo! Finally, a ramen place near work that is not quite as far as Katana-Ya. I was pretty excited to try Ajisen, a fast-food type of ramen joint in the mall.  Their menu looked good and prices are pretty fair.  In my opinion you get a lot of food for the price (and its good food too!)  I've tried the BBQ Pork w/ Corn Ramen and the Premium Pork Ramen.  Both are delicious, just depends on the mood you're in since the Premium Pork ramen has no veggies in it.  Most of all, I really liked the broth at this place (and the type of noodles they have.)

The service here is pretty fast, AND they have boba! Awesome! The boba ends up making me super full (to the point that I feel round and tubby walking out of there), but the boba is very soft and chewy, just how I like it. 

Since Ajisen opened recently they still need to work on a few small things (like designated waiters, bus boys, and cashiers maybe?)  A couple times we were delivered a bill with a credit card when we hadn't even asked for our bill yet so we were a little confused and let them know that wasn't our check.  Aside from all that, and I'm sure they'll work those kinks out eventually, I am going to definitely be adding this into my regular lunch rotation.  Yay for ramen!
author: Tracy N.

description:
Don't be fooled by the fact that this is a chain ramen restaurant in a mall!  Their broth is yummy but not as good as Hapa.  I do, however, like their noodles better than Hapa.  I ordered the chasu pork and corn ramen and it was delicious.  The bowl is packed with seaweed, shredded cabbage, 3 huge slices of pork, a spoonful of corn, and half a soy sauce egg.  They also serve boba milk tea!  Yippee!

Warning: Their table service can be a little disorganized when they're busy.  If you're not in the mood to wait, get your ramen To Go.  They pack everything separately so that your veggies and noodles don't get soggy during transport.
author: Nina L.

description:
I have been looking forward to the opening of Ajisen San Francisco after going to the ones in Fremont, Temple City, and Richmond (BC).  

Ajisen is a chain restaurant and it has a sizable presence in Southern California and three stores in Canada.   This chain is very consistent.  The ramen at all locations taste the same.  

The ramen at Ajisen is a lot thinner than the ones served in places like Santa Ramen or Santouka.  The broth relies less on oil and more on spices and vegetables.  Also, they use straight noodles.  The combination is very flavorful.  I emptied the bowl.

The menu does not seem as extensive as the ones in Southern California.  Hopefully, they can incorporate more items as they go along.  I did notice a sizable drink menu and that seems redundant with Jamba Juice so close by. 

The staff was friendly and helpful but a little disorganized.  Hopefully, they will become more efficient in the days ahead.

I feel that this Ajisen location is an important step to their gaining a foothold in Northern California.  They do have a location in Fremont but it is in a fairly remote strip mall.  If this one does well, maybe it will lead to more Ajisens in the area for the future.
author: Re-pley Z.

description:
After seeing the announcement about this place I was curious, mostly because I love boba tea and am always looking for good places near work. When we arrived, the line was almost out the door (prepare yourself for a wait if you're going over lunch).

So I am picky about where I'll have boba tea, because when done poorly the whole experience is awful. For those of your who worry like I do, fear not! The milk tea is lightly sweet, but not overwhelmingly so. They have small pearls which scored extra points with me. To top it off, the pearls were delightfully chewy ( just the right consistency! yay!). I'd come back here again just for the boba tea... even perhaps seek it out over Out the Door's boba.

As I am not a ramen coniseur, I can't compare it with many other places, but I will say I thought it was pretty good. The potion was huge and I was pretty much full about half-way through the bowl. I realize this is a chain so perhaps it's not possible, but I wish they had a few more veggie options on the menu. 

All in all -- no complaints. I'll be back here for lunch again for sure.
author: Madi B.

description:
Hi Julia! (the yelper below me). Although Julia and I have recently became friends, I don't share the same sentiment about this ramen place. 

I've eaten at this ramen joint several times now, this Ajisen Ramen chain restaurant deserves no more than 1 star for the following reasons:

1. Although the ramen is mediocre, at best, it is a bit on the salty side, it may be the MSG. 2 stars for the ramen by itself

2. I came in once to order the Green Bubble Tea, which consists of green tea with boba. What I got instead was Green Milk Bubble Tea. Not the same, so the lady took back the drink and made me another one. What she didnt know, was that I was watching her make my drink. Instead of throwing away the drink, she re-used the boba, nuked it it water and then placed it in another cup. Then she loaded the boba with A TON of sugar so I wouldn't be able to taste the milk on the boba. 

Moreover, she dropped one of the utensils, but proceeded to rinse it, instead of washing it and used it. 

0 stars for the drink

I am so disappointed with this place. The SF sanitation board should inspect it and then shut it down so the owner(s) and employees can learn their lesson. Shame on them.
author: Nance H.

description:
Definitely not as great as the one in Hong Kong. I've been meaning to come here during their grand opening w/ my friends but it was always too crowded. Finally came here last Sunday and we got seated right away. The staff are real nice to the point it can be annoying. They apologized to me 24/7 even when there was nothing to apologize for. Still, I'll applaud them for that since they are still nice in terms of service. 

As for the food, it's nothing special. It's just okay. I ordered their tender pork ramen. The pork is a lot thicker so it wasn't as tender as I had hoped. It is still tender but could be better if maybe it was thinner rather than a big block of meat. Still, maybe that's how America likes it? As for their ramen, I got a few pieces that were stuck together and not cooked right. Their cabbage was strange. It was like eating really crunchy rubberbands. The soup was not really that flavorful. Rather, it was thick with msg and sodium. The portions are also not that big. It was just right for me. For some, you may need two bowls to fill yourself or just grab some dessert after. Lastly, one of the waiters came to pick up our bowls, and he stepped on my shoe for a good 30 seconds. I tried to move and I said excuse me a few times but he didn't hear me. I guess this wouldn't have happened if I had kept my foot a bit farther in the table. All I can say is, watch your feet. ;[
author: Ash Y.

description:
Decent not my fave, but not horrible. It's in the mall so I can't expect amazing. I did enjoy it but something about the broth of the ramen sort of had me wishing for more flavor. I had the spicy pork and it seemed like chili oil floating in a very thin broth. Noodles were ok. Overall this place is just that ... ok. I will try this Katanaya that everyone refers to. But as far as I am concerned this place has nothing on the southbay ramen shops. 

I have to say though the service is very kind and for that they get an extra star. I hate to be that person to say that as if I am waving the rating over their head, but these guys were really awesome. We came rudely with a group of 8 and no call ahead. They were like "uh ok ... give us like 10 minutes." A little more than 10 minutes later, our stomachs rubbling, coworkers talking of bullying others out of their seat .... and bam this crack team busts out like the super teamwork and clear and move 3 tables together and in unison clean the tables off for us. Impressive show hats off and they even offered separate checks at then end (we didn't take them up on it but it was nice of them to offer).
author: Greg G.

description:
I LOVE this style of ramen. I've been waiting for a chain like this to open in SF for a long time. LA and NY had them for many years now. It's about time snobbish SF residents learn about different types of ramen other than Katana-ya and Suzu.

Some people don't understand that cabbage is a normal topping on Kumamoto ramen. This Ajisen has the authentic taste of locations in Japan and asia. Sounds crazy to give 5 stars to a fast food joint, but I don't care. It's as good as it gets. Also makes up for all the ignoramus that post reviews on Yelp.
author: George M.

description: ABC Ramen was tasty, but the service leaves a lot to be desired.  They try to get you in and out due to the high traffic location.  I would go again, but don't expect anything else but decent ramen.
author: tom w.

description:
The ramen here was just Average Joe. The type I got was the BBQ Pork Ramen with Corn in a mild broth plus started off w/ some Potato Croquette for my appetizer. 

Note: The Potato Croquette is deep fried, comes with this creamy mayo sauce and it's served very hot! So let it cool down for a few. Nearly burned my tongue eating those. You get 4 per order and they were good.

The service was prompt but the ramen could use a boost. (except for the BBQ Pork which actually had lots of flavor). Maybe it's cuz I haven't tried the Premium Pork Ramen that seems most popular with Yelpers yet.

I think this place has potential for growth and improvement. Maybe steal some of the ingredients from Ramen Dojo in San Mateo (=P) cuz there is something magical and diff. in their ramen that makes ppl willing to wait an hour out their door in the cold. 

Since this is in busy SF mall in Union Sq. ppl are still gonna come here anyways for the convenience.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
I always get the Ajisen Ramen (: Veryyy delicious but not quite as authentic as the ramen I've tried in Japan. In any case, the noodles are cooked just right, the soup is very flavorful, and the pork is very chewy! Overall, it's just the right amount to make me full!

There's usually a lot of people here so you'll have to wait to be seated most of the time. Also, they don't serve free hot green tea like they do in the Ajisen Ramen in Rowland Heights (SoCal) so I was kinda disappointed. 

I'd definitely come back, but it'd have to be like once every month or so.. Seems like I would get tired of it easily if I ate here too often.
author: Connie T.

description:
Is what it is...Mall "ramen". If you're stuck downtown while short on time and it's cold, you're sick or you just have to have your ramen fix - Go for it.

Called in for pick up was a plus...Especially during lunch hour.
author: Con L.

description:
I didn't like the food here at all. 

Came here over the weekend with the family and kids.  My kids love ramen...and usually don't discriminate but this place was a first for us where both my boy and girl didn't finish their shared bowl.  I don't blame them...

First off we ordered the two Ajisen Ramen for my wife and kids and the spicy pork ramen for myself.  We also ordered the fried chicken and baby octopus.  Every thing went down hill from there:

First off the fried chicken... guess i was expecting Kaarge...this tasted like Chicken McNuggets.  The baby octopus seemed way over cooked and over marinated... we didn't finish either plates.

Now the Ramen:

1. Looks like Tongotsu broth, kinda has the texture of tongotsu...but didn't have that nice deep taste of broth brewed for long periods.  Just didn't have the richness of a long simmered broth.
2. I needed lots of water after wards... probably loaded with msg.
3. the noodles... reminds me of thinner spaghetti and not egg noodle that i like about in other ramen places.  
4. Cabbage...they put fresh cabbage in... the taste and texture combo of cabbage did not suit me at all.. no bamboo shoots, no corn for the texture
5. Egg way over done... 
6. I think they meant to give me char shui, but the pork looked like thin pork belly.

Maybe I'm too use to the the way ramen is typically made here and this is supposed to be the style from a specific region ... but it just didn't do it for me... heck I'd rather stick to top ramen than this crap.   None of us finished any of the dishes.  Guess my kids now have a place they avoid....
author: Vien C.

description:
I always get the spicy pork ramen.  It consists of half an egg, ground spicy pork, a couple slices of roast pork, and some veggies.  The ramen is pretty good, noodles are al dente and the broth is flavorful.  The last time I was there, the spicy pork was so spicy, I coughed after every bite and I was breaking out a sweat. Holy moly.  Coworker ordered miso-didn't seem like he enjoyed it very much.  The fried chicken appetizer is good.  Make sure you squeeze some lemon over it.  It makes it taste that much better. Yum!

On weekdays, get here by 12:10, otherwise you'll have to wait in line during the lunch rush.
author: Cheryl Q.

description: I come almost every day with my friends. Ramen is great there, service is also good! Love them!
author: Yuqin S.

description:
I like this place and it's probably because it's one of the only two ramen places I go to when I visit friends in Irvine.  With that said, I've been told (without research on my own, yipes) that it's a chain.  Nevertheless, I enjoy it.

I think the prices are decent (under $10) and you get a decent amount of food.  The flavor is good and there really isn't much more I can complain about.  The location is convenient enough from my work place and the rush after 12:45pm makes it relatively quick to get a table.

Slush/icee drinks are a little too sweet for my tastes, so I can't really finish them.

It's not some place I'd punch your mother to get, but it's certainly worth my money for fast ramen.

The only complains I'd have is that you have to get the spice in a jar (I haven't the slightest idea what it's called) by yourself in the far corner and that I've certainly had better ramen for the same price, but those places are much further to get to and lunch hour is only, well, an hour.

If I want ramen, I'd come back here as noted by my whopping two checkins!
author: Alexander S.

description: Terrible service experience. We had a server whose--at least on the ticket--name was Wendy. I and two friends arrived at 10:45am (the yelp listing reads that it opens at 10am) amd were surpised to find it closed. I saw some staff in the kitchen and walked into the open restaurant to inquire what time they would be opening. After I asked the server spoke to me condescendingly, explaining that there was a sign that said they weren't open yet. I explained that I understood and asked the same question again, to which she replied smugly, "we open at 11." I've worked in service for 9 years and know how challenging it can be, particulalry when opening, so I smiled and turned around to go back to my friends and wait for the restaurant to open. When she came to turn the sign around my friends and I walked in because the restaurant has the look of an "eatery" where you order at the counter, get a number and have a seat. We were mistaken but instead of politely informing us she instead snarkily said aloud, "I don't know what they're doing or why they just want to disregard the sign..." We walked back to the front and she pointed to a table in the corner (we were the first ones on the sign in list). The ramen was good. Nice portion and the miso broth was on point (hence the second star) but I had trouble enjoying my meal knowing I was being served by someone who obviously hated their job. Luckily part way through another server began helping us.
author: Colin E.

description:
Totally acceptable mall ramen joint. I got $25 worth of takeout :

+ Spicy Pork Ramen was nice and spicy! Lots of good toppings, decent noodles (mine were not soggy), flavorful broth with the sodium content I'd expect from a fast-serve ramen joint. 
+ Gyoza were tasty and had good texture, but also quite salty  . 
+ The boyfriend was less-than-enamored with the Premium Pork Ramen.
+ Agadashi tofu was lacking in flavor but survived the trip home without  getting soggy.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
If you order milk tea, it comes in a small container. Overpriced


However I constantly crave their premium pork ramen. On a cold day it's the best! I like the noodle consistency and the broth is really flavorful. Usually I get it to-go and eat it on the other side of the mall so I can people watch. If you order to-go, don't leave it out too long or the noodles will stick together!
author: Momo M.

description:
wtf?  I liked this place more than Katana-ya?  Damn right.  I have no idea why people hype up Katana-ya so much.  It's ridiculously over priced and it makes me cringe to think about the ridiculous profit margin on each bowl of ramen they sell

My friend told me that Ajisen Ramen is a pretty popular chain in Socal and other suburban places with nice malls, so I was really curious to try this place.  I got the premium pork ramen, which is fatty pork cut really thinly.  It was really good.  I ate the entire bowl... which I never ever do!!  

The broth is definitely full of msg and made from a packet so I didn't drink that much of it even though the flavor was pretty spot on.  

I would definitely come here again.  Don't judge this place just because it's a chain and that it's located in a mall.  It's seriously better (and better value) than Katana-ya...
author: Anna T.

description:
I love this place. 

I use to live in Shanghai and its a huge chain there! They basically have one on every corner! We use to go there all the time and when we moved back I missed them so much!! 

The menu in China was a bit larger but the ramen is just as good!! I wish they had their chicken wings!!
author: Elena G.

description:
I thought the premium pork ramen was okay but not a great value.  A fountain drink is served in a tiny cup so skip that if you are ordering to go to keep your bill down.  

The biggest problem I had was that the ramen came with piping hot soup in a really flimsy plastic container.  It both caused me cancer related worries and also burned my fingers while I was trying to get the soup and the noodles mixed together.  

There has to be a better way to do that.

Conclusion: Meh. I'll likely stick to Coriander for food court situations.
author: Luke M.

description:
TWO stars for the noodles and ONE additional star for the service.

I had the Corn with B.B.Q. Pork Ramen and the noodles was not that good at all.  They looked and tasted like angel hair pasta; soft and not chewy,  The broth was too oily to me.  My friend had the Pork Ribs Ramen and the broth was even more oily than mine.  Another thing that I don't like is they put cabbage in their ramen.  

The service was fast and friendly; way above average for mall food.  

Go Back again?  Probably NOT for their noodles, maybe to try their rice plates.
author: Liza T.

description:
The first time I ever ate at Ajisen Ramen was in LA.  I remembered liking it so I was excited to see that Ajisen was opening up in the city.  I finally had time to try it this weekend.  

Cute decor. Decent service.  Much smaller menu than LA.  The F ordered the spicy pork ramen and I got the premium pork ribs ramen.  I suspect the broth being the same for both dishes but the F's one was really spicy after he mixed in the ground spicy pork.  The broth was really tasty and creamy.  The premium pork ribs were super soft and tender with bits of tendon within the meat.  It was so soft that even the tendon wasn't chewy.  

The negatives?  The noodles used wasn't exactly ramen noodles.  It was almost like white soba noodles.  If they had used the actual chewy, egg colored ramen, it would have been really good.  The prices were a bit steep for ramen, especially when there wasn't much toppings to the bowl and the portions were quite small.  So small in fact that I wanted to go to the food court afterwards to eat something else.  

Ajisen is definitely better in LA...maybe its the extensive menu they have there or maybe it's because I remember them using the right noodles...but as for this location, eh.  Change the noodles and I will definitely be back!
author: Amy L.

description:
I'm not a huge mall-type-person. Therefore, I am not a mall-food-court-type-person. 
Anything from the food court, gives me (pardon my french), le mud butt'. 
Especially, Panda Express and Chipotle. 

Anyway, maybe I don't know squat about Ramen, but I know the Ramen I had last night from (Koryo sushi in Oakland) was NOTHING compared to the Ramen I had at Ajisen.

I will write a review on the Ramen I had from Koryo. But really quck: my spicy Ramen from Koryo had a few, measly pieces of chicken, 2 teenie weenie slices of fish cake, some seaweed, and a baby-handful-amount of noodles. 
And, I have a medium-size bowl, at home, that I use for pho. When I poured my soup and noodles, the contents only filled 1/4th of my bowl. And, the soup cost me about $12.95. I should have called the police and told them that I had been robbed! 

Today, at Ajisen-- I had ordered a pork Ramen + extra spicy.
They brought over a hefty bowl and it looked damn good! 
It was hot in temperature and the heat, on the spice, was just right! 

Yo! I ate and ate and ate as I sniffed and sniffed and sniffed. By the time I was done, my sinuses had been set free (of my annoying allergies).

I had also ordered my daughter a gyoza and a coca cola.
Everything came out to about $16.00.
I left very satisfied and content.

I will, definitely, return!
author: Sheila S.

description:
Disappointment :[

"Meh. I've experienced better" is right. I came here with high hopes after spending much of my high school life here http://www.yelp.com/biz/ajisen-ramen-toronto

The prices are lower in Toronto. The noodles are thicker in Toronto. The portions are larger in Toronto. And the menu is much more extensive and yummy in Toronto. I realise it's in a mall and all, but I was hoping I could have a little bit of home in Westfield. Not really.

If you have a chance to go to Toronto, try that Ajisen instead!
author: Hilary S.

description:
Decent ramen with a diverse enough menu and a decent price.

I ordered the premium pork ramen that gave GENEROUS amounts of tender, flavorful pork.  Unfortunately, I would have easily traded it for the normal pork at Santouka.  Next time, I'll try their signature Ajisen ramen, as the one I ordered only had pork (lots of it), cabbage, and green onions.  

The broth was the right milky consistency that I'm used to and was probably one of the least salty I've had (which is a good thing), but towards the end, it did get a tiny bit bland.

The more sore part of lunch was the noodles.  These were more akin to top ramen noodles rather than hand pulled noodles that are cooked slightly more al dente.  The ones here were soggy and stringy.

With that said, I'll come back again to try the other bowls and possibly even the curry pork cutlet, which is another love of mine.

For now though, I place this among the second tier ramen shops with Ryowa, Halu, and Himawari.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Even though Ajisen is in a food court in a mall, it's still some of the best ramen in the city.  The only competitor is Kenken Ramen, but let's just say they aren't as dependable as Ajisen.

The first time I went I had the pork ramen, which was good.  This last time I went I got the fried chicken curry, which was very, very tasty.  I think it was something like $8.50, which isn't too bad, considering you're in a mall in San Francisco eating made-to-order food.  The specialty drinks are a little overpriced, and so are some of the other dishes.  In fact, I would recommend the curry over the ramen, though both are still quite good.

Atomosphere:  It's in a food court in a mall in San Francisco.  Have I mentioned that already?
author: Paul G.

description: I got the Ajisen best combo ramen. I've been to quite a few ramen places, and I do have to say, although this place is in the mall it's definitely not bad. I was pleasantly surprised at how good the ramen was. Service is good-fast, but rushed. If your ever craving ramen and in the mall, this your go to! Can't really be too critical of mall food.
author: Oatmeal S.

description:
*3.5 STARS

I discovered Ajisen one day on my lunch break...Let's just say I was PRETTY excited! I love Ramen. I went inside to grab a menu to check out the options they serve along with the prices.  The menu was VERY inviting. It was my kind of menu, PICTURES! haha...Prices are a bit on the high side. So I was a bit skeptical because it was in the mall and if you're going to charge that much, it better be good. So I decided to go and try them out the following day.....

So I went with my co worker and we decided to order two different ramen and share. They were really busy so that was a good sign.  We ordered the Premium Pork Ramen and the Spicy Pork Ramen.  I have to say, it was pretty darn good! Broth for both was flavorful and milky with flavors. Pork was tender and juicy. Ramen was nicely cooked and plenty of it! I was PLEASANTLY surprise and was so excited that I can come and have this anytime I want for lunch! hehe...

Now for the downside...since the place isn't that big, I didn't expect to wait for two glass of water take so long.  And when our waitress finally came to the table, she forgot it and had to go back and grab it. So my suggestion is to hire more help because she was good and sweet, but definitely spread a little too thin during the rush hour for lunch. Other than this, i recommend this place if you have a craving for Ramen while you're in the mall...a bit pricey for Ramen, but a good "hit the spot" for ramen during your lunch break! I would come back and try their rice dishes =)
author: CoCo V.

description:
This is located in the older part of the SF mall, and it's an actual restaurant. For 2 we waited about 10 minutes for a seat at 12:40pm on a Saturday - the wait staff is very quick to come by with water, take your order, and 5-8 minutes later have your food out. 

I like how the broth is milky in the pork ramens. Like most ramen, the price is around $9-10 per bowl, and pretty salty. I would definitely come back again if I had a ramen craving, but overall nothing too special.
author: Leily P.

description:
2/5/ it's not ramen.

i should have read up on the other reviews before popping in here. should have known better than to give up a craving for nick's crispy tacos!

anyways. the noodles aren't ramen! they are different. the soup also has a weird cloudiness to it, i couldn't help but be grossed out as i ate. it was also alot of salt and sesame oil, couldn't taste anything else.

in the end, it is what i get, for eating at a mall foodcourt.
author: Alvin D.

description:
Came here for lunch because I work closeby. Extremely cute set up and decor for a food court place. 

Ramen bowls are around $9-$10 each. Sadly, I did not see extra toppings you can add to your noodles (no bamboo?!?) and you don't get to choose different types of broths, etc. I ordered the corn and BBQ pork ramen, which came with an egg and the regular pork broth. Portions were decent (for someone like me--I finished the entire thing), but not humongous like normal ramen places. Meat was tender and the broth was not bad, but nothing blew me away. 

Overall it was A-OK for mall ramen joint, but it doesn't compare to most other places.
author: Vivian D.

description: great pork ramen. I'm a huge ramen fan. It gets pretty crazy during lunch, but so does every other mall restaurant. The take home containers are great, so don't be afraid to get it to go.
author: Julian C.

description:
They serve authentic Japanese ramen noodle soup. The taste is very good. I really recommend. Especially, premium pork ramen and spicy pork ramen are good. 
Curry rice was OK, not super but worthy to eat.
author: Ted W.

description: Premium pork ramen!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Not much you can expect from a mall...this place was just alright.  Fast service, reasonable prices, and seats available inside the restaurant so you don't have to carry a tray and worry about finding a seat.

My ramen was okay.  I had the vegetable ramen which had a lot of corn (frozen), some seaweed, and some enoki mushrooms.  The broth wasn't super flavorful, but I asked for hot sauce and Siracha came to the rescue! 

Tip 1: Don't come here if you're a strict vegetarian.  Even the vegetable ramen has fish sauce in the broth.  

Tip 2: This is located in the Nordstrom side of the food court (not the new side!)
author: Alvina W.

description: I tried this place in Toronto and I still stand by my 3 star rating. It's not a whole lot to write home about. I got my order to go so I ended up putting it together myself. The vegetable ramen was lacking flavour. I should've stuck with my usual pork flavour. Oh well. The price was just under $10 to go without a drink. If you want a ramen fix and you don't feel like walking to Katana-ya then this will have to do.
author: Amy J.

description: Overall a nice place to get lunch. It's not the BEST Ramen, but it's pretty good. I'd definitely come back. It's definitely pretty good for mall food though. It's pretty overly watered down for ramen in my opinion and the noodles could be better but something about this place works.
author: Thanh N.

description: Always fast and always delicious! I love eating a big bowl of ramen before going to the movie theater.
author: Josh F.

description:
I was never a huge fan of ramen, but the stuff I've had here is by far my favorite.  My go to order is the tender pork ramen with the spicy soup base and a cup of the cranberry, yogurt & lychee drink.  The meat is...well, tender and my noodles have always been cooked just right (haven't had a soggy bowl yet!).

Lunch time gets crazy, so go at least 15 minutes before noon when the rush starts.  And definitely eat there.  I ordered my ramen to go once and ate it in the seats right in front of the store.  It wasn't as tasty as when I usually eat in the store.  Maybe I didn't like it as much just because it was in one of those plastic bowls that remind me of a instant cup o' noodles (just add water!).
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Working in the Westfield has made me spoiled.   So many good quick places fro lunch.  I'm glad to have another Japanese option now as the other place in the mall is really lackluster.

The space is nice; you can sit down in the restaurant or get it to go and sit in the food court.  I don't know why they don't have a hostess stand  at the door since it is assigned seating inside.  Probably a first day kink.  

Service was speedy, but not as fast as more established places.  Again, they are probably going to have this stuff all worked out.

The ramen was very good all around.  Most SF ramen places have really weak broth.  I was pleased to slurp down the extra fatty and rich pork broth.  They have the best broth in town.  I had the premium pork ramen.  I was a little confused as to why they didn't use a fattier slice of pork (as in fat content not width).  I suppose it's just a stylistic choice.  There were ample green onions to add a little tang.  The noodles were perfectly al dente.

I had the citron iced tea.  It was very refreshing, but not heavy on the tea flavor.  There were these delightful jellied peel pieces in the bottom that made it something special.

I might up the score to five stars after I try their 'flavored' ramen later in the week.  Can't wait to go back and try a spicy bowl!
author: Natalie R.

description:
I swear the noodles are from a box of spaghetti. Broth not bad and pork mediocre.
 To give my opinion context, I lived in Japan for 3 years, have a Japanese wife, eaten ramen in Sapporo 1/2 dozen times and eat ramen at least once on  my yearly trip back to Japan.
Goes along with most of the Japanese eateries I have visited in the Bay Area. Hard to find good, authentic J food.
author: Deron W.

description:
I had been to Ajisen SF for lunch twice, and I usually patron the Milpitas chain.  This is a pretty small sit down place at the SF Center.  

Miso Ramen is tasty and at Ajisen, it's not as salty compare to other ramen I tried.  
Corn Ramen is pretty good if you like corn.
Tender pork ramen is alright.  The soup is a bit oily from the pork.  

If you want a light ramen, go for the Miso.  The soup tastes very good.

For the price, they don't really give you much toppings.  3 slices of pork and half egg and lots of cabbages.  I have gotten more toppings elsewhere for the same price.

The reason I only gave a 3 star is that the owner for this place was pretty mean.  It was busy during lunch and I asked if he could take my order.  He wouldn't take my order and let me know that I had to order from one of the servers who were busy assisting other customers.   I feel bad for the workers who work there.
author: Rowena T.

description:
Personally, I feel the ramen here is tastier than katana-ya. Perhaps katana-ya has improved since the last visit over a year ago, but I think it's been skeeted on with a bit too much sodium.

Perhaps Ajisen is overlooked because it's "mall food," which is unfortunate, because it's actually pretty decent. Almost as good as the ramen consumed in secret on weeknight at 10PM in a mom n pop ramen house in an alley near a buddhist temple in Kyoto without your instructor's knowledge of you having ever left the premises, lol.
author: Susan K.

description:
This place is really good.  Food is served quickly and the prices are reasonable.  Awesome spot for your one-hour lunch.  I always get the Ajisen ramen.  When not doing ramen, I get the curry.

It's another region of ramen (I want to say southern Japan, but can't remember), so for people expecting Genki or Katana-ya type ramen, well... they're not going to get that.  Accept that there is more than one kind of ramen, and you might enjoy it.
author: Erika C.

description:
My default order at this place is the Ajisen Ramen. I come here often with my husband when we want a quick meal before watching a movie. 

Other items on the menu that my husband and I really like: fried calamari, tonkatsu curry, premium pork ramen, boba milk tea, mango green tea.
author: Paula U.

description: Ajisen is convenient and pretty good. It's definitely not on the top of my ramen list but I can get there easily at lunch time and it's good enough to satisfy that ramen craving. I really wish they would do soft boiled eggs though. A hard boiled egg in ramen is blasphemy.
author: Mark R.

description:
Great service but I think they are still trying to figure out the customer flow since they just opened on Wednesday.  The ramen is just "ok", not something special to write home about.  I have had better ramen at maru ichi   I had miso char shu and it was so-so, the soup was blend and not hot enough, quite oily to say the most.  Portion was small compared to other local ramen place.  For $8.75, I've had better ramen!  

But great to have something different in downtown area nonetheless.

Welcome, Ajisen Ramen!
author: Gary T.

description: This is mall ramen.  Duck into a crowded spot behind the Hello Kitty store and see the vacant eyes of mall patrons staring you down as you slurp.
author: Ivan L.

description:
This one is not quite as good as the ones in SoCal.  As always I got the Premium Pork and the meat was very tender, but the broth just needed a little more flavor. 

Let's just say, if I had a craving for ramen I would probably go to Katana-ya first.  This place would probably be my second choice if it were raining because I don't want to have to wait outside.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
The Good: Ramen quality is just as great as the other Ajisen Ramens. However, the menu is limited to a smaller selection of sides and snacks. The premium pork ramen is definitely worth getting!

The Bad: The management is horrible. For such a small space, there seems to be an overflow of inefficient and inexperienced workers. The most efficient staff was the busboy, who took it upon himself to take on other duties when waiters were busy. We had to repeat our order 3 times before the waitress got our simple order down. The manager was the worst. While his staff was struggling and long lines were forming, he did nothing to assist them. Guest were waiting in front of two cashiers for take out orders. The cashiers didn't begin taking their orders until the guests demanded service. 

Bottom Line: Go here for the food, but don't expect good service or comfortable seating. Not good for parties over 4.
author: Anthony L.

description: Came here on a Tuesday and it was packed, the place is so narrow with the amount of tables that made going to the counter very difficult, even without a tray of food in hand.
author: M C.

description: I had the Ajisen Ramen with Karaage and was satisfied. I really like this location better than the Fremont branch because the Karaage is much closer to what you get in Japan. This is my second visit and very likely to return often.
author: Gene B.

description: This is one of several three-star restaurants on my rolodex.  I'd love to eat a five-star meal everyday, but there are times when I just need a fast, cheap, and easy ramen fix.  I've had about half a dozen of the ramen options, and the premium pork is the sole standout--it's a generous portion of thinly sliced, well seasoned pork.  Everything else just tastes pre-made or pre-packaged.  The noodles aren't fresh and the broth isn't deep, but this is a chain in a mall and I don't expect much more.  For better ramen, take a walk to Katana-Ya.
author: Liz T.

description:
Cheap, quick ramen.  Not bad for food court ramen!  The broth is actually pretty tasty and one of the few I really like; it's milky and not very oily.  Unfortunately the noodles are definitely not ramen noodles, they're thinner and overcooked, so you don't get that nice al dente/QQ chew, and it makes it feel like it's not really ramen... just noodles in good broth.  Chicken kaarage was surprisingly good, juicy cuts of chicken breaded with a thick fried layer.  

Go here if you're stuck in the mall & looking for decent food; if you're looking for a ramen fix... probably better off going to Japantown or Katana-ya.
author: Joyce H.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. I first knew about this chain when I would go to Hong Kong and it would be a ritual to go there everytime I go back. When I saw that it opened in Westfield I was excited. 

I went there for lunch and it turns out that they have to seat you at a table in their establishment. Normally ok but a little confusing seeing that the place was in the mall so you think.. "Don't I just sit where there's an open table?" It was just me so I thought it'd be quick but I guess I hit the lunch time rush so had to wait. 

I was dipping into the conversation of the people in front of me and they were saying they usually order to go and eat out in the food court area. Since I was in a hurry I figured I'd copy their strategy.

 I was waiting in line to order to go and it seemed to take a long time to take each person's order. here was only 3 people in front of me. I know they just opened so maybe they need to figure out flow better. The cash registers are near the only opening for the wait staff to get to the kitchen so the people in line had to constantly move.  After you've placed your order they have you go all the way to the front of the restaurant to wait. Definite flow problem. My suggestion, have a register for to go orders at the front.

Got my order and was walking with it and noticed that the broth was spilling into the bag. When I got home I noticed that there's a big hole in the lid that would normally be used to let out condensation... but don't use that same lid for soup broth!!! The whole was about the size of a nickel. No wonder my bag had soup in it.

I eat my noodles and it's ok. And then 15 minutes later I got a case of the gurggles. Stomach has been rumbling since lunch and has finally calmed down. 

SUMARRY: Bad to go experience, bad flow of traffic in restaurant, and bad stomachache. 

I'll save my ajisen experiences for when I go back to Hong Kong
author: kimy l.

description:
I ate there today for the first time. I had seafood ramen. I intentionally looked for a place to eat in the Nordstrum's food mall rather than the adjoining Bloomingdale's food court. At Bloomingdale's I've had bad service and bad food (from tasteless to much worse after affect).

I gave Ajisen four (4) stars because it was so much better than what I got at the other mall. On its own, I would have given it a three (3) star rating. My seafood ramen had some taste and the service was good. I will eat there again when I am in that area.
author: Gerald B.

description:
Stopped here while on a roundabout in SF. Initial impression of the place is that there were a good amount of people here. Almost every table was full except for maybe one or two. I figured why would a place be packed if it wasn't good?

Being spoiled from Maruchi Ramen in Milpitas, I was expecting a great deal. I was mildly impressed. I felt that the portion sizes were insane. I'm a small girl, I don't need a super sized bowl. It was a turn off. I ordered the chicken ramen. The meat was tender and the broth was okay. I felt that the noodle quality was meh. The bf got the premium pork ramen. He said the meat was really good and he felt the overall ramen bowl was mediocre. He's Japanese so he's had his fair share of homemade and restaurant-made ramen. 

Bottom line: I'm not going to go out of my way to eat here.

The waitress totally forgot our order of gyoza. We had to cancel our order since we were done with our food by the time she noticed that she did not put in the order. I would've gave this place 3-stars but minus one star for the poor service. Overall, I cannot recommend this place to the ramen enthusiast.
author: Stephanie N.

description:
Just A-ok. I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to come and eat here but when I'm craving noodles, I would probably pick this over anything else in the food court. 

I got the Beef Ramen and it was average tasting.  A little bit bland but not terribly bad. I was a bit disappointed that the menu lacked variety. I've been to ajisen in Hong Kong and they Ajisen's overseas taste wayyyyy better and they have more options. I also had a boba tea from here and it wasn't overly sweet like most places. I appreciated that but the tapiocas were bland =[.

Overall, I'd come back again, maybe they can win my heart back with the premium pork.
author: Crystal C.
