Great ramen in the most unexpected location. This is an awesome addition to the Union Square area. 

There was quite a crowd, so we had a to wait a few minutes for a table. We ordered one bowl of the BBQ pork and corn ramen, and one bowl premium pork ramen with added corn ($1 extra).

The corn was a good choice: it added some needed variety to the texture and flavor. The broth itself (tonkotsu) was rich, milky and meaty, but it lacked that extra dimension of flavor that you might find at a place like Santa Ramen. Toward the bottom of the bowl I found myself losing interest in the broth.

Still, this was a very satisfying bowl of ramen. The portions of noodles and pork were extremely generous. Noodles were firm and had the right flavor. Both the BBQ pork and the premium pork were tasty, but I think I preferred the thicker, fattier (and more affordable) BBQ pork.

As I said, the extra order of corn was important. Otherwise there weren't many interesting goodies: no bamboo shoots, a tiny amount of seaweed, no ginger, no garlic. The premium pork bowl didn't come with egg. I found myself craving kimchi to add some crunch and extra flavor, but they didn't have it.

Service was friendly and energetic, with staff shouting "irashaimase!" as customers arrived and "arigatou gozaimashta!" as they left.

In addition to ramen, the menu has lots of cold drinks like bubble tea, and they serve gyoza, agedashi tofu and curry rice.
author: Matt B.

description:
Been looking at the "coming soon" sign on the wall for many months.   Finally opened, and I was able to try it out just a couple days after the grand opening.  

Well, it's exactly as advertised.  A pretty good franchise ramen joint... no more... no less.  It's just like your average department store ramen you'd find in Japan.  Good customer service, clean restaurant, and what I'm sure will be consistently decent ramen.

To the folks compaining about price.  I think we Americans don't neccessarily understand that ramen is considered fast food.  In Japan, you eat your bowl of ramen very quickly and then move out for the next customers.  How can a small restaurant in downtown SF possibly thrive financially selling $8.00 bowls of soup if every customer takes a table for 45 minutes or more?
author: Bob D.

description: food was mediocre... 2 or at best 3 stars but worst yet...  beware of scam - waitress will tell you that your credit card(s) been declined...  and thus need to pay cash (luckily was carrying enuf)... didn't get change or receipt after paying and waiting for a while.  called cc co's afterwards and they said no attempts were ever made!! huh??!!  maybe their credit card machine is broken but seems something fishy (pun intended) going on....
author: Trader H.

description: Wanted to try this place because it was close by.  Tried the spicy pork ramen, but was disappointed because it was so spicy that was all I could taste.  I couldn't taste the base broth very well. Also the noodles were like spaghetti texture and not how ramen should be so that was a huge disappointment. The pork in the ramen was really good though.  Hubby got the spicy beef ramen and pretty much tasted the same but the beef was pretty good.  All in all it was okay, but I probably wouldn't go again because the noodles just don't have that ramen flavor.
author: Cindy W.

description: i normally avoid the mall like a case of scabies, but i had an errand to run and decided to indulge my noodle obsession while i was there. good ramen. i got the ramen with the ribs. my server, yuliani, was particularly pleasant and helpful when when i asked her to bring me her favorite bowl and she brought me a side of vinegar for shits 'n grins to pour on it. yum. A+ on service.
author: cyrus t.

description: There isn't anything in Aji-sen that will blow your mind (after all, it IS a food court, and while I'm not used to ramen in food courts back in Texas... it's still a food court), but it's a good fix for when you're hungry and/or cold.  People have complained about the pasta being like angel hair -- this is true; they do not use udon noodles but rather a thin angel hair-style noodle that is more reminiscent of that found in instant ramen.  However, I looked past this and still very much enjoyed my meal.  I had the chicken ramen, and there was really nothing I disliked about it.  The chicken was good, the noodles were good and not overcooked, and the broth was actually quite tasty.  I'm also very pleased with their selection of iced/bubble teas.  I had a mango tea and was satisfied by it.  The prices might be a bit high, but that's what you get for the convenience of being in a mall, I suppose.  I thought they were rather fair.
author: Olga P.

description: I love ramen. So when I found out the San Francisco Center just opened one, I was excited to try it. I went there, the place looked nice, a little cramped, but I thought it was expected with the amount of space they had to work with. The service was alright. I think they're friendly, but I think they need to be more attentive. I ordered the Spicy Beef ramen. Yum Yum Yum. I thought it tasted so good, for a food court restaurant. The proportion was a good size. The bowls and everything has a picture of a little Asian girl on it, which I find so adorable. I wish the soup was more spicy, but that's just my tasting. The beef was so nice and tender. I think this is definitely a good place to eat after a long day of shopping, away from all the fast food and fried.  The price is average, $7-9, a bowl. There's also yummy snacks and drinks. I will be coming here to eat more often on my shopping days.
author: Trina D.

description: I am a regular at Ajisen Ramen and have a "standing" Wednesday night date with my daughter, son-in-law and new Grandson. We are always greeted by Yuliani with a big smile and cheery attitude; nice after a hard day at work. We've tried almost everything on the menu and find it to be consistently delicious! The service is great!Even the location is welcoming because it is tucked in the corner of "The Nordstrom Center" away from the hustle ,bustle and noise of The Westfield Food Court. Love my Wednesday nights!
author: sandie m.

description: Our unit at work went to Ajisen Ramen for a little team building. Dan-Dan and I are both avid Japan-o-philes. So of course, when we settled on going out to lunch Dan sent out the SF Weekly review to this Ramen place. We were all pretty stoked to check out this Asian chain. It brought a little to look forward to. All in all, we all had a very satiating and tasty experience. To quote one coworker, "I was extremely satisfied." She had ordered the short-rib Ramen whereas I ordered the spicy pork Ramen. The broth itself was so comforting. I would''ve given this place a 4 had the waiter not screwed up the whole check even when we all ordered separate checks. I think a good way of dealing with confusion, especially when dealing with money, is more discretion. And to their credit, when we walked in, they totally catered to our large party by making space in a pretty packed and cramped floor. Overall, this place was good ta go. The prices ranged from $8-12 dollars per dish. My 2 coworkers shared an aloe drink that they really liked. I want to try it next time I go there. So I guess that sums it all up, I'd totally go back!
author: Amelia Q.

description: This is one of my favorite places to get ramen; my favorite ramen from this place is Tender Pork Ribs Ramen -- it's really good. Their prices are reasonable, and the customer service is also good, especially Yuliani -- She is really nice.  Stop by and try out their ramen if you are inside the Westfield Shopping Centre or just cravin' for some.
author: Stephen G.

description: The pork Ramen is really good,Yuliani is a great Server!, they are fast, cheap and easy. The weekends can get busy, but i prefer to go in on the weekday nights no lines at all.
author: Chris S.

description: I always eat at ajisen ramen, but only yesterday i found out my server's name. Yuliani is the one who served good. Some other day i ate there, and the service was teribble...
author: Robert S.

description: Nothing special, will not be back again. I order a curry beef ramen. The soup is very important in a bowl of ramen, but their soup has too much oil and taste too fat.
author: Li L.

description: I ate here with the boyfriend yesterday, I have just been reminded to why I stopped coming here. -1 star already right when you walk in, they yell across the place to tell you where to sit, -1 star because they literally ask you every 30 seconds if you're ready to order after they had just say "that's okay, take your time" & -1 star because they don't have options! I mean I guess it's my fault for not looking at the outside menu before coming in but still, they have like 10 choices, for a place at the food court in the mall, shouldn't you offer more? HELLO! You are competing with every other food place in the mall. Bleh, food doesn't even deserve to be called ramen. The only thing I half liked was the milk tea, it was good but for 3 dollars? I wouldn't come back here.
author: Diane B.

description: We ordered Premium Pork Ajisen Ramen and Ajisen Ramen. The taste of both our broth was similar and pretty bland. Even though the pork portion was big, it was not tender enough like any other ramen place i ever go. If you are craving for good ramen, you should go to non-franchise ramen restaurant.
author: Immanuel L.

description: what is that? noodles and soup. do not combine well to make it a ramen
author: Justin K.

description: Meh.  Bland broth, pretty skimpy on the noodles - bunch of limp green onions was the most interesting thing in the bowl.  Skip it.
author: Mabel E.

description: I love this place! I was so excited when they first opened because I'm a total ramen lover. My first time here I had the tender pork ribs ramen and I devoured it. It was absolutely delish! The pork rib was super juicy and tender. The ramen was not too hard or chewy and not soggy, and the broth was perfectly seasoned not too salty... it was such a heavenly experience :). I've also had the Ajisen Ramen, that's a standard one. The spicy pork ramen is really good too. It's pretty spicy for when you want some kick to your ramen. I've also had the premium pork that one is so-so. I wasn't so crazy for the cut of the pork meat so thinly sliced. I've also had the miso ramen with bbq pork, that's also a winner. The pork slices are so tender and the miso broth is delightful. It's a little bit creamy and a good salty, not I need to down a gallon of water salty. I could drink every drop (and sometimes I do), but I know that's not the best thing to do gulping all that sodium. I've also had some of the rice dishes. Their fried chicken is tasty. I've had it as a curry dish and by itself as a snack. Their curry is ok. I've definitely had better japanese curry, but it's decent. Their curry tonkatsu is the only thing that I've tried on the menu that wasn't a thumbs up. The pork was really dry and tough and soaking it in the curry sauce did not help. But besides that everything else is great! The staff is super friendly. It get's really busy and this place is a mall spot so it's small and limited seating. The wait is killer so I usually take it to go. The only time I sit there to eat is if it's early enough. The mall opens at 10am, but they technically don't start serving their food until 10:30am, which sucks sometimes when I have to take an early lunch. And it's a little pricey, but so are most ramen places. I have never seen ramen under $8. I think this place is pretty worth it.
author: Michelle M.

description: Slightly less than average Ramen, nothing to rave about. Would only go here if I really crave for Ramen in the area and I am too lazy to drive 15 min. to J-town area (Genki, Halu, etc.).
author: Oyster K.

description: This was my first time trying Japanese ramen, not the packaged kind.  The restaurant looked like a quick-and-go place, but it was an actual place to sit and eat.  Before we sat down, I was eying on the fried tofu.  For $3, I got 2 medium pieces of tofu.  Besides the green onions sprinkled on top, there was nothing really special about the tofu.  It was plain, and the tempura sauce (i.e. watered down soy sauce) didn't taste too good.  The tofu was lightly fried, which I like, but just lacking flavor.  I also ordered the spicy beef stew ramen.  I like the chewy noodles.  I can't remember much, but the soup spoon was pretty cool...you basically drink soup with a short ladle.  Now I want to try a real ramen place.
author: Cindy H.

description: my go to place for nice warm japanese ramen! love this place its yumm the broth is delicious and the noodle are done well.
author: Samantha Y.

description: My go to place for Ramen. The portions are big and its a decent sit down restaurant for the mall. Order the roast pork ramen. It's similar to hawaiian style kahlua pork. Tender and plentiful. There is only one broth but you can spice it up as hot as you like. To add extras are 2.00 and are not very generous. Fish cake was 2 thin slices. Could barely find it. The servers are always pleasant.
author: kelly y.

description: I ordered chicken ramen and was looking around as I waited for my order and I noticed the inspection card = 84. To make a long story short, there was a fly in my soup. I told the cashier and she said, "Sorry, that will be $9.80".
author: Orisela T.

description: I've been there so many times! I like thier miso ramen because it's really good for the price. and they sell really good drinks too. and one of the guys looks very cute. XDDD....  highly recommend to try it if u r shopping there.
author: Bella W.

description: Large variety of decent ramen located conveniently in SF Centre. Definitely will go back if I don't want to wait in the Katana Ya line. (also slightly cheaper)
author: Mei F.
